column12: and at this point in the book I really wished I wasn't reading it
column13: but I guess some part of me wanted to find out what happened
column14: and I felt that the ending was a let down.  Mostly
column15: I feel that this topic could have been really
column19: but the book's lackluster plot and storytelling left me flat.  I won't recommend this book."

column6: "reviewText": "In this sensitive portrayal of love and war
column7: author Itani reveals the life of Grania O'Neill from her earliest days in Deseronto
column9: through her marriage to Jim Lloyd
column10: who serves in the Ambulance Corps during World War I.  Grania has been deaf since the age of five
column11: and Itani opens her inner world to the reader
column12: using Grania's voice to tell the story and gracefully conveying her deafness as part of her selfhood
column13: not as a handicap.  Using short sentences of twelve to fifteen words when Grania is a young child trying to figure out her world
column14: Itani begins the story in a simple subject-verb-object pattern
column15: using no complicated clauses or involved syntax
column16: which Grania herself would be incapable of using.  When Grania becomes fluent in sign language and lip-reading
column17: the sentence structure becomes more complex.  By the time she marries Jim
column19: sentences and syntax are fully developed
column20: and Grania's ability to recognize ambiguity
column22: and to respond fully to a hearing world are obvious in her "voice."The point of view alternates between Grania and Jim
column23: once Jim goes off to war
column27: and strength and dependence--weave and develop throughout their contrasting worlds
column28: Grania at home and Jim at the front in Belgium.  Itani develops these age-old themes in new ways
column29: sensitively incorporating them with the imagery of sounds and silence
column30: sight and shadows
column31: action and inaction
column32: images we have come to associate with the life Grania and Jim share.  In Jim's traumatic world
column33: sound becomes overwhelming:  pounding guns
column34: explosions
column35: screams of agony from wounded soldiers.  As a result of his life with Grania
column37: he is also acutely sensitive to what he sees
column39: ironically
column40: that it is the hands of the dead and dying that communicate most vividly because they "revealed the final argument: clenched in anger
column41: relaxed in acquiescence
column42: seized in a posture of surprise or forgiveness."The subordinate characters further flesh out the themes.  The friendship and interdependence of Jim and Irish
column43: his best friend parallel the love and support Grania has received from her sister
column44: her remarkable grandmother
column45: and her deaf friends.  Grania gains strength through them and is able to give support and strength to others when they need her
column46: just as Jim gains strength from his relationship with Irish and continues to rescue the wounded and dying.  As the reader comes to know Grania and Jim and the love they feel for each other
column47: Grania's silent but active world becomes more and more understandable to the reader.  Ultimately
column48: the reader has to agree with Grania when she declares
column49: ironically
column50: "Sound is always more important to the hearing."  Mary Whipple"
column51: "overall": 4.0
column52: "summary": "Graceful and original treatment of man's oldest themes."

column6: "reviewText": "The title may be Deafening
column7: but the book is anything but.  It's very quiet--too quiet.  As we try to inhabit the life and mind of Grania
column8: deaf since the age of five from scarlet fever
column9: we imagine what it would be like not to know when someone is approaching from behind
column10: or to know when the speaker has changed in a conversation.  This book was just too slow-paced for me and the characters too one-dimensional.  Grania and her hearing husband Jim seem to be without fault.  More complex is Grania's sister Tress
column11: who struggles with her emotions when her husband comes back from WWI disfigured and dysfunctional.  Another interesting character is their mother
column12: who postpones sending Grania to a school for the deaf as long as possible
column13: while she battles her guilt over Grania's hearing loss and seeks a cure via specialists and spiritual quests.  However
column14: the author doesn't fully explore the inner conflicts of Tress or her mother
column15: and we are left with a love story between two very nice people.  Jim's story is more disturbing than Grania's
column17: as he becomes a stretcher bearer during the war and sees both friends and patients blown up inches away from him on a regular basis.  His sections of the book are very moving reminders that the lives lost in wars are not just statistics.  The most moving and ironic incident is Jim's wordless interaction with a German counterpart as they both struggle to rescue their wounded on the battlefield."

column6: "reviewText": "This is my surprise book of the year. It was a gift
column7: and I didn't quite know what to expect
column8: but it's turned into a real winner.Spanning the years from 1902 till the end of WWI
column9: we follow the life of Grania
column10: a child/woman who became deaf following scarlet fever. From a loving middle-class family
column11: she went to a boarding school for hundreds and hundreds of deaf children
column12: grew into a self-sufficient young woman
column15: Jim. He went off to war
column16: as did her childhood friend and brother-in-law
column17: Kenan. Improbably for that Great War
column18: both men returned - but in very different conditions.Divided into several parts
column19: the early chapters are Grania's education
column20: learning to live as a deaf person in the world of the hearing. The next part is Jim's story of his war experience.Then comes Grania's ultimately successful efforts to return the power of speech to her mute and traumatized childhood friend. And finally the resolution of all the stories.This book grows on you. One of the boldest risks author Itani took was to try (successfully) to convey Grania's silent world to readers
column21: and to imitate the understanding of sign language as well as lip reading for those of us unfamiliar with the Deaf World.It's a stunning and powerful book
column22: showing the power of Story to convey love

column6: "reviewText": "I really enjoyed "The Deafening."  I read it after reading another book by Itani which I really enjoyed.  Like most Americans I don't know as much about Canada as I should.  The novel grabbed my attention at the beginning and held it to the end.  It also made me feel so lucky that I have my hearing.  The scenes of the hardships of the men fighting WW1 were difficult to read
column7: but that is war and I think it is something we all should think about."
column9: "summary": "The Things I Learned about the education of the deaf"

column6: "reviewText": "A great novel!This  book
column7: by Francis Itani
column8: revolves around the world of a girl/woman who as acquired deafness through childhood illness. The setting is initially in Ontario
column9: Canada in the late 1800's and then eventually alternating between Ontario and the European theater of World War I.I must admit I had some difficultly getting into this work
column10: but I persevered and I'm glad I did
column11: because this book is truly a magnificent read. Once committed
column12: I could barely stand to put the book down.As with all great books
column14: is the quality of the writing.  The prose just seemed to flow effortlessly off the pages as time melted away. You learn things about deafness
column15: quietness and darkness that you never really noticed before;  you begin to appreciate what people without hearing have to endure to get through an hour
column16: a day or a lifetime. There were a couple of occasions in this book where I was taken aback with a new revelation regarding deafness; where I would just let this book slip to my lap and think about what I'd just read.There are parts in this book that are not for the faint of heart; some of the description of the trench warfare in France and Belgium are very graphic and disturbing. (but
column19: a story that is quietly beautiful and at the same time beautifully sad. Really
column20: one of my favorite books. If I had to compare it to another book for quality
column22: then I'd pick Charles Frazier's \" Cold Mountain\". Both books have that intangible timeless aura to them that separate them from their peers.Highly recommended!"

column6: "reviewText": "Canadian author Frances Itani had a promising idea to write about the education and early life of a girl struck deaf in infancy
column7: as her own grandmother was at the turn of the last century. And it was an intriguing one to contrast her silent world with the cacophony of the western front in World War I. The novel that results contains interesting characters and effective passages
column8: but it is too diffuse to really work.Grania O'Neill -- the name is an anglicization of the Irish for \"love\" -- loses her hearing at the age of five as a result of scarlet fever. She wakens to a world shaped and contained by words
column9: but where language is deceptive and words have to be agonizingly relearned. She has an ally in her grandmother Mamo; the relationship between the two is the most lovely thing in the book. But I found the early chapters repetitive and could never enter fully into Grania's world. I was more interested in the relatively brief section dealing with her time at a special boarding school and the battle between the two theories of education for the deaf: sign language and the oral method.As a young adult
column10: Grania falls in love and marries. But it is 1915
column11: and her husband Jim goes off to war as a medical orderly. The unusual perspective makes some of the war writing quite powerful
column12: occasionally approaching the intensity of classics such as Sebastian Faulks'BIRDSONG. And the scenes back in Canada show something even less often written about
column13: a picture of wartime life on the home front. But the fact remains that there is an ocean between Grania and Jim
column14: and their parallel stories barely connect. Still
column15: a few touching episodes do manage to bridge the gap
column16: as when one of their friends returns wounded and mute
column17: and Grania teaches him once more to talk.This is a book that needed to dwell in language and sound
column18: and above all in silence. It calls for an almost abstract style that can handle ideas and sensations rather than events -- poetry rather than prose. The steady narrative that Itani offers contains much that will interest and even move its readers
column19: but for this reader at least the most exciting promises are lost."

column6: "reviewText": "It is only March and I have already voted this book for my Book of the Year Award
column7: which I normally select toward the end of the year.  This book was beautifully written.  You could see the human emotions coming through the characters and it made me want to keep turning the pages to see what was going to happen.  You feel both sorrow and joy in the characters.  Frances Itani knows the human heart and displays it so well on paper.  Great job!  I am going to make this book a part of my permanent library."

column6: "reviewText": "The true test of an author is the ability to portray the mind of someone else.  Recently
column7: that ability has been stretched by writers who describe the \"abnormal\".  The young
column8: autistic Christopher in \"Curious Incident\" is the prime example.  Frances Itani takes us into a different world
column9: that of the deaf.  It's a world of endless confusion.  There are sounds
column11: but meaningless to the deaf.  We think speech is the only important sound
column14: and indistinct.  Nature produces her own sounds which we use in speech
column15: but for which there's no meaning to the deaf.  Through Grania O'Brien's early life
column16: Itani strives to introduce us to that world.  Does she succeed?Grania
column17: who would have been \"Grainne\" in her ancestral Ireland
column18: lives in small-town Ontario as the story opens.  Deafened by scarlet fever [remember that?]
column20: her grandmother.  Blessed with a quick eye for lip-reading
column21: Grania is given a book with words displayed as rope.  The rope
column23: becomes highly symbolic as the book progresses
column24: but Grania begins to equate the shapes with meaning.  Mamo strains to have the girl equate printed words with proper sounds.  It's important that Grania \"blend in\" with the rest of the community.  With her parents running a hotel
column25: Grania's only other tie is with her sister Tress
column26: with whom she develops a secret sign language.All of Mamo's dedicated effort
column28: can't force the pace.  Grania is to leave home for a \"Deaf School\".  Itani portrays the school as staffed with immensely caring ladies.  No Dickens intrudes with harsh discipline or abuse
column29: but the school draws children from across the Province.  All the children remain in school until the summer holidays.  Sign language is discouraged for those who can speak - dividing the children
column30: some of whom are mute.  Itani passes rapidly over Grania's progress in the school.  The deaf girl
column31: however
column32: manages to shed some of her fear of the dark - a long-held terror.Meeting a young aide in a hospital after leaving the school
column33: Grania's life takes a new turn.  The courtship is but a moment in the story - the wedding description not even related until much later in the book.  Instead
column34: the Kaiser rudely intrudes on their lives with the invasion of Belgium.  Itani carefully rejects any political discussion in the narrative.  King and Country [Britain
column35: not Canada] are under threat and Jim must sign up.  There's no family discussion
column36: no question of how Irish immigrants in a far land should react - Jim crosses the Atlantic.  There's a training stint
column37: then Jim finds himself in the thick of battle.  When time and circumstances permit
column38: letters are scribbled in muddy trenches.  Sometimes Grania's reach Jim
column39: but delays in the exchanges make communication a flimsy thread.Itani makes a splendid effort to depict the impact of the Great War.  Confronted as we are today by daily images of conflict
column40: Itani still manages to impart a special sense of horror at events.  The years pass with Jim
column41: a stretcher-bearer
column42: braving the bombardments and fusillades of machine-gun fire
column43: without being able to fight back.  He carries wounded
column44: tends their injuries
column45: dodges fire and grows increasingly introspective.  Never once
column46: does he question the worth of the conflict.  At home in Desoronto
column47: Grania watches the causality lists
column49: lengthen while she worries.  Soldier's wives need more visibility and Itani's effort is commendable.This book cries out for a sequel.  Grania's life hardly ends with the Armistice.  With the end of the War
column50: her deafness remains
column51: the family is almost intact and a future must unroll.  Itani has built a unique scenario with skillful prose.  You will not find it easy to put this book down as you read.  However
column53: you will find the conclusion abrupt.  Nothing is lost by that finale
column54: but there might be much gained by going on.  [stephen a. haines - Ottawa

column6: "reviewText": "If you are interested in what shaped Sir John Franklin before his abortive exploration in the Arctic
column7: McGoogan presents a tour-de-force portrait of his second wife
column9: an indefatigable traveler and adventurer. I read this book for insights into 19th Century Tasmania and was not disappointed. Excerpts from letters and newspapers give a clear sense of public and private reflections on this colonial period

column6: "reviewText": "I have just finished McGoogan's book about John Rae and his search for the northwest passage. Rae's search also found the first  proof that Franklin and his men had perished in the Arctic. Instead of gratitude
column7: Lady Fgranklin turned on Rae and this is the next book that sheds light on this enduring tragedy. It will be an other 'can't put it down book'."

column6: "reviewText": "I ordered this book through one of Amazon Marketplace sellers as it was no longer offered by Amazon itself. While the book is in the shape I ordered it (used-very good)
column7: I have not read it yet as I only just received it after ordering in it on 11/26/10. I received the book mid January

column6: "reviewText": "A very indepth (some think too indepth
column7: but  I loved that) look at a very amazing person in the context of an interesting time.Some of the best historical fiction I've ever read."

column6: "reviewText": "This book
column7: though long
column8: chronicles an amazing lady for any historical period
column9: but especially Victorian times.  Her wealth
column10: influence and encouragement made wonderful human rights progress in Tasmania
column12: as well as in her native England.  After her captain husband was deemed lost in his search for the Northwest Passage
column13: she spent over 20 years and millions of dollars searching for answers to what happened to him and his expedition.  In the process she made significant progress and discoveries.  A world traveller when most women rarely left there own local home areas
column14: Lady Franklin is an inspiration for the ages.  The 'revenge' refers not only to her quest to exonerate the false slandering of Lord Franklin's good name and works
column15: but also her victory over a harsh environment of frozen waste.  An amazing read of one amazing lady."

column6: "reviewText": "I just finished reading this book.  It is interesting to me that many of the reviews focus on his chapter on Milk.  I didn't take that much from that chapter
column7: but simply that the verdict isn't really out on Milk.  I think he would have done better to address the question of raw or pasteurized--another big subject of debate.  But
column8: that logically must come from the belief first that milk is good for you and I didn't really feel that he made a decisive decision about it though he leaned more towards milk than away from it.There were several things I enjoyed about this book.  I enjoyed learning a lot of nutritional history--like the history of vitamins and how different things in our food (like canola oil) were developed.  There were also interesting chapters about various vitamins.  I now finally understand why there are vitamins B6 and B12
column9: but not B7 and B8 (they were originally named and then discarded because people realized they had no nutritional value).  There was a very interesting (to me) chapter about detox diets and the lack of scientific evidence that they do any good.  In fact
column10: there is no evidence that there are health benefits to them.But
column11: the reason I haven't given it 4 or 5 stars
column12: is that the author leans heavily towards the opinion that chemicals in our food is just fine.  Even given his scientific evidence
column13: I am not fully persuaded.  Many of the things he talked about haven't been around for years
column14: so we don't know their long term effects.  It was just this year that several reports were published stating that artificial sweeteners are digested the same as regular sugar and do not contribute to weightloss.  Which
column16: I was very surprised that he didn't talk about Splenda at all but he did talk about other artificial sweeteners.  I did notice after another reviewer mentioned it that studies are mentioned
column17: but not footnoted or identified in an appendix at the back of the book."

column6: "reviewText": "Although the premise of the book is sound - to examine the accuracy of common food beliefs - the work is unimpressive and completely unhelpful. There's plenty of scientific research quoted
column7: but some of the nutrition information and \"conclusions\" about various foods is wrong or terribly misleading. No matter what your interest is in reading about food and nutrition
column8: you will be better served by skipping this book and opting for something else."

column6: "reviewText": "Near the end of the book
column7: Joe Schwarcz quotes Mark Twain's famous maxim that \"It ain't what you don't know that gets you into trouble. It's what you know for sure that just ain't so.\"  If (some of) the reviews for this book are any indication
column8: Dr. Joe was right: scientific scrutiny is unlikely to change anyone's mind.  People continue to smoke
column9: people continue to eat mostly red meat
column10: etc.  Those people who eat red meat and smoke are often willing to admit they are participating in unhealthy behaviour.  So much more
column12: is it difficult or impossible to convince people through the scientific literature that their preconceived notions are not correct when the topic is not something for which literally billions of people have served as experimental subjects (through their normal activities).  That is an observation that is mostly independent of the book's qualities as prose and entertainment
column13: but it does identify the point from which this book starts.In a series of bite-sized chapters (3-5 pages)
column14: Schwarcz takes us through some of the topics he's encountered and researched in his role as a science commentator over the last 30 (?) years.  As such
column15: I would suggest that the topics are a little skewed to the supplements side - there are many chapters devoted to particular dietary supplements with supposedly miraculous effects (to cure cancer
column17: etc.).  These claims are usually laughably easy to dismiss because the \"evidence\" of their efficacy is non-existent.  The book is much more interesting when he tackles issues of pesticides
column20: the scientific literature shows that the amounts of these items in an average diet are so small as to be non-issues.  Sure
column21: they cause cancer - in amounts millions of times as large as humans take in.  And these amounts are far less than the naturally occurring carcinogens that we are exposed to automatically because we breath and eat food.  This leads to the primary thesis of the book
column22: with which no nutritional expert could argue: eat a good balanced diet that emphasizes vegetables
column24: and whole grains.This thesis is proven again and again throughout the book
column25: and the primary problem of this book is its repetative nature.  In trying to keep each chapter reasonably autonomous
column26: and because the conclusions are virtually the same each time
column27: the author cannot possibly make the book entertaining for long reading times.  It's more of a \"pick up
column29: put down for a couple days\" kind of book.Other reviewers have objected to the lack of footnotes.  This is a valid criticism; I suppose it was a conscious choice on the author's and editor's parts (for ease of readability).  Certainly I would have prefered if the studies he cites were more clearly referenced.  (Rise and Fall of the Third Reich had thousands of references
column30: so it's insulting to think that the reader would pass on buying the book simply because they are in there
column31: especially as this book's raison d'etre is to bring to the public the objective scientific conclusions on the nutritional questions raised in the book).  I would add the criticism that two hot-button nutritional issues are not dealt with.  (1) Bisphenol-A
column32: a monomer used in polycarbonate synthesis
column33: has been banned by Health Canada and others
column34: but ruled safe (in the amounts present in polycarbonate drinking and storage vessels) by the FDA.  Based on the number of articles I see (in newspapers and even the American Chemical Society's magazine)
column35: this chemical is perfectly positioned for the Dr. Joe treatment
column36: and I find it curious that it is omitted.  (2) Perhaps because this movement has only gained real traction since the book was written it was not included
column37: but the \"eat local\" mantra is in conflict with the \"eat lots of variety\" mantra espoused by nutritionists and featured prominently in the book.  If you live in a breadbasket (e.g. California)
column38: you can have a widely varied diet throughout the year.  If you live in a northern clime (e.g. northern Minnesota
column39: most of Canada)
column40: you will not have access to locally grown fresh fruit and veggies for most of the year.  Eating as Dr. Schwarcz suggests would leave you with an enormous carbon footprint due to the transportation and refrigeration costs of moving the food from southern locations.It is also curious that Dr. Joe never mentions the placebo effect.  Some remedies are effective because the patient thinks they will be effective.  Sure
column41: double-blind studies take this into account (people receiving the placebo and the test compound are both going to benefit from the placebo effect
column42: so any additional effect in the test group will be due to the efficacy of the test compound)
column43: but anecdotal \"evidence\" is easy to accumulate by charletons
column44: and these testamonials can certainly be true!  If you're one of the lucky ones whose cancer goes into remission at the same time as you started drinking three litres of acai juice a day
column45: you will certainly \"know\" that the acai juice caused the remission.  So it's my unfortunate conclusion that Dr. Joe is singing to the choir with this book - those with a scientific/statistical background will be convinced
column46: but we were convinced anyways.  Those who are the statistical outliers will still be convinced of their positions
column47: and the charletans will continue to make money off of them."
column49: "summary": "Some neat tidbits
column50: but it's somewhat repetative and unfortunately it's unlikely to change anyone's mind"
column51: "unixReviewTime": 1257120000

column6: "reviewText": "\"Phew! That was a lot to digest
column7: wasn't it?\"Those are the words author Joe Schwarcz uses at the conclusion of his book which is jam-packed with the latest data
column9: and drama about the foods (and chemicals <gasp!> therein) we eat. His book is indeed a full-course meal...and then some.First
column10: he leads us through a tour of naturally occurring substances in our food supply
column18: he presents the most controversial issues related to the manipulation of our food supply: fortifying with  iron and fluoride;  sweetening with natural and artificial sweeteners; manipulating genes in our food; and preserving with sulphites
column21: he takes us up close and personal with the contaminants in our food supply
column28: Joe leads us through the nutritional hype surrounding some of the latest nutritional fads such as goji juice
column30: DHEA
column31: and green tea.It's likely your head will be spinning after consuming all the nutritional chemistry
column32: controversy and and commentary that Joe serves up. (And
column33: to answer his question above: yes
column34: it is a lot to digest!) He does do an impressive job in guiding us through the maze of myths
column35: misconceptions and truths about the foods we eat
column36: but--as food science is rarely a conclusive one--be prepared to be confused at times.  Fortunately
column37: Joe offers relief at the end of the book

column6: "reviewText": "In \"An Apple a Day\" the McGill University professor Joe Schwarcz offers salient useful nutritional advice.  Eat lots of fruits and vegetables.  Meat is fine but make sure you have more whole grains on your plate.  Emphasize variety and balance in your diet.  Avoid processed foods
column7: especially those high in fat
column9: and salt.  Exercise.  There are no miracle foods and short cuts to a healthy diet.That's great advice that comes at page 353 of this 355-page book.  I have many issues with the structure of the book
column10: the main being Dr. Schwarcz's decision to divide his book into easily digestible chapters tackling all the major food debates out there:  organic
column13: and so on.  It would have been a much better book if Dr. Schwarcz structured it around his main thesis:  that there are no short cuts to a healthy diet.Science has spent decades and billions of dollars analyzing the different components of food in the hope of distilling the magical qualities of apples and tomatoes
column14: and selling it in a bottle.  There is no scientific basis for the overwhelming superiority of a certain vitamin
column16: or nutritional supplement.  Quite the opposite:  eating or drinking too much of a good thing can be a bad thing.  Seeking balance
column18: and variety in nutrition is the best and only path to good health."

column6: "reviewText": "Joe Schwarcz tells us what to eat and backs his advice up with the best and most verified lab results from all over the world. If you just love chemistry you'll love this book but if you care about yourself you'll find him a treasure chest of tips to live a long healthy time."
column7: "overall": 5.0
column8: "summary": "An Apple A Day keeps old age away!"

column6: "reviewText": "Schwarcz is a Professor of Chemistry who has written several books about diet and nutrition. Judging by this book I'm thinking he should stick to chemistry.I'm not saying that Schwarcz's dietary recommendations are bad. After you take away the discussions of chemical terms and processes you end up with the same sort of recommendations you've been hearing about for decades: Eat mostly foods based on vegetables
column7: fruits
column11: is there ANY nutrition book out there that recommends eating mostly meat
column14: and overeating?I majored in biology at college
column15: so I thought that a chemistry-focused discussion of nutrition would be interesting. I was wrong. I can't really fault Schwarcz for that
column16: because his book makes it clear that it will get into some chemistry
column17: and many of the chemicals in foods have long
column18: hard to pronounce names. But the subtitle to the book led me to believe that the chemistry discussion would be enlivened by learning about \"the myths
column20: and truths about the foods we eat.\" Again I was wrong
column21: and this time I can fault Schwarcz. Schwarcz ends up recommending the same type of whole-food
column22: unprocessed diet as any mainstream diet book
column23: so I wonder just which myths and misconceptions he thinks he is addressing? He recommends that meat should be \"an occasional treat
column24: \" and even then the portion size \"should cover a small portion of the plate.\" Those people who still believe in the \"myth\" that humans need to eat lots of meat would sooner barbecue Schwarcz's book than read it. Regarding other myths and misconceptions
column26: well-trod ground. I suppose this book might be helpful to someone who has had his head in the nutritional sands for the past two decades.I can't forgive the chapter on milk. His discussion of calcium and osteoporosis is superficial at best. He doesn't address any of the major risk factors for osteoporosis
column27: nor does he discuss the chemical processes underlying them
column28: nor effective countermeasures. He doesn't offer a single study demonstrating that consuming dairy lowers the incidence of bone fractures
column29: which seems strange considering that this is the dairy industry's number one claim to fame. Schwarcz does point to two studies which contradict his claim that milk is good for bones
column30: but he blatantly dismisses them. One study shows that \"Asians have a lower incidence of osteoporosis than Westerners even though they consume less dairy.\" Schwarcz responds by saying
column31: \"True enough
column32: but they also have a very different overall diet and lifestyle.\" He leaves it at that
column33: and he doesn't bother to say what parts of the \"very different diet and lifestyle\" are healthier! He then mentions the comprehensive Nurses' Health Study \"which found that nurses who drank two or more glasses of milk a day actually broke more bones and had a higher risk of hip fractures.\" Schwarcz responds by subscribing to a hypothesis that the nurses who drank more milk were the ones who had the weakest bones to begin with! I say hypothesis because he has no evidence for it. To make things worse
column34: Schwarcz goes out of his way to describe anyone who \"criticizes\" milk consumption as part of the \"antimilk lobby
column35: \" driven more by an irrational agenda than any objective analysis of the evidence. I eat moderate amounts of dairy (for taste
column37: and I'm not part of any antimilk lobby
column38: but does that mean I must believe that dairy foods are good for my bones? Schwarcz says that when we \"look at the totality of the evidence
column39: an overwhelming number of studies show that bone strength improves with calcium intake
column40: and dairy products offer the best source of calcium.\" Schwarcz is linking dairy to calcium to bone strength
column41: which in effect means he is suggesting that dairy is good for bones. But again
column42: he doesn't offer even one study which gives any evidence for this claim
column43: and instead shows us two studies which contradict it. Furthermore
column44: Schwarcz dismisses \"antimilk\" arguments that no other species except humans drink milk after weaning. He's missing the entire point: the objective and telling observation that all adult animals on earth thrive without milk. Schwarcz would have us believe as scientific gospel that human adults
column45: for special reasons he never explains
column46: need milk to thrive and prevent bone fractures (except
column47: of course
column49: who have very different diets and lifestyles!).This is the model of clear
column50: rational
column51: scientific thinking we're supposed to follow
column53: that \"leaves readers with a rational framework for evaluating the complex nature of foods and how they affect health.\"? I'd say it's a great example of a cloudy
column55: and incomplete framework. In the end
column56: the best that Schwarcz can do is tell us that milk \"is not a poison
column57: \" as some fringe members of PETA might say.In conclusion
column58: Schwarcz did not bust any new myths or misconceptions and his recommendations are consistent with mainstream recommendations. You know the drill: Eat mostly veggies
column64: get adequate rest. If you do all that don't worry about whatever else you like to eat!"

column6: "reviewText": "I bought this book based on two 5 star customer reviews

column78: not having access to cow's milk

column88: and more environmental contaminates in general

column96: as the Weston A. Price Foundation acknowledges

column11: but it's a good read all the same. Its 300-plus pages fly by
column13: you begin to feel like you're a part of the circus
column14: understanding what it's like to work behind the scenes. It discusses the meaning of love
column16: and honour: what do you owe the people around you?The parts I loved best
column18: and that touched me the most weren't the love story: I've seen too many of its kind before. No
column19: it was the discussion of aging that got to me and made me cry so hard in the last two pages I woke my boyfriend up: what does it mean to age? What does your family owe you as you age? And what does your life mean when you're ninety-something
column21: and alone except for your memories? These questions terrify me: they wrack me with guilt and fear
column23: this book became something more than a beach read. I don't think I'll think of Rosie too much
column24: or Bobo; I don't think I'll remember Jacob or Marlena too often
column25: either. But I will remember Jacob's struggles in the nursing home
column26: and where we leave him when the book ends."

column6: "reviewText": "Since I've never written a review on Amazon
column7: you can bet it would take one heck of a book to get me to do it. Water for Elephants is that book. I buy a LOT of books
column8: and with most of them I'm left feeling dissatisfied. But with this book I read it over a weekend and just tore through it. Solid writing
column11: and a great story. I just love this book! As a fan of HBO's Carnivale
column12: it reminded me a lot of that series
column14: this is NOT a derivative work. I'm just hoping that Gruen will return to this universe in the near future and give us another installment."
column16: "summary": "WOW! Could not put this one down!"

column6: "reviewText": "I have not seen the movie and was not sure how I'd like a book about the circus but a lot of people recommended this novel and it got great reviews so I gave it a try. It was beautifully written with vivid imagery. How could you not fall in love with Jacob? How could you not be enterained with the stories about the circus? How could you not be enthralled with Marlena and Jacob's secret love? I really enjoyed reading it
column7: in fact I could not put it down and it only took me a week to read it. I think this is a story anyone could enjoy
column8: and the author did an amazing job with her research about everything from the circus to the prohibition. The parts about the old man got kind of depressing but there was a happy ending for all at the end. Highly recommended. Lovely read."

column6: "reviewText": "This is a fabulous story
column7: written with humor
column8: compassion and profound insight. We are first presented with Jacob Jankowski as an elderly man in a nursing home. The old coot may have problems with his short-term memory
column9: but he certainly has a terrific long-term memory when it comes to remembering the details of his youthful days in a travelling circus. I thought that I had no interest whatsoever in the workings of a depression-era circus
column10: including the care of the exotic animals and the various freaks and acts. However
column11: the author depicts this unique microcosm of humanity with such passion and color that I found myself absolutely absorbed in the story early on.Adding to the historic ambience of this saga are the well-chosen photographs at the start of each chapter: a man with a deformed human growing from his stomach; a woman proudly showing off her bare upper extremities; excited people milling around the big top...It is the undercurrent of spiritual darkness that makes this story fly so high. Gruen depicts the battle between good and evil with stunning accuracy: the greed of Uncle Al; the brutality of August; the surprising kindness of the abandonned dwarf
column12: Walter; and the meek vulnerability of Marlena and her animals.The scene with the drunkard Camel being told that he is dying of poisoning from Jamacai ginger extract is poignant. This
column13: followed by scenes with Camel being cared for in a box car by Walter and Jacob. Stirring
column14: because alternating chapters depict a now elderly Jacob in a similar position of helplessness.In sum
column15: a GREAT book. Whoever thought that an elephant would carry such literary weight? (No pun intended.) I am totally baffled by some of the very negative critiques it has received on Amazon
column16: only to be followed by 5 star praises. Some have said it is poorly written. Are we reading the same story?"
column18: "summary": "A unique and beautiful story for your summer vacation"

column6: "reviewText": "I understand some of the criticism
column7: but does a book have to be a literary masterpiece to be immensely enjoyable?  The overwhelming positive reviews explain why not.It is well researched
column8: but maybe the plot stretched a bit too far at times and low quality dialogues have taken away from the book's otherwise star quality.The depression era was well represented
column9: gave a good realistic feel of the troubled times and the people.  Circus setting was pure genius
column11: it is a very enjoyable book
column14: "summary": "Does it have to be a masterpiece?"

column6: "reviewText": "Every once in a while
column7: there's a book that seems written for you. It speaks to you in a way books you love haven't. You don't just visualize the author's words
column9: and rather than watching the movie in your mind
column10: you are living it. You feel the pain
column12: the laughter. When the book is finished
column13: you're more than disappointed. You feel invigorated
column14: and you search eagerly through the author's books to see what
column16: she has to offer. You search readers' recommendations to find the books that leave the same imprint on you. Inevitably
column17: though the books satiate your appetite
column18: they don't resonate in the same way. Welcome to Sara Gruen's Water for Elephants.In the prologue
column19: we're privy to a murder. We see it as Jacob sees it
column20: and tries in vain to stop it. Though the victim and murderer aren't named
column22: it becomes clear in our mind who filled those roles.Then we start from the beginning
column23: in the midst of the Great Depression. Jacob is in class
column24: during the final few weeks at Cornell preparing for his finals before he becomes a doctor of veterinary medicine.In a moment
column25: the Dean will enter and change his path. Jacob was to go home and set up shop with his father
column26: working with the animals in his town. Instead
column27: he goes home to identify the remains of his mother and father. He sees the sign his father added to their on-site practice: Jankowitz and Son Veterinary Practice. After identifying his family
column29: who tells him he has nothing. The bank owns the house and everything in it. The explanation as to why his parents mortgaged the house shatters him. He returns to school to finish his finals and finds that he can't.Jacob flees and seeing a train pass
column30: tries to jump aboard. Once on
column31: he realizes it is a circus train. An old man
column32: Camel
column33: vouches for him and works to get him a job within.As soon as the boss finds he is Ivy League educated
column34: degree or no degree
column35: he becomes the animal man. With such a prestigious job within
column36: he straddles the division between the higher ups and performers
column37: and the lower echelon who helped secure his place.One performer in particular
column39: fascinates him. She reminds him physically of the girl he left behind at school
column40: and emotionally captivates him. She matches his love of animals. Married to August
column41: who has the boss' ear
column42: she is off-limits
column43: but a friendship develops anyway.Later comes Rosie
column44: an elephant pilfered from a circus that has gone defunct. Rosie suffers August's wrath many
column45: many times. Jacob is stunned by her human like qualities. Understanding
column46: pain
column47: anger
column49: happiness all emanate from her big brown eyes.Following the story
column50: I felt all of the emotions Rosie feels (except perhaps
column51: the pain). Astonishment at the goings on to keep the circus running smoothly. The love Jacob develops for many people who help him in the course of creating a new life for himself
column52: free of the memories surrounding his past. Sadness at the loss of animals
column53: anger at the treatment of the animals and the red lighting of
column55: carnies.The characters came alive to me
column56: as did the setting. As soon as I finished this book
column57: I eagerly went to Sara Gruen's website to read excerpts of other novels she had written. While good
column58: they didn't capture me the way this did. And I wanted more of this. So I went to Amazon's recommendations Disappointedly
column59: I moved on to Barnes and Noble. No dice. So I tried the next best thing. Research. I wanted to read first hand accounts of the circus the way it was back then. The more I read
column61: as though they knew my hunger
column62: work offered me discounted tickets to the circus. I'm still debating. On the one hand
column63: it's the circus. Elephants that feel things like people do! Horses that synchronize! How can I say no? On the other hand
column64: it's not the 1920s. It's almost 100 years later. What if it's not the same? I mean true
column65: we're in the middle of a depression (point 4 of pros: It's almost the same!). But people are categorically different than they were then. Theoretically
column66: this extends to performers as well right?But alas
column67: I have chosen to forego the circus at this moment
column69: like the recommendations of Barnes and Noble and Amazon
column70: it may fall short. So I will hold onto the satisfaction this book gave me
column71: and the hunger for more of the same. Hopefully
column72: there will be another book that catches my attention like this one. And soon."
column74: "summary": "The best I've read in a long time"

column6: "reviewText": "I got WATER FOR ELEPHANTS as a gift from my husband. When I opened it I said to myself
column7: why on earth did he buy me this? I aked him what prompted him to chose it - he said because I've had a life long fascination with Freak Shows and they're part of the Circus. OK. Fair enough.If it hadn't been for him buying it for me I would have missed out on what has become my favorite piece of fiction I have ever read.I am in love with this book.This book is enchanting. The characters are
column12: nasty and dastardly.Sara Gruen knows her characters so well and writes them with such passion they seem real. You will feel that you know them too. And the writing is so vivid you will feel like you're standing ring-side. Inhale deeply - can you smell the cotton candy?And the ending of this book is the most perfect
column14: ever read.I'm not going to pigeon-hole it with category or genre and risk putting some people off...like me.There are some Book Club talking points at the end of the paperback version and one such talking point is to discuss the book's 'pathetic glamour.' That is a perfect descriptor. The circus fakes its glamour and its glitz; the daily lives of the crews who work it are anything but
column17: even.I've learned a valuable lesson from this book - what I want as a reader is just writing that takes my breath away. I got that from WATER FOR ELEPHANTS."

column11: and suffers from the condescending  attitudes toward the patients there.  This aspect of the book was particularly good

column6: "reviewText": "Book DescriptionAs a young man
column7: Jacob Jankowski was tossed by Fate onto a rickety train that was home to the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth. It was the early part of the great Depression
column10: the circus world he remembers was both his salvation and a living hell. A veterinary student just shy of a degree
column11: he was put in charge of caring for the circus menagerie. It was there that he met Marlena
column12: the beautiful equestrian star married to August
column13: the charismatic but twisted animal trainer. And he met Rosie
column14: an un-trainable elephant who was the great hope for this third-rate traveling show. The bond that grew among this unlikely trio was one of love and trust
column17: it was their only hope for survival.[...]This book came to us as a recommended read from several sources. Once selected
column18: we could not possibly put it down. The author
column20: builds the detailed and fantastic world of a travelling circus during the Great Depression from the ground up! The story of Jacob Jankowski is one of sorrow
column21: love and at times terrifying. His constant emotional struggles can be related to by many readers (though perhaps not as fantastical) and will captivate the imagination. The other characters Gruen constructed are perhaps the most remarkable outside of young Jacob
column23: they all act their parts accordingly ... with flawless precision.One does not need to be a circus aficionado or historical reader to take pleasure in this novel
column24: for it contains a little of everything to captivate any bookworm. We guarantee you will not be able to put this one down!"

column6: "reviewText": "This is not really a particularly intellectual book
column7: or the kind that will have you pondering but it will hold your interest and enthrall you; which makes it a perfect holiday read. It is not only a fantastic love story but is a seemingly accurate depiction of circus life during Great Depression (so you still get to learn things after all)and has enough plot to hold your interest but not so much as to seem over engineered. There is even a lesson about how we should treat old people.A good read"

column6: "reviewText": "I finished all 350 pages in a day and a half. I Couldn't put it down. I've read a lot of great books
column7: but this is by far my favorite of all time and it sooo deserves the five stars I gave it. It's like heartbreak
column12: and a blast from a cruel yet exciting past all in one and I may go read it again once I finish this review. Water for Elephants broke my heart and touched me at the same time."

column6: "reviewText": "Jacob Jankowski is a student at Cornell University
column7: studying veterinary medicine so that he can join his father's practice.Near the end of his senior year and before he sits for his final exams
column8: he is called into the dean's office and told his parents have been killed in an automobile accident. When he returns home to bury them
column9: he learns that his father is bankrupt and all he inherits is debts. After the funeral he returns to Cornell where his room and board have been paid up until the end of the year. He tries to sit for his final exams but ends up leaving without answering a single question. He walks away from the college and finally jumps aboard a railroad car and begins what will be an unusual life
column11: and exciting life with a circus.The story is told by Jacob when he is an old man living in a rest home. It is a depiction of life during the hard years of the Great Depression
column12: the even harder life as a member of a traveling circus
column13: and also provides a peek into the life of early rest homes.I found the book to be a little raw in spots but also exciting and entertaining because I remember the traveling circuses with the big top tents and the intriguing side shows which
column15: I was never allowed to see. Alma Winters-Author of the newly released Once Upon a Time Tales."

column6: "reviewText": "I was eager to read this book after all of the praise it has received. I wasn't necessarily disappointed but not exactly getting all the hype. I enjoyed the visual scenes that Gruen painted and could easily picture it. I just couldn't get past the story.  I didn't feel an immediate chemistry between Jacob and Marlena. I'm sorry if most other people disagree with me
column7: but the 'heat' just wasn't truly there for me. At times I almost felt that Jacob only attracted Marlena due to his difference to August
column8: not due to the actual love between them. While I also enjoyed the perspective of Jacob as an old man remembering his story
column9: it really just left me sad whenever I read scenes from the older Jacob's perspective. He seemed so unhappy and it made me feel as if I were reading two stories
column10: one with a happy ending and one with a sad ending. In all
column11: I gave this story 3 stars because I felt that perhaps if it wasn't being sold as a love story I would have appreciated it more. Instead I am left wondering what was so noteworthy about the characters love beyond the fact that they supposedly found love while working on a circus."

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants has a quality so many modern novels are lacking
column7: and that is an sense of enchantment. So many novels these days take you to a place you would really rather not be
column8: but even the scruffy world of the down-and-out traveling circus is full of mystery and--dare I say it--soul. Love doesn't hurt
column9: either. My 84-year-old mother dislikes modern novels (too much bad language) but she loved this one."

column6: "reviewText": "There are books you read for the story
column7: and books you read for the writing.  Water for Elephants is of the former variety.  It's a quick read and a good read
column8: but it is not a great book.Ms. Gruen was thorough in her research
column9: so the reader does get some feeling for the gritty world of the \"train circus\"
column10: yet I felt when I finished the book that I had no clear sense of who the characters were.  Jacob is a nebulous character as a young man
column11: and a shallow one in old age.  As for the rest of the \"cast\"
column13: when they are good they are very very good
column14: and when they are bad they are...monsters.  Rosie the elephant is one of the more developed characters!The author doesn't seem to have a good ear for speech
column15: either.  Any of the book's dialog could come from any character's mouth
column17: and some of the things Jacob says (or says in his mind) as an old man seem to land with a clunk.  They just don't fit.Add to that a slightly corny ending and a structure that comes out of any pulp murder mystery (old person recalling a murder
column18: then going back to the start of the story and working back up to the murder...with a twist)
column19: and you get just a middling-good book.I am vehemently against the use (abuse) of animals in circuses
column20: so I was happy to see that animal abuse was part of this story.  In fact
column21: I think the author cleaned it up a bit too much (few facts about the orangutan and the chimpanzee
column22: for instance..it's sickening what the higher apes were subject to
column23: and still are).  What I think she could have cut back on is the gratuitous details about sex and the cooch tent.  That all seemed tacked on and unnessesary.Overall
column24: I consider this book worth reading
column25: but I don't see what all the excitement is about.  If you really want a feeling for circus sideshow life

column6: "reviewText": "In addition to writing an engaging story that offers a glimpse into a fascinating world foreign to most of us
column7: Ms. Gruen shows herself to be a master \"architect\" with this novel
column8: crafting a story that flows seamlessly between two radically different eras in her protagonist's life. The book starts with a flashback
column9: so you know at some point it's going to bring us back to the opening scene. But Ms. Gruen does so in such a surprising and unexpected way
column10: with a twist that left my jaw on the floor. It's not an exaggeration to say I was stunned.With Riding Lessons and Flying Changes
column11: Ms. Gruen proved she was capable of writing good commercial fiction.With Water For Elephants
column12: she proves herself capable of writing a great American novel."

column6: "reviewText": "This is one of my all-time favorites.  The story is engrossing.  Rosie the elephant is an amusing and wonderful character. Loved her."
column7: "overall": 5.0

column6: "reviewText": "I got the Audible version of this book because I was curious about its incredible popularity and wanted to see what I was missing. Having finished
column7: I'm mystified about the huge number of five-star reviews.I don't know much about circuses so I can't comment on the quality of the author's research efforts
column8: although I see other reviewers have pointed out shortcomings. What jumps at me
column10: are the one-dimensional characters and overly contrived nature of key plot points.It's never easy for an author to pull off a first-person narrative from the vantage point of the opposite gender
column11: and I wish Sara Gruen hadn't tried to speak through a male character. It seemed fine in the parts where he was speaking as a 90-something
column12: but the young-man version fell flat. Often during the romantic and erotic interludes I found myself thinking Jacob sounded way too feminine.August
column14: was way too over-the-top: animal abuser
column18: etc. Why is he even part of the circus. I think the author should have established some merits
column19: enough to justify employing him. Of course August
column22: so perhaps no merit was needed.I was also appalled at the self-centered irresponsible behavior on the part of Jacob
column24: who seemed quite willing to indulge his own \"love\" needs completely mindless of the horrific consequences likely to result for his friends. I don't want to go into detail which would force too many spoilers. Suffice it to say that I strongly believe that Jacob
column26: absolutely positively does NOT deserve the long and largely happy life he'll eventually get to lead. It's one thing to care about animals and less fortunate humans. That test
column27: Jacob passes with flying colors. But when it comes to moderating one's own urges and balancing them against the well-being of others (all others close to you
column30: Jacob gets a huge F-."
column31: "overall": 1.0
column32: "summary": "Overrated - Shallow characters"

I simply LOVED this book and will recommend it to all my friends.  Well written and wonderful characters.  Great read."

column6: "reviewText": "I've had this book for two years and only just read it last week.  Why did I wait so long???  This truely is a gem.  You feel like you know all the characters
column7: and the ones you don't know so well are introduced with enough hints and inuendos that you can easily imagine their colorful pasts.  I fell in love with the elephant.  She brought a wonderfully odd twist to the story.And as for the author
column8: I was half way through the book before I paid attention to the jacket picture and realised that it was a female. She wrote exactly as a man would tell the story.  The elderly Jacob was perfectly portrayed.  She has obviously been around very old people and knows how they act and react to all kinds of situations.I truely did not want the story to end."

column6: "reviewText": "and take a look at "behind the scene" of a "train" circus from a long ago era.  The book appears to be impeccably researched and the author has drawn on some stories that contribute to the books entertainment value and poignancy.Earlier reviewers have already provided a look into the plot so no need to reiterate.  I devoured the book in about three days and place it in the top 10 books read within the last year.  I found the characters

column6: "reviewText": "I found \"Water for Elephants\" extremely entertaining
column7: despite never seeing a circus or having any interest in the subject.  The backdrop is the 1930's
column8: and the book throws you into the era of carnivals
column10: and the Great Depression.  You're led by slums with hobos
column11: and everyone is dying for regular pay and something to eat.The story bounces back and forth between a man living out his twilight years in a nursing home
column12: and his 23-year-old self... where circumstances find him joining a circus.  Life revolves around the train for these guys - they always travel in cramped space with all kinds of memorable characters.There are some great anecdotes so strange you'd think they were true.  My favorite was Rosie the bull elephant sneaking lemonade by pulling her stake out of the ground
column13: and then being smart enough to replace it to avoid getting caught.The author respects the reader enough to let him figure out what's happening from contextual clues.  For instance
column14: a show horse is put down
column15: and the starving lions miraculously wind up fed.  You have to connect the dots to understand the whole story.Another positive: this book is not a tear-jerker and avoids supernatural components
column16: unlike other popular fiction (e.g. Dean Koontz).  Note that there are some graphic sexual encounters and profanity that make this mature with a capital \"M\" - don't give it to anyone younger than a high school kid."

column6: "reviewText": "This book has been on my to-read list for quite some time and I finally got around to reading it. I would have to agree with the majority of the reivews in that it certainly was an excellent and entertaining story. I am especially looking forward to seeing the movie now that recently came out.I liked how the story flipped from present-day Jacob who was 93 years old in a nursing home to the story of young Jacob on the circus train. The first part of the story of the events leading to how Jacob comes to join the circus in the first place really get the story going and draw the reader's interest. There is a fair amount of sexual content within the story that surprised me a little but was in keeping with the progression of the story. I didn't particularly enjoy the portrayals of animal abuse that happened on the circus train
column7: but these also helped in building the storyline of August and Rosie (the elephant).I was pleased by how the story wrapped up and am definitely interested in checking out some of the other books by this author."

column6: "reviewText": "This story helped me in gaining a better understanding of what it is to be elderly.  The audio version is narrated by two men
column7: both are meant to be the main character
column8: one voice representing his twenties and the other is in his nineties.  It certainly isn't centered around being of an advanced age
column10: it was still very clear.I was pleasantly surprised by my conflicted response to the story.  On the one hand
column11: his lamentations over being at the end of his life made me sad; on the other hand
column12: he was funny and his life was a full one
column13: giving him many wonderful memories.My advice to a prospective listener or reader?  If you are bored with the first chapter
column15: it picks up and is worth getting to the end."

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is a love story set in a post depression traveling circus and told from the memory of 93 year-old man.  The story jumps between the current life of the narrator a uncontented man who believes he is 90 or 93 and his rememberance of the love story between Jacob and the Benzini Brother's circus.After the death of both his parents Jacob a veterinairian student finds himself penniless. Although not intentionally  he runs away to the circus where he finds love.This story give great historical flavor and is a must read."
column7: "overall": 5.0
column8: "summary": "Run Away to the Circus of Post Depression America"

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is a tough one for me to review. I loved the theme and the split realities of it. You are basically following Jacob Jankowski
column7: the protagonist
column8: through two of his life's biggest adventures. We are introduced to him at the circus and follow his story of how he becomes a vet for the Benzini Brother's traveling circus. We are also switching back into his current reality where he is re-living these days from the nursing home that he now resides in.There are good plot points throughout
column9: and I did find myself wanting to get back to the book to see what happens next. At times
column11: I found certain events did not play out in a way that was realistic to the story that was being built. Even though I was enjoying the story and the narrative - I found myself aware of the fact that there was an author behind it all
column12: pulling the strings. Not being able to quite put my finger on why
column13: I was often pulled out of believing the story
column14: almost as if the author was showing too many fingerprints of the process of writing. For this reason - it was hard for me to get lost completely in the book itself.All of that aside
column16: I still found it beautiful. There was a moment in particular when I felt incredibly sad for our main character - to the point where I had to put the book down and step away for a moment to collect myself. There is a wonderfully commentary woven throughout that allows the reader to ponder where one is at when you are looking back at your life in old age. I really enjoyed that thread.I had heard a lot of really good things about the book
column17: and was going into it that way. Unfortunately
column18: there was something missing for me when I completed it
column19: almost as if I had skipped an important part. For that reason
column23: yet slightly hard to get lost in"

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is a wonderful read.  The story grabs your interest quick and keeps you moving along at a great pace.  I enjoyed the way the author transitioned between the older Jacob and the younger Jacob so seamlessly.  Wonderful writing style."
column7: "overall": 4.0

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is first narrated by Jacob
column7: a 90-93 year old living out his days in a nursing home. He begins to tell the story of his life including a 70 (or so) year old secret he's revealing to anyone for the first time. Jacob is a young man just short of taking his tests to become a Veterinarian until both his parents die
column8: and his life seems to hold no direction. He accidently finds himself in the midst of circus train where he meets an unpredictable circus manager
column12: and later a difficult to train elephant
column13: Rosie.The element that lights up this audio book is John Randolph Jones amazing narration as the tired and cantankerous older Jacob. His voice is heavy with age and experience. It would be difficult for any secondary narrator to compete but David LeDoux does a good job of holding his own. Though the setting is lively and obviously well researched
column14: the love triangle is underdeveloped and the end of the book just sort of unravels. At turns mindless
column17: Water for Elephants effectively captures a bygone time and offers some fascinating circus details most will enjoy."

column15: but it is the absolute truth.This novel made me smile

column6: "reviewText": "This book was just so-so for me.  There was a total disconnect for me with any of the characters specifically between Jacob and Marlena.  I thought their love story lacked passion of any kind.  For me
column7: it felt like the only thing keeping them together was the horses and later Rosie.  It wasn't until half way through the book when Jacob finally admits he's in love with her and it's so lackluster I didn't really believe it.  Perhaps I feel this way because I had just finished reading \"Wurthering Heights\" before this and expecting more passion between the young lovers; however I'm not interested in reading this book again to find out if that's true.......which is saying a lot.  I thought the most interesting part of the book was the Q&A portion at the end where Gruen talks about her research and how all the events that took place on and off the train were based on real events that happened to various circus's during that time.  Knowing that did kind of put those events into prospective
column8: but not really being interested in circus history is where it failed to capture me.  In the end: Big on Circus history
column9: lacking on the love story.  Not one I would recommend unless you like reading and/or learning about the traveling circus."

column6: "reviewText": "I bought this book orginally when it first came out. It has been sitting on my shelf untill this weekend. I started this book early morning and had it done by the end of the day. I couldn't put it down!I the author does a great job with switching back and forth between times. Alot of authors try and do this but can't acomplish it but this one did a great job.The book held me in suspense the entire time. There never was a down moment in the whole book. Something was alway going on to keep the readers attention. I loved that he did research to write this book. The pictures also helped with what you were imagining as you read it.The author does a good job with making us have a love hate relationship with many of the characters. One minute I wouldn't think someone was that bad and then the next thing they did I couldn't stand them or vice versa.The interaction with the animals brought in a whole different set of characters. Rosie seemed almost human to me.I hated and loved to finish this book. I haven't found something this good in a while."

column6: "reviewText": "I had heard a lot of positive comments on this book for a while and thought I would see for myself what all the praise was about.  Well this book deserves 5 stars and more.  It is really a book that will stay with you for a while.  I know it will be among my all time favorites
column7: as well it should.  The writer has done an excellent job fleshing out the people and you almost feel as if you know them personally or have dealt with people like time in real life.  The depression was deep in the US when the story is introduced.  Life can hand out a lot of hard knocks

column6: "reviewText": "I have a tendency of sticking with supernatural stories because I love the magic of them. While \"Water for Elephants\" is far from supernatural
column7: this story was easily the definition of magical.The story actually starts out in the nursing home
column8: which is so intricately described that I could hear the whirring of the mechanical machines; helping the patients stay alive
column9: and I could smell the putrid scent of finality in the air. Instantly I was pulled in by the lyrical writing style. The author also does a nice job of analyzing life's major questions
column10: and hopping on her train of thought was enjoyable.The unwinding of Jacob's memories is done so beautifully. Gruen achieved what few authors can and brought her characters to life. I almost felt like I was hearing this beautiful
column12: brave and wonderful story first hand
column13: staring at Jacob's frail body beneath the fluorescent lights of the nursing home.This book took me on a journey
column14: and at the end I wasn't quite ready to hop off the train. There was a twist I never saw coming
column15: and my only regret is it took me so long to pick this one up and read it. I recommend it for people who love a story of adventure
column17: and love that overcomes all obstacles."

column6: "reviewText": "I loved the rich
column7: descriptive language. The author does a great job of the writer's maxim \"show
column9: \" revealing bits and pieces to fill in the details and background of characters over time. The main character
column12: especially when he's a 93-year old with attitude. I felt so sorry for old Jacob after a while. I really wanted to get back to young Jacob and hoped for a happy ending. Without giving anything away
column13: I was incensed at one point about what happened to old Jacob. I hated that part so much that I questioned all the favorable reviews. However
column14: I must say that I'm satisfied with the ending and glad that I read the book. One bonus of the fact that it's a best seller: I was able to easily check this out from my local library after a few week's wait. No problem
column15: I wasn't in a hurry.Regarding adult themes (beware potential SPOILERS below):I'm definitely NOT a fan of inserting graphic sex or nudity or swearing into a story for no reason. I prefer nice clean stories and think you really don't need to be explicit. However
column16: I think the scenes in this story helped set the environment. They were typically treated with such humor that I laughed a lot and didn't mind them. First
column17: young virgin Jacob guards a stripper while she performs. The striptease and gigantic breasts are described in vivid detail. Jacob's horror
column20: having never seen a naked woman before shows he's really not in Kansas any more. That's the most explicit scene and it's really hilarious. There are a few other sexual situations
column21: often mixed with drinking. The actual love making was left to the imagination. There's a little swearing. I found the beating of animals to be the most objectionable; Jacob
column23: spends a lot of time trying to figure out how to help."

column6: "reviewText": "I really enjoyed this book. Sarah Gruen did a great job of telling the story ofcircus with all the beauty
column7: cruelty and the harsh life during the depression.The author states that she did research the circus during that time period and it shows in her writing.  She really describes the  people and animals that were the main part of a circus and they  come to life in my mind. I could see and hear them as I read the book.It starts off with the main character
column8: Jacob Jankowski as a very angry oldman in a nursing home. He decides to go to the circus and reminisces about his past. We are then introduced to the young Jacob Jankowski. The book goes back and forth in time as many do today.The author really nails it when she writes about the depression. I have read and studied the depression and she portrayes it so vividly. I felt so sorry for the workers
column9: performers and the animals. They all suffered in one way or another.The characters had their flaws.The book paints the Ringleader as a charming but violent man. One who had a short fuse and was a loose cannon.I was fascinated by Jacob Jankowski. In spite of the hardships that he had to endure
column10: his kindness and gentleness never wavered.I admired Marlena as a beautiful
column11: graceful and long-suffering woman. She was  not brave enough to leave. I recommend this book to all. The movie followed the book very closely except the Ringleader was not as mean as in the book."

column6: "reviewText": "Wow!  I picked this up to read on the airplane to & from Las Vegas.  I wound up finishing it while on my trip.Gruen is a wonderful story teller

column8: that is the main setting for most of the book.  I really thought it would be a book all about Carnie Folk.  How far from the truth was I?!The story is told from the view of an ageing circus vet
column9: which is different to begin with.  One would think that these types of stories would be told from performer's points of view & while that would be interesting
column10: Jacob's POV is just as intriguing as another other's would have been.It's a great short read that's captivating & spellbinding."

column6: "reviewText": "First I must mention that I love books that take you to a time and place that you have no knowledge about and in this case it's circus life in the first half of the 1900's. It was fascinating to read what life was like in those days for those who worked in the circus
column7: from performers to the labors. As for the book itself I did enjoy it
column8: but I wouldn't call it a page turner and often in the first quarter of the book I thought about just putting the book down and starting something else a little more exciting to read. However the farther into the book I got the more I started to care about the characters the more invested in the book I became. In the end I was very glad I continued to read the book and now I can say I would recommend the book to friends."

column6: "reviewText": "I can't say I have ever read a book that was even remotely similar in plot or storyline. Water for Elephants is one of the most original novels that has ever graced my eyes. I felt all the emotions Jacob did as I read
column7: and the story seemed to transition seamlessly between the present
column8: and his memories without being confusing as some other books can be when they try the memory flashback thing. It's one of the few books that I read that I simply could not put down
column9: stopping only to eat and sleep."

column6: "reviewText": "This is a very beautiful
column7: well-written story that at times had you really feeling - both good and bad feelings - for many of the characters. Jacob lived a hard life after his parents died but I appreciated his tenacity. He was determined to make it in the circus and to make it in life. I throughly enjoyed the ending and I think if I was Jacob that that's how I'd want to spend the rest of my days too. I highly recommend this book for anyone who wants to read a story about real life

column6: "reviewText": "...so all I can do is add my voice to chorus.Gruen writes an incredible dual-novel.  The tale of one man

column6: "reviewText": "I don't read fiction.  A snob journalist

column6: "reviewText": "I had high hopes for this book.  Lots of great reviews

column10: the \"old man reflecting from a retirement home\" is a tired technique and all those chapters bored me to tears. My main problem with the novel
column12: is that the characters are one dimensional.  They always seem to be doing dramatic things and facing tragedy after tragedy
column13: but I couldn't connect because there is very little reflection or internal monologue (not even in the retirement home!).  The story clips along at such a quick pace it gets bogged down by its own far-fetched events.  I found it difficult to understand why the characters
column15: act the way they do--everything seems trumped up to make the plot work. I can't say I even completely understand the title.  I got the connection to the man in the retirement home who claimed he carried water for elephants
column16: but what in the heck did this have to do with the story?  Maybe I'm just not deep enough to understand!  Quite frankly
column17: I didn't enjoy the book much at all and my advice would be to skip it.  Perhaps the movie is better."

column7: August

column14: then you must read this book!"

column6: "reviewText": "1) I hate the circus because I don't believe in subjecting animals to this kind of treatment.2) I loved this book so much it is now one of my favorites because:3) After reading this book

column9: who is a horse breeder/activist from what I gather
column10: for writing about the circus. I thought it was going to be some horrible account of the circus life and have no substance. Boy was I wrong. The protagonist Jacob leaves his exams to become a vet after learning of the death of his parents and literally jumps aboard a train not knowing what kind of train it is or the kind of people on it. I guess you have to just take the biggest risks in life sometimes and do what does not make sense to reap the biggest rewards.I am anxiously awaiting the movie to come out in April! I hope they don't butcher it."

column6: "reviewText": "I agree with many of this book's reviews.  They're right; the author does make you empathize with her characters.  When reading
column7: I felt like I was right with the characters

column9: and reading about this circus-society is entertaining and informative.Now
column11: the book's writing was nothing extraordinary.  While Sara Gruen tells a unique story
column12: she is not a unique storyteller.  Her writing was too common for me
column13: too similar to the writing styles of so many authors who are currently alive.As I was reading
column15: \"Have I read anything by this author before?\"  The truth was
column16: I had never read anything else by her.  But I felt like I had
column17: because her writing style and word choices were nothing new to me.I imagine that
column19: I won't be able to remember reading this book.  Perhaps I'll hear someone talk about it
column20: and I'll get a feeling of deja-vu and say
column21: \"Oh yeah.  I think I might have read something like that

column24: and I cared about the characters.  It was a good read
column25: and well worth my time.  I happily recommend it to people who want to be entertained
column26: and who might like to read about the circus.  Just don't expect anything amazing.Oh
column27: and if you don't like violence or scenes with sexual content
