column6: "reviewText": "I am not real sure what I expected going into this book
column7: more of a romance \"chick\" book I guess. I don't really like romance books all that much so it was awhile before I actually read this book but wishing now I had read it sooner! It was NOTHING like I thought it was going to be at all!This book is about a 93 year old man in a assistant living home that is recalling the time he spent in the circus as a young man after his parents got killed in a car accident. I was really expecting it to be more happy upbeat book about the circus but there was very little \"happy\" in this book! Some parts were so hard to read and I had to keep myself reading
column8: not because the writing was bad or the book was bad but because some parts were just heart wrenching that it was hard to read without crying or at least on the verge of it
column9: or wanting to go and kill August!The writing was amazing the author has amazing talents and I never expected the ending! I was actually fairly pissed off when Jacob didn't get to go to the circus and was thinking that I was going to be pretty upset with the ending but it caught me off guard and I ended the book smiling and crying at the same time.Amazing book read it!"

column6: "reviewText": "I have read a bunch of novels recently that kept me engrossed for the first 70-80% and then faded badly. Water for Elephants is worth reading right to the satisfying ending. It is very well paced and has interesting twists and all the characters seemed real to me.I had never considered the 1930's touring circus as a basis for writing a novel. Now I want to learn more about it. That's because Gruen does such a nice job describing it. The characters (and the animals!) are very human and I think she captures the time they lived in quite well. I am impressed that there are over 1000 reviews and still more coming for a book that's been out now for over 4 years. It speaks to some of the universal qualities that appealed to me and perhaps other readers. The lead character is interesting
column7: he's human and he has reflected on a life well lead while  yearning for more. I see a little bit of my father in there!One thing I am always looking for is how well a writer can give voice to a character that is so different from him or herself. Ms Gruen as a modern woman writing in the first person a man in the 1930's does very well in making Jacob a believable character. The writing is tight
column8: swift and it was a pleasure to read."
column10: "summary": "Delivers Right to the End. A pleasure to read."

column6: "reviewText": "I just finished reading Water for Elephants and I really enjoyed it. It's a love story and so much more. The author conjured up images so sharp and clear that I often thought of the classic movie The Greatest Show on Earth (directed by Cecil B. DeMille). The characters were well-fleshed and it was obvious from the beginning who was the 'hero' and who was the 'villain'
column7: both vying for the beautiful heroine. And then there was a secondary story set in present day that was artfully woven among the vintage circus story. I really enjoyed this book. The author did a fabulous job of drawing in the reader
column8: and I found myself longing for bedtime (my reading time <g>). I know this book has been optioned for a movie and I do hope the director does the book justice."

column6: "reviewText": "For several years

column10: and cruelty and tenderness.  It starts weakly

column12: and winds up working for a circus.  But don't despair
column13: I promise it's worth finishing.Gruen's characters are vividly drawn.  Hierarchies amongst performers
column14: workers and management prevail.  Descriptions are so vivid
column15: you can almost smell the hay
column16: and everything else so accurately described.This is a wonderful window into life in a circus
column17: with all it's horrors and despite them

column6: "reviewText": "First

column6: "reviewText": "I love the novel

column10: traveling circus. He cares for the circus animals

Captivating from beginning to end.  I would recommend this book for anyone who wants to go on a circus adventure."
column7: "overall": 5.0

column6: "reviewText": "I'm trying to hold back and be nice
column7: remembering I just finished rereading The Great Gatsby (and there's not much that can compare to that)!  Overall
column8: I liked the book.  I found the depiction of circus and railroad life during the depression very interesting.  It appeared that the author did some in depth research.  The flashback technique between the circus and the nursing home
column10: left me flat.  I did not feel that the nursing home chapters were of the same quality as the circus chapters and frankly rushed through them to get back to the \"real\" story.  If anyone starts the book
column12: keep going as the ending is well done.My disappointment in this book came from the author's handling of important thematic materials.  The scene was set for so many important (and universal) statements and the author simply threw them away.  So much could have been written about class structure
column18: etc. and nothing came forth.  There was no symbolism or connections to classic themes
column19: and I sure missed the place where the main character was equated with the biblical Jacob.  Those efforts would have made the difference between a book that will last and one that won't be remembered in ten years."

column6: "reviewText": "I LOVED this book!  It takes me awhile to read a book due to lack of time but
column7: I couldn't wait to pick this up at every opportunity possible.  Great story
column8: wonderful detail - and the type of book where you felt like you were on the sidelines watching."

column6: "reviewText": "OK - I admit it.  I really liked this book.  My wife was shocked that I wanted to read it
column7: but she had loved it so much I thought I would give it a try.  It is such an interesting story.  You can tell it was well researched as it truly brings to life the way circus people lived nearly 100 years ago.The characters are memorable.  You really feel that you know Jacob and all the performers in the Benzini Brothers Circus.  The story revolves around a love triangle all set within the context of the depression and circus life.  This does not come across at all like a romance novel.  The story is well-crafted and keeps the reader's interest.  All key items I look for in a book.  There were a few fights intermingled to keep my sense of action / adventure happy too.Pros:o well researched depression era circus lifeo wonderful characters who you grow to know and loveo full telling of story - you don't feel like anything was left outCons:o none big enough to comment onOverall - I highly recommend this book.  A great American novel."

column6: "reviewText": "It was a time when I judged a book by it's cover
column7: which I am told to never do.  I am so glad that I read this book.  It has stuck with me since I finished it and it is a book that I will read again and again."

column6: "reviewText": "This novel is a beautiful love story surrounded by a fascinating spectacle. It goes without saying that if you are a circus lover you will really enjoy reading this book. Sara Gruen provokes tears
column7: smiles
column8: and sighs along with other emotional reactions from the reader by encompassing circus life without failing to include any heart wrenching details. I highly recommend this book to anyone looking to go on a circus adventure and test the resilience of love."

column6: "reviewText": "Wow
column7: 1696 reviews to date!  Oprah's recommendation really can motivate a lot of women with time on their hands LOL!  I won't even bother to read the 5-star reviews because I'll probably agree with all the specifics about what a good book this is.  It has colorful
column8: well-fleshed out characters with only a few cardboard stereotypes
column9: great sense of historical and circus detail
column10: and a neat surprise ending.The trouble is
column11: this does not belong up there with some great recent
column14: like Memoirs of a Geisha or The Kite Runner.  One thing they all have in common is introducing us to a foreign or unfamiliar world
column15: in this case the depression-era circus.  But those other two books have a depth of soul
column17: than Water for Elephants.I was also disappointed with a big
column19: where Camel was to be reunited with his son and the reader was set for that pivotal event
column20: only to be let down and short-circuited by the surprise ending.You will definitely enjoy this book
column21: and be enlightened to learn more about life during the Depression
column23: let's not give standing ovations for every good show."

column6: "reviewText": "One of the Stern Librarian's great challenges is to get patrons who say they don't like novels to read them.  Water for Elephants is the novel I will now be pressing on those people who say they only like reading history or biography rather than fiction.  Although readers will get lost in the invented world in this book
column7: they will also learn a great deal of real facts about the Depression
column8: train circuses and animal behavior along the way.  And they will feel the plight of Americans in the grip of economic panic in ways that most history books cannot convey.  Photographs at the beginning of most chapters both illustrate the plot and confirm that most of this unbelievable story really did happen.  I particularly loved learning about the mechanics of circuses
column11: how the crowd was shaken for every last nickel
column12: how they performers and animals were fed and housed.  The paperback edition contains an interview with the author and other notes that describe the research that went into the book and reveal that a few of the more amazing events in the novel actually occurred.  As if the glamour of old circuses weren't enough
column13: this book also contains a second story set in present day about an elderly man in a nursing home.  Many readers have told me that they take to this old man's voice like elephants to lemonade.  The Stern Librarian (I work for peanuts too)."

column6: "reviewText": "I was born in 1920.  I grew up during the Great Depression and the Prohibition eras.In 1965 we owned a bait and tackle shop in Venice
column7: Florida.  At that time the Ringling Bros. Circus wintered there and we became acquainted with many circus people.  Our shop was a hangout for them and every evening after rehearsals they would stop by for a beer.The book: \"Water for Elephants\" is extremely well written and I am planning to read more of Sara Gruen's work.I have ordered two more copies and given them to friends.  They have given me very good reports."

column6: "reviewText": "I have strongly mixed feelings about _Water for Elephants_.  The alternating story between the daily life of a 90-ish year old man and his cantankerous behaviour with his youth as a circus vet kept my attention; the details about the social heirarchy between members of the circus was (on the authority of a former circus roustabout friend of mine) accurate; and I have to admit
column7: I am a sucker for a love story.  However
column10: and the mannerisms of men of that era were abhorrent - but then I am a stickler for these kinds of detail.The story - of a Cornell vet student who quits his final exams before graduation to join the circus and his subsequent adventures (and love story) has undoubtedly caught the imagination of the vast majority of Amazon reviewers - including myself.  Yet I deduct a star because of the lack of attention to detail regarding the male protagonists and the verbage of the time.  For most readers
column12: in which case I would stronlgy recommend it.As far as breezy summer reads go
column13: this certainly fits the bill - who *hasn't* fantasized about running off with the circus?  (Happily oblivious to the hard work
column14: long hours and mediocre pay ...)  Which among us doesn't dream (or hasn't dreamed) of finding  your soul-mate on such an adventure?  Recommended
column15: particularly for the romantics among us."
column18: too - I carried water for elephants\""

column7: "overall": 5.0

column6: "reviewText": "Almost every child has dreamed about running away to join the circus.  In the days of the big top
column7: there were lots of menial jobs that kept those who wanted to be part of the circus busy from before dawn into late into the night
column8: even if those jobs often involved nothing more glamorous than shoveling up the remains of an elephant's snack.Water for Elephants starts with an elderly (at least 90 years old) Jacob Jankowski remembering snatches of his past as he frets over the indignities of living in a nursing home while his children ignore him except for token rotating visits on Sundays.  One memory in particular stands out
column9: a violent memory that he didn't share with anyone for over 70 years.Most of the book moves through flashback into the 1930s when America was broke and people were starving.  Into this challenging world
column10: Jacob has high expectations as he finishes up his veterinary training at Cornell.  But the hand of God intervenes
column11: and his life will never be the same.He soon finds himself serving in any role that he can get at BENZINI BROS MOST SPECTACULAR SHOW ON EARTH (as the rail cars read).  This isn't the big time.  It's just surviving by staying one step ahead of the local sheriffs while not delivering on promised acts and providing entertainment for men that has nothing to do with being a circus.  This circus doesn't even have an elephant.Much of the story involves the nitty gritty of how circuses operated in those perilous times.  It's a story that encompasses lots of cruelty
column14: it's enough to make you wonder why you ever dreamed about running away to join the circus.  So if you would like to keep that dream shiny
column15: perhaps this wouldn't be the best book for you to read.At the center of the story are three people and one elephant.  Marlena is the queen of the circus
column16: the star of the equestrian act that involves first 12 and later 10 horses.  She's married to the volatile August who runs the animal acts.  When Jacob becomes involved in caring for the animals
column17: Jacob is invited to dine and party with the couple.  The relationship becomes more complicated when Jacob finds himself drawn to Marlena and repelled by August.  When the circus buys an abandoned elephant that seems unusually stupid
column19: the book is about responsibility and loyalty . . . qualities that are more important in and taken more seriously by the circus world than by the \"rubes\" who attend the circus.  The message will serve as yet another indictment of our modern world which favors efficiency over doing the right thing.The book is beautifully illustrated with vintage photographs of early circuses that nicely match the story line of Water for Elephants.Unlike many authors of such historical fiction
column20: Sara Gruen does a good job of keeping a few surprises up her sleeve.  So don't quit mid-book thinking you know how the story will turn out.Grab a shovel . . . and dig in!"
column22: "summary": "A Surprising Look at Circus Life in the 1930s"

column6: "reviewText": "I've had this book on my shelf for a while...the circus has never really interested me--but it's been on the bestsellers list for so long...it just must be great
column7: right? Well it's okay--but I'm convinced it's the ending that's leaves readers recommending it to friends. It has a typical Hollywood happy ending.The story prior to the ending is nice enough. It's pretty short and has a few interesting photos taken from the Ringling archives. I thought the details of the Great Depression were woven niceley into the story and it seemed well researched.That being said I don't think the story was as deep or detailed as it could have been. Gruen obviously had some rich material at her fingertips. I can't help but think she could have done more with it.I also found the constant interjection of Old Man Jacob Jankoski distracting and annoying. Although
column8: the parts are well-written and moving--definitely makes me twice about the elderly--He seems completely unnecesarry to the plot of the novel and I thought his space in the book should have been filled with something else-preferably
column9: the developing romance between Marlena and Jacob.Pluses: Cover
column13: The ending. Photos.Cons: Characters are dull or overwrought
column15: Old Man Jankowski distracts from circus plot."
column17: "summary": "An okay book with a great cover."

column6: "reviewText": "As a prize-winning author myself
column7: and a Pulitzer nominee
column8: I know good writing.  This book was so riveting and fascinating I couldn't put it down.In fact
column9: it became so real to me that I began to think of it as non-fiction some time after I'd finished.  I had to read these reviews to recollect it is fiction.  Having read a great many of the posted reviews
column10: I can't help noticing the negative or low rated reviews are sneering and superior
column11: and critical in the extreme.  This is
column13: typical of poor writers who feel compelled to comment scathingly on others' skills
column14: but who are incapable of writing compelling literature themselves.  As a professional academic reviewer
column15: I strongly disagree with the snide commentary.  It is a rare gem."

column6: "reviewText": "I was hesitant to read this book at first because I was concerned about the animal abuse. However
column7: Sara Gruen did a wonderful job with keeping it at a minimum. I quickly scanned over one or two of the scenes and then realized when I was done reading the story
column8: how the little bit of it added to the story.Well researched and well defined
column9: Gruen takes you by the hand and leads you into the life of an elderly man who
column11: reflects back on his life in his younger years while he was a part of the circus life. Vivid and captivating
column12: I felt as though I was a part of this exciting journey.There are thousands of reviews on this book
column13: so I'll keep mine brief. Clearly stated
column14: this is one work that will remain in my memory all the days of my life. Fascinating!!"

column6: "reviewText": "This review originally appeared on my blog.If you are considering trying audio books
column7: I think this would be an excellent one to start with. I loved the narrators
column8: they really added something extra to the story. Also this story is meant to be told orally and listening to it really makes it all come to life.I was a bit worried when I decided to listen to this book. I don't usually like books that involve animals
column9: mostly because of the guaranteed heart fail. Not only does this book have animals
column10: it is set in a circus. Having worked as a zookeeper
column11: I learned some of the not so nice things that happen to circus animals. Then add to it
column12: the story is set during the Depression. All of these had me cringing a bit. But who hasn't dreamed of running off to the circus?I was hooked in the first few minutes of the reading. I could tell that it would be a story I would lose myself in. I have to say though I was a little annoyed with the music playing in the background. Particularly with the older narrator as it made it difficult for me to hear him clearly.Oddly enough
column13: it was the scenes of the older Jacob that had tears coming to my eyes
column14: rather than the animals. It sucks to be old and his story is probably far more common than not. Though I did cringe every time August had a scene with Rosie. I was also a little shocked at the debauchery that took place at a circus (today it is such a family event).The descriptive nature of the story had me feeling like I was there at the circus. I could smell the popcorn. hear the cheer of the crowd
column15: and when I closed my eyes I was in the menagerie with all the sights and sounds that come with a tent full of animals. More so than any other audio book I've listened to
column16: there was a mini movies running through my mind.I went to see the movie a couple of days after finishing the book. I don't usually like to see the movie version so soon after finishing a book because the details of the book are so fresh in my mind. But I have to say
column17: the movie was so well done that I fell even more in love with the story. The movie left out the parts that I found annoying in the book (in particular the back and forth between the old Jacob and young Jacob). I do have to say that I was a tiny bit upset that BoBo was cut from the film. I think he might have been my favorite animal."

column6: "reviewText": "This book left me with a insight into the circus world and wanting to read more and more. I loved the way she incorporated the thoughts of the older character into the story
column7: it really makes a person realize how aging feels. I really liked the characters and felt like I knew them personally!"

column6: "reviewText": "This book begins and ends with the main character
column7: Jacob Jankowski
column8: in his 90's and residing in a nursing home.  He doesn't remember how old he is or even the people that take turns coming to visit him.  But what he does remember more than makes up for his current state of boredom.  The beginning reminded me of Stephen King's \"The Green Mile\".  The author obviously had to do a great deal of research into circus life during the depression in order to write this book.  What she found does not make a pleasant story.  Being an animal lover
column9: the cruelty displayed toward the animals
column11: really disturbed me.  I still have a hard time believing that Jacob
column12: who had nearly received his degree as a veterinarian and loved Rosie
column13: would not have done more to prevent it. The cruelty displayed towards the employees was just as bad.  Railroad goons would actually push workers off moving trains in the middle of the night rather than pay them.  I thought the affair between Jacob and Marlena was not as torrid as it should have been.  Rosie was my favorite character - she was described in human terms which made the cruelty more difficult to endure.  In the end
column14: both the peon workers and Rosie got even.  But that was not even the ending that made this book such a great read.  I was so excited when I read the ending
column15: I had to tell someone about it!  It was the best ending ever!!"

column6: "reviewText": "This book was highly recommended to me by women in an assisted living facility where I teach

column6: "reviewText": "When my two sons were perhaps 6 and 10
column7: I took them to the circus here in Salt Lake City
column8: Utah.  They were remarkably nonplussed:  \"Duh Dad
column9: a bear riding a bicycle?\"  And so
column10: going back in time 75 years to get the look and feel of circuses was a lot of fun.  Dusty
column19: all of it.  But the heart of the book is the story of Jacob
column20: a young veterinarian (who hasn't yet passed the exam)
column21: who is pulled out of his orderly life and into the circus world virtually overnight.  And suddenly
column24: a young and handsome 23 year old being used and abused by the men and women in this crazy circus sub-world.The story is told by Jacob at age 93 and now living in a rest-home.  Going between old Jacob with nurses clucking about trying to get him to behave
column25: and then going back in time telling the circus story
column26: reminds me of the old lady's perspective in the movie
column28: \"  who is telling the story of young Jack and her life altering romance with him.  There's something about the technique that makes it all seem very real
column29: like it's all in the present.Jacob's romance with one of the young
column30: beautiful circus performers is a touching and believable tale.  The hucksterisms of his two bosses who run the circus
column31: are also very realistic and an important part of the story.  I won't give too much away here
column32: in case you haven't yet read the book
column33: but an elephant named Rosie is also one of the main characters of the book who makes sure things turn out as they're supposed to.A very fun

column7: "reviewText": "This book does provide a fairly riveting story set within post depression America and also provides good insights into the circus business during this era. The book balances the dynamics of maintaining a circus in tough economic times against a host of vivid and disparate personalities that can both support and challenge the stability of the circus. For example there is Big Al who runs the circus with a nearly ruthless practicality
column8: \"redlighting\" individuals who violate his rules. There is August
column11: supportive and cruel. There is Jacob
column13: who stumbles into the world after fleeing Cornell Vet School and who subsequently falls in love with August's wife. The book alternates between the young Jacob in the circus and the elderly Jacob in a nursing home. Some of the dialogue the characters use during the depression era sounds like it came from the 21st century but other than that there is a gritty
column14: often grotesque and unblinking realism in everything from death to romance."

column6: "reviewText": "No need for a long review here...This one is definately worth reading.  A great story
column7: written well.  Highly recommend!"

column6: "reviewText": "Note on Kindle version: A number of minor glitches: Typos in some of the latter chapters and the author's note appeared twice; The first was joined to the last sentence
column7: unseparated by any spacing (this one's pretty annoying
column10: the images in between chapters appeared fine and crisp
column11: dictionary functions well.Water for Elephants is one of those big
column12: entertaining read that is packed with action and wonderful details
column15: a love story. From the first few pages there you get a clear sense that the story is just tailor made for the movies. The structure of the narration
column16: the intricate period details as well as the classic twists and turn of the plot makes you feel like you are
column18: reading a movie. I could even hear faint soundtrack music in the background as I flipped through the pages!Jacob Jankowski
column20: found himself on the road after his life is turned upside down by a freak accident. He made a fateful jump on a passing train
column21: which turned out to a travelling circus. Soon after
column22: he finds himself employed as the circus vet and falls head over heels for the star of the troupe
column24: who just happened to be the wife of the schizophrenic head of the menagerie. Then one day
column25: an elephant joins the troupe and everything started to unravel.The love story itself is filled with cliches. Young man falls in love with a woman out of his reach
column26: thinks his love in unrequited but can't help to yearn for her and therefore continues to woe her. And just when he thought his chances are gone
column27: she confesses that the feeling's mutual. Aha
column30: they go through heaven and hell to escape him and that's basically it. The love story.And so it's not a surprise that the characters are not of great depth. Jacob is the naive
column31: testosterone-bursting young fella who knows what or who he wants but doesn't have a clue how to get it. And is showered with luck and good friends to support him. Marlena
column32: is the charming damsel in distress and her husband the wicked yet brilliant villain.But all those flaws
column33: as great as they seem
column34: are overridden by Gruen's superbly paced and gripping storytelling of a magical world of a bygone era. The world of the travelling circus in the 1930s she described just sucks you in. The lack of depth of the human character is replaced by the depth of character of their animal counterparts. Rex and Leo
column35: the lions
column36: Bobo the chimp and Rosie the Elephant. The story just came alive with all those great period details.Also
column37: despite of the predictable outcome of the love story
column38: it is the structure of the narration that keeps you glued until the last page. Gruen zooms back and forth between Jacob's old self
column39: a miserable 93 yo in a nursing home
column40: wifeless and seen as a mere duty to his family and his young self. The way old Jacob yearns for life is all too familiar and is echoed in the young Jacob's lust for life. Ultimately
column41: you want to know what happens to both Jacobs: Will the young Jacob win his love
column42: and will the old Jacob regains his peace of mind?Finally

But these uncertainties didn't stop me from enjoying the story.  Surprising twist.  Sweet ending."

column6: "reviewText": "When Jacob Jankoswki learns of the death of both of his parents in an automobile accident
column7: his grief renders him unable to sit for his final exams at Cornell Vet school and he hops the first train he sees out of town. Fate has intervened
column9: and it turns out that the train belongs to a traveling circus
column10: which ends up hiring him on as the show's animal doctor. The year is 1931
column16: and August rule the circus with an iron hand. Performers are treated well
column17: but working men often go unpaid or worse
column19: \" or thrown off the moving train in the dead of night. It is a brutal world
column20: and Jacob walks its fine line between working men and performers. One day Jacob falls in love with Marlena
column21: the show's star attraction and the wife of homicidally paranoid schizophrenic August
column22: and their worlds at the circus will never be the same.This is an excellent and engrossing novel
column23: told from the point of view of Jacob both in 1931 and today
column24: with him at age 93 and in a nursing home
column25: reflecting on past memories. Pull back the tent flap and step right in to the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth. You will yearn to be sitting in the circus train's boxcar
column26: curled up with a book by the light of a flickering kerosene lantern amidst the folds of big top canvas as you roll on through the night to the next town and the next big show."

column6: "reviewText": "As I have stated before
column7: one of my MANY quirks is that I must read a book before I watch the movie. When I read in Entertainment Weekly the Reese Witherspoon and Robert Pattison would be starring in the film adaptation of Water for Elephants
column8: I knew that I had to pick it up. I rarely pay full price for a book. However
column9: this one had such rave reviews that I couldn't help myself. Still
column10: it sat on my bookcase until this week when I promised to read it before the opening of the movie. Honestly
column11: I was greatly disappointed.Sara Gruen tells the story of Jacob Jankowski who is so distraught after his parents' deaths that he runs away with the circus. He leaves between his education at Cornell University and his future as a veterinarian. Fortunately
column12: his study of veterinary medicine helps him land a job as the circus' vet. While touring with the circus he meets a number of characters from a red haired midget clown
column13: to an old circus worker who is struck with \"jake walk\" (a condition brought on by drinking tainted whiskey). Jacob soon discovers that life on the road is beyond trying. When an elephant is brought on as part of the show
column14: Jacob finds himself torn between his job as a compassionate vet and the rules of the circus. This causes Jacob to bump heads with his boss
column16: who is beyond temperamental and at times masochistic. To complicate matters
column17: Jacob is in love with the lead actress of the show
column19: who just happens to be August's wife.While the subject matter of the circus would seem to be incredibly interesting
column20: this novel was boring from start to finish. The entire plot was cliched
column22: and the characters were without depth. From the first chapter
column23: I knew the exact path that the novel was going to take. Every time I thought to put the book down
column24: I convinced myself to give it one more chance. It was after all a bestseller
column26: I thought it would get better. It never did. If anything
column27: it got worse as every cliche was reinforced. The only twist came at the very end and was so absurd I had to re-read the last few pages three times over to make sure that I read it correctly. A book is only as good as its character development but in this novel there is no development. Though Jacob attempts to mature
column28: he can't seem to figure out what his priorities are. Incidentally
column29: neither can Gruen for she has Jacob bemoan his conflicting emotions between his love for Marlena and his feelings towards animal abuse. Fortunately for Jacob
column30: the animals take their fate into their own hands which relieves Jacob of having to develop. I hope
column31: for the box office's sake
column32: that the movie fails to resemble the book. Either way
column33: I will not be the first in line at the theater."

column6: "reviewText": "A sad story
column7: beautifully told. Gruen cuts effortlessly between a faultless evocation of a seedy circus during the Depression - a grotesquerie if ever there was one -  and the modern-day life of an nonagenarian trapped in a failing body and a souless nursing home. Gruen's vivid prose and dead-on dialog transport the reader to a place and time
column9: that does not fail to fascinate.  What in less talented hands might easily be a depressing tale of old age is animated by the spunk and wit of her main character.  My only complaint about the story is its ending
column10: which I frankly found implausible.  But that's a minor complaint about an otherwise absorbing book."

When the elephant comes to town

You look up from the page at your surroundings and feel a momentary confusion.  The morning light that was streaming through your window when you started reading is now afternoon light coming through the door.  That rare book that

Most of the \"old Jacob\" chapters are tedious to read and the payoff at the end with him is pretty small--especially as you aren't really sure how he got to be so grumpy and bitter.The main thing I disliked about this book is that it gives away the ending in the first chapter. You already know the hero prevails and the tension or the thrill of finding out what will happen is gone."

column6: "reviewText": "When a friend recommended this book I was hesitant because I normally do not like novels that revolve around history or romance. I honestly read the book to appease my friend
column7: and was blown away by the characters and the storyline. The book was definitely not the boring and corny romance story I expected it to be. I found Water for Elephants to be captivating
column9: and heartbreaking.The book begins with a young veterinary student who discovers that his parents have been killed in a car accident. He returns home to find that he has been left with nothing and that his parents had put everything at stake for his ivy league education. When they died their home
column11: and savings were all lost to the bank. Overcome by grief
column12: he is unable to complete his finals and runs away from everything and everyone he knows. At a loss for direction and purpose
column13: he jumps a train in the dead of night hoping to find himself in a strange town where he can start to live again. Instead
column14: he finds himself on a circus train
column15: where he becomes engrossed in a community unlike anything that he has ever experienced. The weeks and months that follow are both his saving grace and his living hell."

column6: "reviewText": "What an intriguing story!  From the first gripping lines of the prologue

column12: and is a sharp portrayal of the seedier side of the depression era sideshow life.  The author juxtaposed greed
column16: and the fascinating circus world of cheap glamour and talented charlatans against the bittersweet remembrances of an old man and his present day frustration with trying to live life more fully at an advanced age.  There is a little surprise at the end that I had not foreseen.  The back of the book describes this work with words like vivid
column18: and riveting.  It is all of those things and more - a great story well told.  Water for elephants is highly recommended."

Add to that the constant  cutting back and forth from young-buck Jacob to retirment-home Jacob and you feel not that you're immersed in another world

column6: "reviewText": "I loved this book.  I could not put it down once I began reading it. Perhaps it's because I'm rapidly approaching the age where I could end up in a nursing home myself
column7: but that part of the book fascinated me. It's from the perspective of a 93-year-old man in a nursing home.  It rang true.  I was touched by the nurse who treated him like a person
column9: and cried with him when his family failed to show up to take him to the larger-than-life event he had looked forward to throughout the book--the circus.  It made me think back over the experiences with our own parents and wish I could go back and do things differently.The other part of the book
column10: the flashbacks into this man's history were fast-paced and exciting.  I immediately sympathized when
column12: he lost his parents and found himself alone in the world
column13: and understood his running away from it all. Maybe I question the believability of one or two points while he traveled with the circus
column14: but not enough that it marred my enjoyment of the book.  I simply took it as an indication of how much things have changed in this country over time. What would not fly now might have at one time. It opened my eyes to how easy it is to become absorbed into any society (even the world of a traveling circus)  and how to survive
column15: a person must abide by rules they might otherwise never consider.  The book showed the higher and baser aspects of human nature
column16: all of which I found easily believable.  The world is filled with people who have differing stories and problems.  We don't all behave the same or believe the same
column17: but we do conform to the ethics of our individual worlds--good or bad.  I believe the author demonstrated that  beautifully.I read some of the other reviews
column18: and was saddened that some people couldn't see past  the imperfections and simply enjoy the different facets of the story.  It's a good one.I highly recommend this book to anyone who loves a good read."

column6: "reviewText": "WATER FOR ELEPHANTS is like candy for readers.  It was one of two best books I've read in the past year.  In fact
column7: it probably ranks as one of my favorite books of all time.  It was expertly
column9: written by Sara Gruen.  The novel tells the story from the perspective of Jacob Jankowski who currently resides in a nursing home.  The story alternates between Jacob's current living situation and the story of his past
column10: how he once worked in a circus during the first part of the 20th century.  The impending visit of a traveling circus next door to the nursing home prompts him to remember the details of his circus life/experiences when he was a young man.Gruen's description of the nursing home
column12: and its day-to-day activities was spot-on.  Having visited my grandparents on several occasions in their nursing home
column13: I could easily visualize and relate to Jacob's experiences.  It really came to life.You can tell that a lot of research was also put into the circus recollections of Jacob Jankowski.  Gruen delves into circus life in the early 20th century when circuses traveled via train from town to town
column14: and animal welfare and regulations were little more than an afterthought.  I found all of Jankowski's experiences intriguing and actually felt like I was experiencing them right along with him.  The characterizations felt realistic
column16: and I could easily distinguish between the many different circus workers
column17: and even some of the more prominent animals.It wasn't until halfway through the novel
column19: that I realized how the nursing home is a metaphor for the circus.  Gruen makes subtle comparisons between the animals in the circus and the residents of nursing home.  They're both herded
column22: \"I'm so used to being scolded and herded and managed and handled that I'm no longer sure how to react when someone treats me like a real person.\"  So true.  And sad.Now that I've read this fantastic book
column23: I'm very eager to see the forthcoming movie adaptation.  I'd like to say that I'd love to see a sequel to this great tale; however
column24: I think Jacob Jankowski's story has already been told in full in this one well-crafted novel."

column6: "reviewText": "I couldn't put this down.  A wonderful story
column7: with rich authentic detail."

column6: "reviewText": "You've heard the story about the blind man feeling an elephant and trying to describe what it is? In many ways
column7: I felt the same way reading Sara Gruen's fast-paced and engaging story. It is an oddity. It is wondrous. And it also has some plodding
column8: filthy elements.\"Water for Elephants\" starts with a grippping prologue
column9: during which we see the murder of a circus employee in the 1930s. The story then switches back and forth between young and old Jacob
column10: a man who gets pulled into the circus life
column14: and then reflects back on that as an old man. Gruen does a fine job creating this empathetic character
column15: though the old man's story becomes less important and almost campy by the end. The young man's story delves deeply into circus life
column16: with lots of interesting details and conflict
column17: although the characters are all fairly black and white
column18: with the villains being obvious and predictable. For some reason
column19: Gruen also seems compelled to give us lurid details of the circus striptease and Jacob's own loss of virginity at the hands of the \"cooch tent\" prostitutes. Why these elements are described in such detail only detracts from the already shallow love story to come. It would be nice to see some intellectual dialogue between our male and female leads
column22: \" and the surface attraction of teenage relationships.Soon
column23: Jacob's background in veterinary studies allows him to find a place onboard the circus train
column24: during which he falls in love with Marlena
column25: a woman trapped in an abusive relationship. When the circus procures a new elephant for its act
column26: it provides a link between Jacob and Marlena
column27: as well as with Rosie the elephant. The problem is the jealous and psychotic August
column28: Marlena's husband. We know he must be removed from the picture for this to work. Deeply ethical and moral issues come into play
column29: but Gruen chooses the easy route and solves the problem in a somewhat satisfactory but highly implausible way. This is only underlined by the equally implausible solution of old-man Jacob's frustrations. Sure
column30: it's all warm and gushy
column31: but the deep research and texture of the circus and some of its elements give way to romanticized solutions that turn a historic novel into one of borderline fantasy.With all the fanfare over this novel and tie-in movie
column32: I suspect I'll be accused of being the blind man here in my description of the \"elephant.\" Many elements were strong and well done
column33: but much like Sebold's \"The Lovely Bones
column34: \" all of the wonderful storybuilding gives way to a conclusion that feels a bit forced and too easy."

column7: it's the tale of an old man

column6: "reviewText": "Wow! Sara Gruen is a master storyteller. Her words make the often seedy yet oh-so-fascinating world behind the scenes of a legendary circus train seem so real
column7: so here and now. The central figure of Jacob Jankowski is so well written. I am especially taken with the depiction of life in a nursing home with the body of a 93-year-old and the wit and mind of a much much younger man. It gave me a whole new perspective on how sad and depressing life must be like in an institution like that and will make me spend more time getting to know those who find their homes in such a place. But what struck me most was when I read the Afterward in which Ms. Gruen explained the motivation for writing this novel and the incredibly detailed research that she found herself doing just to put pen to paper. Not only is she so very gifted with the ease of writing
column8: but she is very committed to the realism of details. Incredible! She took some really fascinating true stories from some of this country's most storied circuses and rolled them all into one incredible journey. I highly recommed this book to everyone I meet and I will be looking for more of her works to inspire and inform. Do yourself a favor and pick up this book today."

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants begins by pulling back the curtain on the inner workings of a nursing home
column7: a man begins to speak of the adventure of life in the circus. The book reminded me once again of how much I detest nursing homes. I remember when I volunteered at a nursing home... it was so hard to shake the feeling of depression as soon as you walked in
column8: no matter how many activities you planned. It was a sad place filled with lonely people staring out of the front doors just hoping family or friends would come visit them. Yet as you roamed the halls you could hear the most amazing stories of lives lived so fully when age did not seem to have the slightest grip. As you read Water for Elephants just like with any life there are parts which you might wish had been edited out
column9: yet the story so clearly shines the light on a life lived fully and how society tries to shelve those it believes no longer have something of value to offer...**This book is not recommended for all ages

column6: "reviewText": "A remarkably fast read
column7: leaving the reader breathless from tight action and tingling suspense.  This book reveals the glitz and sparkle of the circus

column9: who ties the events together  with skillful repetition of words and phrases.  I wish there were more novels that take place during the Depression - an era that had such enormous impact on our society and continues to reverberate in modern times.  This book did not make me want to run away and join a circus.  It did make me happy that movements toward animal-less circuses have made a toehold."

column6: "reviewText": "Sarah Gruen clearly establishes and proves her research of traveling circuses in the 1920s and 30s in this novel. Written from the point of view of the protagonist

column32: considering that he makes some rash decisions

column35: the performers

column40: August's wife. I mean
column41: if you are going to write about the circus
column42: and do the research on it
column43: why not concentrate more attention on events that involve the history of the circus. There was a pronounced shift to the love affair between Jacob and Marlena

column46: it was an enjoyable and relatively quick read. Gruen's ability to detail scenery and hook the reader into a story is present from the beginning to end and her writing flows smoothly. This is the kind of book that has many redeeming qualities

column6: "reviewText": "We can read in an author's note that Sara Gruen has studied elephant behavior.  She has more than studied it she has affectingly captured it in Rosie
column7: a large gray elephant and the one hope of the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth
column8: a down at the heels circus trying to make a go of it during the Depression.Now
column9: Rosie wasn't too much of a hope because she was lovable but could not follow any command .  Rosie's only unique characteristic was a seemingly unquenchable thirst for  lemonade.  Her inability to perform was no excuse for the intolerable cruelty visited upon her by August
column10: the callous menagerie director who thought nothing of tossing a lit cigarette into Rosie's open mouth.  He didn't limit his abuse to helpless animals but also mistreated his lovely wife

column12: Water For Elephants is at its heart the story of three - Jacob

column14: and finds a home with the circus
column17: Rosie.  It's a poignant look at their lives set against an oppressive
column19: and a look back at our country during the grueling Depression years.  Most importantly
column20: it's a reminder of the resiliency of human beings and how love can heal.- Gail Cooke"

column11: renting it).Water for Elephants is definitely different from the other fiction I normally read.  The book takes place after the Great Depression
column12: and Gruen did a lot of research surrounding circuses during that time to influence her book.  Many of the chapters began with a picture from circus archives

I absolutely loved how the chapters alternated between the main character's experience in his early 20's as the circus veterinarian and as a 93-year-old man in a nursing home.  It really made me think about the stories of my own grandparents
column14: who are nearing their 90's themselves.The diverse cast of characters in the circus also made the drama of circus life a fascinating read.  I had no idea of the caste system in circus life
column15: the treatment of employees and animals alike
column16: and how competitive circus troupes were during this challenging era in U.S. history.I have heard that the book is better than the movie.  I admit that I am a bit skeptical about the movie given some of the casting choices for its main characters.  But
column18: I do intend to see the movie to see how it compares to one of the best books I've read so far this year.  I highly recommend this book for those who want a story with adventure
column20: and excitement under the big top."

column6: "reviewText": "A very unusual book. I couldn't put it down. It gives an insight to circus life in the days when they travelled by train. It is written through the eyes of a young lad who traumatised by the death of his parents was unable to complete his final exam to become a vet and accidentally joins the circus. The characters and the animals are all very real. Some you love and some you hate (never the animals. Anyone who loves circuses and remembers (or would like to know) how they used to be will love this book."

column6: "reviewText": "The love triangle at the heart of the narrative comes right out of Sophie's Choice.  A beautiful yet disconnected young woman and her gregarious alpha male husband befriend and uplift a lonely young intellectual.  The climax confrontation and subsequent revelation of the true nature of the husband's problems are blatant plagiarisms.  But the thing that tipped me off early on wasn't the love triangle.  It was instead when a character named Kinko is mistakenly referred to as \"stinko\".  You may recall Meryl Streep doing the same thing when referring to Stingo.  Unfortuantely for fans of this book

His bitter and sarcastic exterior conceals a deep pain and the certain knowledge that the better years of his life have passed by.  As Citizen Kane says old age is the only disease that no one wants to be cured of.Things weren't always this way Jacob was young once until an unfortunate series of circumstances ended his hopes of being a vet forever.  He is then taken on a journey across the country with a circus it is a fun little book and well worse the trip.  The characters have life and everything that fictional characters should have.  You'll find it to be so good that even though you can see the ending coming from three miles away you will not even care.Overall-It is rare that I run across a book this good"

I wasn't all that attached to any of the human characters
column7: but I loved the animals and actually think my favourite character was the Circus itself. I was able to view the Circus as a living

It was completely distracting from the story and I was disappointed how often it would randomly be thrown into the writing. I felt it was almost always unnecessary...it did more to detract from the novel than it ever could have added. I suppose it was a wake-up call for me about the difference between young adult fiction and adult fiction. Had it not been for those two things I would have definitely rated the book a 4 or 5."

column6: "reviewText": "\"Life is the best show on earth\"I have never read a book about the circus - or even gone to a circus for that matter. Yet
column7: reading this book through Jacob Jankowsi's memories
column8: I feel like I know what goes on like I've been many times before.\"I don't talk much about those days. Never did. I don't know why - I worked on circuses for nearly seven years
column9: and if that isn't a fodder for conversation
column10: I don't know what is.\"There is so much that happens in Water for Elephants

column12: and it's own perils as well. When he meets Marlena and begins developing feelings for her
column13: he finds himself standing on thin ice with her husband August
column14: and when things begin to turn sour it seems he's not the only one out to get him.\"I am ninety. Or ninety-three. One or the other.\"But there's another side to this story - the Mr. Jankowski who lives in the nursing home after the rest of his family seems to have forgotten about him. The man who doesn't quite remember how old he is. Who doesn't like the 'food' (if you can call it that). The man who still remembers his days at The Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth.The story was well crafted and encompassed all the different elements of life in the circus. Some actual photographs found at the beginning of each chapter added to the 'realness' of the plot and make the whole store seem even more realistic. Similarly
column16: and the patriarchal hierarchy of circus performers vs. workmen was explored also. I loved to see how Marlena became a stronger character throughout the novel
column17: eventually taking a definite stand against her mentally instable husband. And Jacob? Well
column18: during the whole story he was there to learn the ropes and was always there to stand for what was right - for the animals he treated and the people he became friends with.*CONCLUSION*Overall
column19: I really enjoyed Water for Elephants. I felt completely immersed in the circus lifestyle and was always desperately wanting to flick through the pages and find out what was happening next. Next on my list is to see the movie and see how it compares."
column21: "summary": "\"Life is the best show on earth\""

column6: "reviewText": "On the simplest level
column7: all I can say is that it didn't amuse me and I couldn't force myself to finish it. But I'm a \"hard sell\" for fiction
column8: and I can see by the other reviews that many people loved it. Lucky them!On a slightly more analytic level
column9: I'd say that what prevented me from enjoying the book was the \"voice\" of the narrator
column10: who is supposed to be a man in his nineties remembering his youth in the circus. I'm a man approaching seventy
column11: with some circus experiences as a teenager in Iowa and as the father of a circus acrobat in the Cirque de Soleil era. I found the \"voice\" of the narrator unconvincing
column13: as a male of the species and as a male American of the 1930s and 1940s. I couldn't get past that central implausibility. I found myself scoffing at the sensibilities of the pseudo-male narrator at every emotional turn of this quite melodramatic novel."

column6: "reviewText": "I could not have loved it more. Water for Elephants is one of those wonderful novels that has an interesting setting
column7: but it doesn't let the setting take over the story. It is a novel about the people in that place
column8: and the people of Benzini's circus took over my mind and stay with me still.Jacob begins Water for Elephants alone. Orphaned by his immigrant parents
column9: he is weeks away from his Cornell graduation
column10: but he simply cannot return to the life he has known. He jumps aboard a moving train-the train carrying the Benzini circus to its next production. No one on the circus cares that Jacob didn't finish his final exams. The diploma
column13: and nobody here gives a damn about that. You're on a show now. The rules are different.\"In fact
column14: the circus seems to have no rules at all. Jacob somehow finds other kind souls among the misfits
column15: and these people work together to protect themselves and the animals. The villians-Uncle Al and August-are well described and three-dimensional. You understand why they behave the way they do. These villians are not cookie-cutter images
column16: and their real-world sensibilities make them even more frightening."

column11: animals and popcorn. I felt what the characters felt when they fell upon hard times. This book also opened my eyes regarding how a rough slice of life a small circus can be.Bring on the circus parade!"

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is about an old man at the end of his days reflecting upon his life and the events that lead him to run away and join the circus right before he finishes college.  His story goes back and forth between his modern day stay at a nursing home and his days in his early 20s during the Great Depression traveling around the country with the Great Benzini Brothers Circus.Sara Gruen does a phenomenal job of painting a vivid portrait of Depression era America and of the end of the golden age of circus life in the USA.  The Photos that head each chapter are fun little bonuses that let you see the actual performers of this time as well as some of the settings in which the book takes place.The characters come to life and are vivid portrayals of heroes and villians.  The relationships formed amongst all the characters are memorable and keep you wanting more.  A page turner that does a good job of keeping you interested by flipping back and forth between past and present.5 star recommendation."

column6: "reviewText": "I don't consider myself a lit-snob by any means. I love fun
column7: breezy reads like many readers out there. I have read `em high and... low. There are times when I just want an escapist read. But given the perimeters--those reads usually deliver the goods. Though the stories may be a tad simple.Here we have a book that's been out a while. Supposedly one with some substance. So we have a guy who winds up joining the circus after ditching an Ivy league education in the Depression years.  I can go with it. No problem there. But then we have the host of characters in the circus itself. Some of this is good reading--but then--we have problems of cliched
column8: predicatable writing wedged between sections of rather better-than-average writing. And all too many flat characters with little substance.Much of this appears in this story. That's the problem. Besides
column9: Jacob is just not all that engaging to me or a convincing character. And the story comes off predictable and rather weak. So it's a passable beach read.Given the kind of over-the-top and unsubstantiated praise this novel has received
column11: I can't be the only one who feels this way and I can't help but notice than whenever there is a unfavorable review of this book  there will be an outpouring of five star reviews--one after another--that are all two or three sentences of praise and little real commentary.Coincidence?Again
column13: but this is no KITE RUNNER or actually
column14: SNOW FLOWER AND THE SECRET FAN
column15: two far better reads than this."

This book has affected me deeply.The last book to touch me this way was some months back when I read \"The Piano Shop on the Left Bank\" by Thad CarhartThe Piano Shop on the Left Bank: Discovering a Forgotten Passion in a Paris Atelierwhich I heartily recommend to you.With \"Water for Elephants\" Sara Gruen creates the long-forgotten days of the Train Circus
column16: and all that life entailed in those days...from the impossible \"set-ups\"
column18: and in many cases \"hasty retreats\" from any particular chosen town before the authorities arrived upon the scene.\"Hard Luck Days\" certainly would be a fitting genre to place this awesome story into. And

column35: an unfortunate
column37: addicted to and dying from Jamaican ginger paralysis

column39: and witness his ways with dealing with those \"done with\" on the traveling show.Sara Gruen has created a most wonderfully \"real\" environment and \"time\" for this story to inhabit
column40: one that clearly allows one to \"see\"
column41: \"feel\"
column42: \"smell\" and \"witness\" at what seems \"first hand\" how life was for those who lived \"the Big Top life\"....a marvelous talent for a writer. If she were never to write another story
column43: this one

column6: "reviewText": "This is an engaging
column7: fast paced story of a veterinarian in a circus during Prohibition.  The plot tension is well-handled and intense.  There is plenty of likeable characters

column6: "reviewText": "I usually don't read mass market
column7: best selling paperbacks written by women. Nothing wrong with women writers I just don't read them. A friend at work asked if I wanted to read this book and her previous recs were mostly good.I really enjoyed this story. It was a nice change of pace.If you are a guy read this book cause you then have opportunity to see: What girls want in a man and why girls act like they do. That seems like a blanket statement but being a guy I would not have done many things the hero did and I couldn't understand why he thought what he did and was so against sound advice til I realized the author was a women and she was trying to write from a guys perspective. Of course what I have written may not be true and there are surely arguments against but I think I am right.I think you should read this book and am looking forward to the movie"

column7: like me

column10: and take this excellent journey with this gifted author.  Water for Elephants
column12: is a very moving story about relationships and family.  When Jacob Jankowski loses his family
column13: he actually joins the circus.  Not because he wanted to
column14: but because it presented itself.  Fortuantely
column15: Jacob was studying to become a veterinarian and the circus was full of animals.  The story is told from the perspective of Jacob as an elderly man and Jacob as a young man.The relationships that Jacob forms during this excellent novel form the corserstone of the story.  I found myself caring about a grouchy dwarf and his 3-legged dog
column17: and a cast of numerous colorful characters.  The evocative descriptions of the circus itself - the Benzini Brothers; a wannabee Ringling Brothers - during the Depression; actually put you on a railcar with the smell of dust all around you.  This is certainly no glamorous lifestyle
column18: and Gruen does an exceptional job of providing vivid imagery.  The menagerie that Jacob helps care for are an important piece of this wide ranging cast that features individuals that are easy to hate and aome that are easy to love.  Jacob meets Marlena
column19: who is married to the evil August
column20: and the relationships that ensue become increasingly complicated.I now know more about circuses that I ever knew I wanted to.  I am glad that I do
column21: because the learning was all part of the great fun to be had here.  This is a very entertaining and compelling book.  I could not read it fast enough
column22: yet I felt myself wanting to slow down to enjoy it all the more.  I rate this a highly recommended 5 stars.  Enjoy!"

It is imaginative and takes me into the wonderfully described world of a 1930's third-rate train (traveling) circus. If this world seems a little grungy

The introduction of the novel is very good and it's easy to read although at times when he's reminiscing

column6: "reviewText": "Definitely worth reading. It offers a great look at life in an on-the-road circus

column8: but who believes he has been put out to pasture.I would have given the book probably five stars if it hadn't contained so much profanity and scatological language.  The old man's tale would have done a very good job of living on its own without that."

column6: "reviewText": "As a person in his 70s who deals with a mother-in-law in her 90s
column7: I found much Jacob's trials in the nursing home close to home. That he could escape into the memory of his youthful connection with the circus was probably a life saver for him.Ms Gruen did a masterful job of separating and at the same time blending Jacob's experiences in his youth with those in his present state of being 90 or 93.It is worth reading this book all the way through to get to a surprising and wonderful end that I shall not reveal so as not to spoil it for others.Ms Gruen obviously researched circuses. Her attention to detail
column8: both when she wrote about the circus and also when she wrote about the nursing home helped make the story realistic.All in all
column9: it was well written and held my attention."

column6: "reviewText": "I was really looking forward to reading this book

column9: except at certain points when he was elderly.  I actually felt very embarrassed for the author while reading the many squalor erotica scenes that did nothing to help me connect or care for any of the characters.  I was expecting a heartfelt romance
column13: are so one dimensional that I found the whole thing absurd and unbelievable.  I kept trying to get into it and hoped it would get better as it went along
column14: but no such luck.  If you must read it
column15: try to borrow it instead of buying or see if you can pick up a cheap copy at a thrift store.  Better yet
column16: spend your time reading something with a convincing story and engaging characters instead."

column6: "reviewText": "Even people who say \"I only read nonfiction\" can enjoy this entertaining novel
column7: which is rich with fascinating details about life in a traveling circus during Prohibition and the Depression. For example
column8: circus members stocked up on booze in Canada and sneaked it across the border into the US  by storing it in the middle of the train car carrying camels
column10: and customs agents didn't want to mingle with them. Against an unusual background
column11: the fictional characters (humans and other animals) weave a story that keeps readers turning the pages."

column6: "reviewText": "Do you know how difficult it is to run and cry at the same time? Good books do that do me. And this was a good book.Brilliant
column7: actually.That's the best way to describe it. The words themselves
column9: the anticipation. It's brilliant.Water for Elephants by Sara Gruen is the story of Jacob Jankowski at twenty-three and at ninety (or ninety-three). At twenty-three
column10: he ran away and joined the circus after his parents were killed in an accident. He had been studying to be a vet and was all but final exams. In the circus
column14: Jacob's in a nursing home.The story fits well with Resurrection with it's themes of dignity
column16: and anticipation. Twenty-three-year-old Jacob's Resurrection scene spread the resurrection and transformation to others. The Jacob in the end of the book is different from the Jacob in the beginning
column17: and his transformation allows him to step in and fight for others. He may not always succeed in the way he desires
column18: but he hands resurrection to others. It's a story about coming home.It's a story about dignity. Gruen frames the story so that you are hit by the fact that this old man
column19: left to drool over Jello his last few years
column20: is the twenty-three-year-old Jacob in the circus. These stories aren't just stories. They're stories of people we've forgotten about. It made me remember sitting at tea with my grandmother listening to her stories. I wish I'd written them down.It's about the dignity of the outcasts. In Depression-era America
column24: and the bottom-of-the-barrell working class were the outcasts. They weren't \"needed\" in society. They were easily disposed of. Because of this
column25: Jacob becomes a Christ-figure restoring the dignity of a midget and a drunk
column27: both human and animal.Gruen's strongest point
column29: is her ability to build anticipation. One scene captures it: Grady has (bad) news for Jacob. In waiting for Grady to spill it
column30: Jacob notices the two drops of grease leaking from Grady's hamburger. Brilliance in these little details. The reader (namely
column31: me) wants to shake Grady by the shoulders and scream at him to tell already!It's also about what Gruen doesn't write
column32: where she holds back. I think as writers
column33: sometimes we think we have to fill in every detail. For example
column34: in a fight scene
column35: Gruen doesn't give a blow-by-blow. Rather
column36: she focuses on the confusion of the protag (Jacob)
column37: his swirling thoughts
column38: a moment of pain here or there
column39: his inability to stop hitting. Rather than observing the fight as you would a movie
column40: you're caught up in the hero. I love this."

column6: "reviewText": "I. SettingDepression era. The glory days of the circus. A time when a plethora of men out-of-work combined with a plethora of families looking for amusement and a modicum of freaks. Let's face it: throughout history
column7: mankind has been sprinkled with a modicum of physical and mental freaks. Their ability to find job satisfaction fluctuates
column8: but they're always out there.(Caveat: As a child in Wisconsin
column9: I certainly attended a circus or two
column10: and dutifully watched the now-defunct Great Circus Parade on TV
column11: but have never visited the Circus World Museum in Baraboo. I am just as much an outsider as the rest of you
column12: unless you are a Flying Wallenda
column13: in which case I am a much bigger outsider.)The circus of Water for Elephants is the (name of circus)
column14: which is certainly a mouthful. To the eyes of this non-Flying Wallenda
column15: it appears to be pretty typical of the time
column16: especially once it gets an elephant. More on that later.II. PlotJust a brief synopsis here
column17: since you have likely seen the film
column19: or are planning to do so. Jacob Jankowski (protagonist)
column20: runs away to join the circus after his parents die in a car accident. Perhaps unwisely
column21: he does so just before finishing his veterinary degree. He meets August
column22: the bipolar head trainer. He falls in love with Marlena
column23: August wife. After the circus picks up an elephant named Rosie
column24: Jacob uses his profound understanding of animals (and the Polish language) to bond with her. And with Marlena. Since August is a total jackhole
column26: this relationship is doomed.Luckily for everybody
column27: the circus owner (Big Al) is known for cutting corners
column28: and his spendthrift ways end in total calamity. The animals get loose
column30: and Jacob sweeps Marlena off to live happily ever after. They have children
column31: he works for a real circus (Ringling)
column32: and end up ditching the nursing home for yet another circus.III. CharactersI couldn't help but picture Robert Pattinson in my head as I read this book
column33: and I hated that. Same for Reese Witherspoon and Christoph Waltz. Nothing to be done
column34: but I wish it had been left to my imagination.Though I found the premise a little unbelievable on the whole (literally running away to join the circus?)
column35: I did empathize with Jacob. Preparing for a profession that requires you to stick your hand up a cow's butt is hard enough. Once your parents are tragically killed? Forget about it.The Jacob/Marlena/August love triangle didn't convince me either
column36: but perhaps that was residual cringing from Jacob's sexual awakening facilitated by the ladies of the cooch tent.(I should also apologize to the man sitting next to me on the bus that one day. Sir
column37: if you happened to notice that I was reading about a man getting deflowered
column39: the character I liked best was old Jacob. (No
column40: my favorite was not the elephant. I did not cheer when she killed August
column41: nor at the many times the reader was reminded that ELEPHANTS ARE PEOPLE TOO. Save it for Greenpeace.) Old Jacob
column42: an imperfect narrator
column43: combined the indignities of old age with a fierce desire to keep living. He doesn't remember how old he is
column44: nor which of his many relatives was supposed to take him to the circus camped next to the nursing home. But he's feisty enough to scoot himself over when no one else will
column45: and it's that same sort of self-determination that won us two world wars
column46: darnit!*wipes tear from eye*Maybe I'm just nostalgic for the grandpa I never had. It's like that scene from The Royal Tenebaums
column47: when Royal reads the gravestone of a man who died heroically on a sinking ship. The viewer is led to believe this is a relative of Royal's. He then says something like
column48: \"What a man. I wish I knew him.\"Well
column49: I wish I knew Jacob Jankowsky. After he finished all that silliness with the circus.IV. StyleGruen uses a framing device
column50: in which the bulk of the book is recalled through the eyes of the now-aged main character. The parallel? Present-day Jacob is eagerly anticipating a trip to the circus
column51: whereas past-day Jacob worked many years on a circus. I do love the framing device
column52: confusing as it is when you start the book. (More or less than in medias res? Discuss.)I appreciate a single protagonist/point of view kept constant throughout the book. I would not have liked to read a chapter told by Marlena
column54: or the dwarf. It's hard enough keeping these people (and animals) straight with just one narrator.The ending was a little tidy for my taste--I kept expecting Marlena to miscarry or die in childbirth. That their long and productive union disappointed me probably speaks more to my own predilection for dystopian fiction (where EVERYBODY dies) than Gruen's storytelling abilities.The pacing was good
column55: and you definitely knew when the book climaxed. I appreciated the real-life archival circus photographs scattered throughout
column56: as well as the small details of circus life: the cookhouse flag
column58: the segregation of performers and labor. Who knew that 50
column59: 000 people were paralyzed after drinking Jamaica ginger extract? Not me
column60: even after watching the entire first season of Boardwalk Empire. HBO fail.Conclusion:Water for Elephants is a \"slice of life\" novel. In this case
column61: Depression-era circus life. My criticisms aside
column62: it's a worthy read. While researching this blog entry (ie reading the Wikipedia article)
column63: I learned that this novel originated in NaNoWriMo. If given one month to write a book

column6: "reviewText": "I had no or low expectations about this book. I didn't know anything about the plot. It was on the bestseller lists
column7: which doesn't necessarily make it a good book
column8: but I was a little intrigued about all the peripheral hubbub about it. If I had known this book really had to do with circuses (That's not a plot spoiler.)
column9: I don't know if I would've started this book. I'm so glad I took the chance. I found it just like a steam engine (read the book); it took a little bit of effort to get rolling
column10: but once it started it just kept picking up speed and going and going and I kept waiting for it to slow
column11: but it didn't. I was amazed that someone actually wrote this story
column12: it was so good. I read it fast and furiously and tensely anticipating what was coming next. I also really appreciated the \"discussion\" with the novelist after the novel itself. I enjoyed her explanations. Kudos to Sara Gruen."

column6: "reviewText": "Circus life
column7: during the American Depression. Told in the first person by Jacob Jankowski a young college boy who is suddenly orphaned and penniless and finds himself literally on board the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth! There's a prologue where we discover a secret which Jacob has kept for seventy years then we begin the story
column8: alternating between 1931 and the modern day with an elderly Jacob.Very easy to read...I found myself flicking pages quickly. Gruen seems to capture the circus's attraction and glitz as well as it's often uncomfortable reality. The hierarchy from the roustabouts to the performers and bosses is fascinating and Gruen's descriptions bring to life the days when circuses had trains (conjuring up images from Dumbo!)The novel pulls you in
column9: starting off slowly and ends up unputdownable as you have to find out what eventually happened/happens. I found the contrast between the way the Jacob of 'then' and 'now' is treated
column10: both startling and thought provoking and ultimately I just really enjoyed reading about something I had little knowledge of
column11: with a good twist in the tale."

I can more easily understand that it was made into a movie (even though I haven't seen it and after reading the book I probably won't)
column10: as I can imagine it is truly a spectacle with all of the color and magic of a circus.  And I will agree with other reviewers that it is well researched and the author does a good job portraying the post-depression times.  But that alone just doesn't carry the rest of the storyline

At the end he wants to \"run away\" from the old folk's home and return to the only life he'd ever known - no surprise there - but it's a ridiculous proposition due to his age and I can't imagine anyone in the circus inviting him.  If you get nothing else from Uncle Al's character it is that he or any man in his position would be ruthless and cut loose anyone who didn't pull their weight
column16: so what would a 90+ year old man do?  Certainly not water the elephants."

column6: "reviewText": "I wound up enjoying the book tremendously
column7: more than I expected to when I started.The story starts out slowly
column8: but subtly draws you in until you are intrigued as to what's going to happen next. The world of circuses
column10: was completely unknown - so I couldn't predict what was coming. I was surprised at what horrible conditions both the people and the animlas endured on \"train circuses\" of the 1920s-1940s. If you're looking for a happy \"magical\" story about running away to join the circus
column11: this isn't it.The character development is limited
column12: as it is written in the first person. My favorite character was Rosie the elephant - because the narrator clearly loves her and therefore you love her.Apparently Gruen did vast research on the train circuses - making her use of jargon
column13: lore and the incorporating of actual stories the core of the novel.As far as I can remember
column14: this is the first time I read a book that provides insight from the perspective of an old person living in a nursing home or assisted living facility. Jacob's frustration at his body failing him and of people making decisions for him and treating him like a child
column15: along with feelings of being abandoned and useless really got to me and were gently and movingly written.The magic comes in the highly improbable
column16: yet tremendously satisfying ending.I definitely recommend the book."
