column6: "reviewText": "This engrossing book sucks you into its colorful world and holds you there until the 800-pound fat lady sings.Plot summary:Veterinary student Jacob joins the Benzini Bros. circus train in 1931 and falls in love with Marlena
column7: an equestrian performer
column8: who happens to be married to his boss the volatile animal director August.Pros:This is a must-read
column9: page-turner featuring a unique setting for a classic love triangle. It's gripping and complex
column10: with some wonderfully written supporting characters such as Walter
column12: Uncle Al and Rosie the elephant. The tension slowly builds between the central characters
column13: but is relieved with some laugh-out-loud moments from circus lore. The story is told in flashbacks from a 93 year old. There are some truly poignant moments at the nursing home. This is a really unique
column15: and I liked that I couldn't guess the ending.Cons:Virtually non-existent and what there is is nitpicky
column16: but here goes... It's written in present tense
column17: which takes some getting used to. On p. 147: \"A black boy offers to shine my shoes.\"  My 98-year-old grandmother uses the term \"colored\" and I believe that was the common term in the `30s and that \"black\" was a '60s term. Again
column18: stupid nitpicky and doesn't detract from this fabulous book.Worth all of the hype
column19: this is one of the best books I've read this year (and I've read a lot of books.) Read the book before you see the movie. Enthusiastically recommended. 5 stars."

column6: "reviewText": "-Juvenile and disney plot.-faulty and unrealistic details.-Uninteresting and underdeveloped characters.-Premature professions of love.Basically
column7: this book reads like a typical Hollywood movie. This is unfortunate
column8: but it is representative of a new class of novelists who are more influenced by movies' depiction of culture

column6: "reviewText": "If you ever dreamed of running away to join the circus
column7: this is a must read. A deep look into the mysterious world..."

column6: "reviewText": "I’m ambivalent about this novel. It’s good. It’s very nice. It’s a page-turner. It doesn’t suffer the fate of many
column7: many novels — even some of my best loved — but there was something missing.That’s a convoluted way of saying I enjoyed it but it didn’t stick with me.Plot and pacing are excellent in this novel. I often write that most books need to be shorter. Novelists seem to always come up with a great opening. Better ones have great endings. Most fail in the middle. That middle third of most novels is such a bore to me. I think it’s filler to beef up a word count. I didn’t find this in Water for Elephants at all. Gruen can structure a story and keep the pace going. That’s a terribly hard thing to do and she pulled it off wonderfully.With one glorious exception
column9: the characterization fell flat for me. Did I care about the characters? Kinda. Did I care about the romance? No. What did touch me was the role of the older Jacob. How this young
column10: female writer climbed into the head of a ninety plus year old man
column11: I’ll never know but his thoughts and actions rang true. He was facing death but still facing life and his inner monologue caused an almost claustrophobic feeling in myself. My god
column12: I kept thinking. This could very well be me - trapped in a body
column13: aware that I’m losing my mind to age and
column15: without the ability to do a damned thing about it. I hope to elicit that kind of reaction in a reader one day.The parts of the novel confined to an old man doing nothing much more than sitting in a wheelchair will stick with me for a while. I may go back and read those bits at times. The parts with the trains
column20: romance and violence? Not so much."

column6: "reviewText": "Excellent read! Ms. Gruen masters character and plot with beautiful prose. I remained captivated and found myself caring for the diverse cast.  Ms. Gruen successfully evokes a sense of the times
column7: the desperate nature of survival during the Depression
column8: as well as one's attempt to salvage one's sense of self as age betrays the body.  The storyline is suspenseful
column10: and woven through with a touch of romance.  The setting is gritty and evokes the reality of Circus life on the road and  the behind-the-scenes work required to attain the magical world the public craves.  Well done!"
column12: "summary": "Who knew aging could be so suspenseful?"

column6: "reviewText": "Actually
column7: come to think of it

column6: "reviewText": "So great I read it twice - and am reviewing both versions at once!Jacob is in the last weeks of veterinary school at Cornell when he is hit with a massive shock: the death of both of his beloved parents
column7: and more importantly the loss of everything he owns to the bank.  This is the throws of the Depression.  He does what every man would do in his situation
column8: hops a train to anywhere only to find out it is the circus train of The Benzini Bros. Greatest Show on Earth!  As the show's veterinarian he forms a close relationship with crazy August (the equestrian trainer)
column10: and Rosie (the elephant).  As the days go on
column11: life on the circus gets crazier and crazier
column12: until one day all hell breaks loose.  What will Jacob do next?This book is narrated by two voices - that of the 90 something year old Jacob (retelling the events as he remembers them) and that of the 20 something year old Jacob (experiencing the events).  The audiobook did an amazing job of casting two narrators and it made it one of the best books I have listened too.  You were easily able to tell at what time you were by who was narrating and it made it feel so real.Gruen does an amazing job of researching the life of circus workers during the Depression.  At no time did I feel that the details were out of place.  You could feel the desperation of the roustabouts when they were continually not paid
column14: ran out of food.  Reading this book was like stepping back in time.I loved this book!  It is easily very near the top of my favorite books list.  According to the authors website
column15: Fox 2000 has purchased the rights to this book to make a movie and hear rumor that Reese Witherspoon might be cast as Marlena.  I think it would make a fantastic movie."

column23: is unnecessary to appreciate the vivid story but definitely made me appreciate the author's research to include tidbits of American history that might otherwise be lost.  I found this novel to be the most compelling book I have ever read and literally lost hours of sleep over it."

column6: "reviewText": "Characters were constantly doing things that just didn't make any sense.  His parents are both killed in a tragic accident a week before his finals
column7: and his professors do NOTHING to give him the benefit of the doubt on his exams?  Were incompletes a complete unknown in this time period?  (There's a lot more
column8: but I'm trying to block it out....)  The main character himself seems to have virtually no inner life except a vague desire to get laid.  At one point he says he's interested in animals
column9: but there sure no evidence of this.The entire first half of the book is exposition about circus life
column10: with a long segment of gratuitous titillation thrown in.  I've got nothing against "gritty" and "true to life".  However
column11: I have no tolerance for scenes that are so obviously there only to sell the book as soft porn to an audience that wouldn't know literature if it hit them in the face.Characters are less 3-D than cardboard cut outs.  My dad's vague recollections of a circus coming to town when he was a kid in this time period were way more riveting.  At least they involved actual people
column12: with real human motivations -- not characters who move from point A to B only because the author's outline said the plot had to move there.And present tense?  Throughout the entire book?  That's a device that should have been discarded in high school.  It does nothing but make me snicker at the author's obvious lack of writing talent.I had heard a rumor that this book was written as a NaNoWriMo project
column13: and I can certainly believe it.  It seems to have been dashed off from a previously constructed outline
column14: without any regard for building up characters and then modifying the plot if it made more sense for their motivations.  The present tense writing style is another give away that this was written in a rush and barely revised.  And the plonking in of vocabulary and "facts" willy-nilly -- stopping what little story there is in mid-stream -- kind of screams "first draft" all the way through."

column6: "reviewText": "***SPOILER ALERT***Put this novel on the FUN READ shelf. Definitely nothing mind-blowing in terms of plot or prose but a very entertaining look at depression era circus life.The author alternates (for the most part) chapters between Jacob's life during the depression and his life as a 90 year old in a nursing home. One gets the sense that the author seeks to evoke some sympathy for the 90 year Jacob's plight. In this endeavor she fails as she never fully fleshes out his relationship with his children. Thus the reader is left feeling slightly apathetic as to his plight as a lonely and ornery old man wasting away in a assisted living facility.Finally
column7: the ending is a bit contrived and convenient. The frail old Jacob making a break for it out of the retirement home and going to the circus event that is in town. There of course he meets and befriends one of the circus directors who spirits him away on their cross country tour. Happily ever blah blah blah.All of this is not to discourage someone from reading this novel. The author can write with rhythm and keeps the pacing light and quick. Viewing the novel as a love story
column8: the author is adept at capturing the dual emotional nature of love with phrases like: \"exhausted and recharged
column9: desperate and fulfilled.\" With a good writer
column10: this book would make a great movie."
column12: "summary": "Fun read and one day a GREAT movie!"

column6: "reviewText": "This is one of those books that I read because I loved the movie first. So
column7: I was quite surprised when I read how the book begins - with the murder of one of the main characters. When I further realized that August does not own the Benzini Brothers
column8: I began to see the movie as its own story separate from the book.Jacob is by far the most interesting character of the book
column9: especially since he tells the story as an old man in a nursing home - and has the wisdom and experience to go with his age. His emotions are infectious and I longed to sit down with him and listen to all of his stories in person way before I finished the book.August is the kind of villain that is confusing in his evil deeds - he has schizophrenia - which makes it somewhat unfair to dislike him so much. His irrational behavior has been exploited for the almighty dollar by Uncle Al - but the real villain tends to fade into the background.Marlena is beautiful to the point of angelic
column10: very little of what she does can be considered wrong in any way
column11: as she is a victim struggling for freedom for most of the book. She approaches August's mood swings with the same caution due a wild animal
column12: and remains faithful to him despite her personal feelings
column13: and does not leave until he first betrays her. Considering how women today will leave their husbands for any reason
column14: I admire her strong morals.The background is set during the Great Depression
column15: which made for many intense situations as the circus struggled to profit
column16: as well as the survival of the cast of characters. Though I studied this period in American history
column17: the direct experience gave me a clearer idea of the desperation of people alive during this time - how easily morals could be put on hold for the sake of another mouthful of food or another coin in the pocket. So many men of the circus would work without pay for the promise of another meal and unending hope that life could still improve.Rosie
column19: is also one of the most fascinating characters in the book. She proved to be only one example of how animals were exploited to the point of cruelty for profit. I could not help wondering where the animal activists were.Needless to say
column20: this book sparked many conversations and inspired many moments of personal contemplation for me. I loved this book

column6: "reviewText": "Jacob Jankowski
column7: the main character
column8: is a 90 or 93 year old man in a nursing home and he tells the story of how he wound up joining a circus in his early 20's.  His parents are both killed in a car accident and finds out that his parents have mortaged everything to pay for his tuition at Cornell Vet school.  Figuring that he is unable to continue his education and he jumps on a train in the middle of the night running away from everything he had known.  The train that he winds up on is a circus train.He befriends several individuals and winds up working for the outfit.  One particular person is a married woman named Marlena.  Jacob's boss is Marlena's husband
column9: August.  August is a bit off mentally to say the least.One of the most remarkable and memorable characters in the book is an elephant that the circus aquired named Rosie.  When she is first aquired August believes she is dumbest animal on earth because she would not do anything that they tried to get her to do.  Because of this August beats Rosie on a regulart basis until Jacob by accident discovers that she only understands commands given to her in Polish.  After that discovery Rosie is the star of the show alongside of Marlena.Things don't stay rosy for long.  August has more fits
column10: ex circus employee's who were thrown off the train catch up

column6: "reviewText": "Water For Elephants
column7: written by Sara Gruen
column8: is a book told as a memoir by a fictional ninety-something old man about his time with the circus as a young man. This experience matured him and forever changed the direction of his life.This book is charming. I could relate to the characters and understand their motivations easily. I enjoyed reading it and have re-read it several times. I highly recommend it to everyone. (Should be at parents discretion as there are some adult themes. Probably best for those over thirteen.)"

column6: "reviewText": "I found this book interesting because of the research Ms. Gruen obviously did on train circuses and depression-era life. I also thought her passages detailing the life of Jake as an old man were the best written things in the book. Since Ms. Gruen is a woman who appears (from her author's photo) to be barely middle-aged
column7: I have to assume that some research went into finding out about the lives of elderly men as well
column8: because she writes these passages with a clear and utterly believable voice that truly resonates.Unfortunately nothing else in the book resonates nearly as much
column9: and there's a lot lacking here. The young version of Jake never takes off as a character
column10: nor does his entirely manufactured love story with a circus bareback rider. We know from the moment he sees Marlena that she'll obviously be his love interest
column11: but their relationship never actually develops before they're suddenly declaring love for one another and hitting the sack.Ms. Gruen also fails in her execution of believable villains. Her two main villains are August
column12: a brutal horse trainer who abuses or neglects all of the animals
column15: but their villainy never really jumps off the page. For some reason
column16: she chose to make her main antagonist (August) Jewish. I still don't understand the reasoning behind that
column17: nor do I understand her choice to call him a paranoid schizophrenic as well. Oh and for good measure
column18: he's also a wife beater. He's simply too many things rolled into one. Perhaps if she'd concentrated on one aspect of his brutality
column19: she could have made him more believable. And unfortunately
column20: since his religion really has nothing else to do with him as a character
column21: it's hard not to simply label Ms. Gruen as anti-semitic. Perhaps if she'd actually used the \"show
column22: don't tell\" philosophy and let us SEE what Uncle Al was doing instead of just hearing about everything second hand from other characters
column23: he wouldn't have seemed so two-dimensional. As it is
column24: I never bought these guys as the towering pillars of pure evil they were obviously supposed to be.I also never bought Jake
column25: at least not as a young man. One minute he's making a vow to himself that he'll stay with the animals so they won't be hurt
column26: because that's what his dead father would want him to do. Yet
column27: he stands by not once but TWICE and allows August to savagely beat an elephant with a hook. It's hard to respect a character like that. Jake rarely takes any real action; he mostly just stands by while things happen TO him or happen *around* him.I also felt the book could have benefited from a diagram. In books that take place on ships
column28: there's usually a sketch in the front of the book with all the parts labeled for readers to refer back to so they can understand the action. I had a lot of trouble visualizing the train where a good 40% of the crucial action takes place in this book
column29: and that was a major barrier to getting into the story. Had there been a sketch of it up front with all the sections labeled
column30: those sections of the story would have been much easier to understand.Overall
column31: I am giving this book 4 stars because of the research
column32: the informative author's note at the end
column33: and the sections with Jake as an old man. I also really got a kick out of the ending. But on the whole
column34: I would recommend this as a library book or a used book store book -- definitely NOT one you pay full price for."

column6: "reviewText": "I think that most people seem to either love this novel or hate it
column7: but I have a hard time stirring myself to care much either way.  It is by no means a standout book
column8: but neither is it so horrible that I couldn't force myself through it.The best writing in the book
column10: are the sequences with Jacob as an old man.  They ring true
column11: and have a poignancy regarding the lives and treatment of the elderly that stirs some guilty discomfort.  Leaving aside the over-the-top
column14: these sequences are satisfying and believable.The larger narrative
column15: that of Jacob in his twenties
column16: also has an air of authenticity
column17: at least in terms of feeling (to an outsider) like a dingy
column19: depression-era circus.  It is successful at creating a strong sense of the world.  But I never found myself getting wrapped up in the stories of any of the individual characters.  In other words
column20: I just didn't get pulled in.Some people probably take offense at the blatant sexuality of a handful of scenes
column21: and at the mistreatment of animals in several more.  I am not personally bothered by these
column22: as they are pertinent to the story
column23: but neither do they stir me to care much about the outcome of the story.  In the end
column24: it was an easy read with a vivid world
column25: but lacking (for me) much character-driven interest.  So I'm on the fence about whether I like it or not.  But who says I have to pick a side?"

column7: tics

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants\"A Novel
column7: Written By Sara GruenBook Review by Jay GilbertsonWho
column9: doesn't like the circus? If you answered \"yes
column10: \" then this book is for you. If you answered \"no\" then this book is for you too. There is something for everyone in this tremendously well-researched novel of schizophrenic madmen
column11: a possible murderer in pink sequins and a towering heroine who happens to be addicted to lemonade. What could be more fun?A depression-era circus can be the best place to be if you're Jacob Jankowski and you just buried your parents
column12: found out they mortgaged everything they owned to send you off to veterinary college and ultimately you had nothing left to lose.Some of the central themes of this page-turner are to follow your instincts
column13: stay true to what you believe in and try to survive no matter what. It's the what part that kept me flying through the book. The story shifts back and forth from Jacob at ninety (or ninety-three--he's not sure) to his incredible life on the train with the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show On Earth--the circus! By incredible
column14: I mean that there is a constant fear-factor woven underneath every nuance
column15: every situation is rubbed raw in not ever being entirely sure of just what the future holds
column16: or even if Jacob has one. That dread is dolled out in buckets-full by the head honcho of Benzini Brothers--Uncle Al--who can have you \"red-lighted\" (tossed off the train) for any number of indiscretions
column17: or simply to lesson the load. The incredible part is that
column19: Jacob not only manages to become the circus veterinarian
column22: one elephant (Rosie) and eleven horses. Who could ask for more
column24: that's who.Then there are the animals. A team of \"Liberty\" horses
column29: and Rosie--the elephant--the Polish elephant no less. The elephant that
column30: like all elephants
column31: drinks far more water than anyone could ever imagine carrying
column32: which is one of many parables in this fast-paced tale.Did I mention the train? Benzini Brothers traveled exclusively by steam-train. The train becomes a powerful force that literally grabs up entire
column33: failing circuses in its path and absorbs them like the little fish being eaten by the bigger one.Think shark.Uncle Al is a \"take no prisoners\" kind of fellow
column34: unless he can get you for a song. Then he owns your soul.The secondary story line
column35: that of old Jacob looking back on his days with the circus
column36: added a depth to this novel rarely seen in most modern literature. He may not know his exact age
column37: but there is a spark of life in him not quite ready to waste away in the nursing home that has become his prison. Then a circus comes to town and begins to set up shop right next door to the nursing home. It's an opportunity that Jacob simply can't resist.You won't believe what happens next..."
column39: "summary": "Oh My Gosh---Finally---A Happy Ending/Begining..."

column6: "reviewText": "When his parents are killed in a car accident
column7: 23-year-old Jacob Jankowski
column9: skips out on his veterinary school finals and hops a passing train. The train happens to be that of the Flying Squadron of the Benzi Brothers Greatest Show On Earth
column10: a middle-of-the-road depression era circus. Jacob earns a job as the circus' vet
column11: caring for a small menagerie of animals.The story is told by a 90- or 93-year-old (he can't remember which) Jacob living in a nursing home many years later. And although this aspect adds depth to Jacob's character
column12: it dragged a little for me. However
column14: that of Jacob's adventure with the circus
column15: is full of energy. Parts of his romantic involvement with one of the circus performers felt a little predictable
column16: but most of the story was engrossing. Gruen's meticulous research shows throughout the book. The story is never bogged down in details
column17: but her vibrant writing brings the circus to life so well that at times I felt like I was watching a really good movie."

column6: "reviewText": "After reading the reviews of this book I knew I would not be disappointed. This is the first book I have read from this author and I found myself interested in the book from the first sentence.The main character (Jacob Jankowski) starts the story as a 90 (or is that 93?) year old man in a nursing home living out his life. He is unhappy and realizes that his kids and the world have forgotten him. He then thinks back to his early adult life when he was in school to become a veterinarian. He takes us back to those years of the Great Depression and the adventures he had while working for a small traveling circus.The book never lets you down and the characters that Jacob Jankowski meets will keep you interested. It is a book that
column7: in my opinion
column8: lays open the human experience. At times
column9: the book takes a romantic and even very sensual tone. At other times
column10: the cruelty of the Great Depression and the desperation of people who worked hoping for some type of income or food will remind you of the harsh life of those times.The book spends some time going back and forth from present day to the days when Jacob Jankowski was part of the circus. The ending surprised me and when I finished the book I was glad that I had the pleasure of reading such a great piece of fiction."

column6: "reviewText": "An interesting premise
column7: Water for Elephants: a melodrama that takes place in a traveling circus during the first half of the last century. Throw in forbidden love
column10: and a few other plot twists
column11: and you're assured a best-seller followed by a Hollywood movie with a topnotch cast.I went to the circus as a boy; I never wanted to run away with it
column12: but I enjoyed it; then again
column13: I never feared clowns.I've had Water for Elephants on my reading list for more than a year; it was highly recommended to me but it just kept getting pushed down on my reading list. Finally
column15: I opted to make reading it a priority.I won't say I didn't enjoy it
column16: but I can't say either that it's deserving of all the accolades it's received. Author Sara Gruen obviously had a passion for the circus
column17: as evidenced by the research that went into this piece and the period.Normally I enjoy melodramas--Victor Hugo's Laughing Man comes to mind. But Elephants
column18: for some reason I can't quite put my finger on
column19: just missed.Maybe it's just me. Some call Romeo and Juliet the greatest love story ever written. I happen to think it's the most overrated piece of literature ever penned. I mean
column21: Romeo falls instantly in love with Juliet the first time he ever lays eyes on her
column22: and only after they part does he realize he forgot to ask her for her name. Can true love be founded on such a shallow premise? No
column23: he's just reacting to hormones. It's young love
column24: which is not really love at all
column25: merely lust.At first I thought it was because Ms. Gruen wrote the piece from the perspective of a male protagonist
column26: and like a lot of cross-gender writing
column27: it somehow lacks a certain authenticity. But Jacob is a likeable enough young man
column29: he joins the circus to what we in the 21st century would say
column30: \"Find himself.\" He certainly is attracted to Marlena
column31: initially
column32: for all the reasons a 20-year-old young man would be: she looks great in her pink sequined riding costume.But it wears old after a while--we want to see a relationship grow between them. What the story reveals is that Marlena
column33: married
column34: suffers from Battered Woman Syndrome. Her husband is mentally unbalanced and jealous to the point of insanity. He accuses her of infidelity with Jacob even though nothing has happened--except in their own mercenary hearts.Well
column35: we were ready to impeach Jimmy Carter for admitting he'd lusted after women in his heart. Even the bible teaches that if your thoughts are impure
column36: if you're unfaithful in your mind
column37: you're just as guilty as if you'd committed the act. But nothing has happened between these two innocents except a shared kiss. But because her husband is such a beast we accept that it is okay and feel sympathetic toward Marlena since she is committed to make it work with her unbalanced husband because her parents previously told her
column38: when she wanted to come home after admitting to them the marriage had been a mistake
column39: that she had to lie in the bed she'd made.Yet I found neither Jacob nor Marlena very sympathetic; neither character was very memorable
column40: even if the writing was sharp
column41: crisp and authentic to the period. My sympathies lay with Rosie
column42: the poor elephant who suffered such abuse at the hands of Marlena's husband she
column43: the elephant that is
column44: eventually killed him.Now that I've had more than a week to think about Elephants
column45: to capture what seems to be an elusive reason for my indifference to this book
column46: it occurs to me that a lot of books these days are written in this fashion
column47: they expect the reader to connect with the character in their own way.I understand what that means and I don't disagree with it--until it's taken to an extreme and I'm presented with cardboard characters
column48: caricatures.I want to connect with characters
column49: not become them. I want to see how others respond to adversity. I can always later compare what I would've done
column50: how I would've thought
column51: were I in those circumstances.I guess
column53: that's what was missing for me in Elephants: I just couldn't connect with Jacob or Marlena.Or
column54: maybe at my age I just don't get young love anymore."

column6: "reviewText": "This is really a heart warming story. I especially loved the elderly Jacob. Working in Long Term Care
column7: I so could see some of my patients over the years in Jacob and perhaps even caught a glimpse of how patients over the years have seen me! The ending warmed the cockles of my heart and left me smiling for days (well all day b/c I just finished it last night
column8: but I can't see not smiling everytime I think about it). Definitely give this book  a chance. I waited when it was recommended to me b/c the Circus didn't really appeal to me
column9: but it really was interesting to read about Circus life in the Depression Era. Loved the surprise twist when the epilogue picks back up at the end of the book! Didn's see that coming
column10: but I guess that's the point. LOVED THIS BOOK!"
column12: "summary": "Water for Elephants = A Snuggie for your heart!!!!!!!!"

column6: "reviewText": "Water For Elephants tells the story of one man's life with the circus as the backdrop to all of his experiences.Jacob is a student studying to become a veterinarian when his parents are killed in an accident and he is left with no family
column7: no money  and he walks away from that life.  He ends up picking up some work with a traveling circus and his life takes a turn that he never anticipated.  He becomes a part of the circus family (as dysfunctional as can be..........but they put the fun in dysFUNctional!)Jacob recalls his life
column8: while he is over 90 years old and relegated to a nursing home. A nurse mentions that the circus is in town and everyone will have the opportunity to attend a show. As he sits at a dinner table with several other elderly folks
column9: one man looking to gain attention from the women makes the claim that he \"..used to carry the water for the elephants.\"  Jacob calls him a liar
column10: because Jacob knows the amount of water that an elephant consumes
column11: and those vast quantities could not be carried by one man.  When a nurse asks if Jacob worked in a circus he does not answer her
column12: and that is when his memories are brought to life.  As he waits for his outing
column13: the days pass and he relives the last 70+ years of his life in his mind.  The stories that are told about how the circus works
column14: the value that is placed on the money coming in
column15: the care or lack there of
column17: the living conditions on the trains for the circus workers...........all these things and more come alive in Jacob's tale.While it seems that the story starts a bit hesitantly
column18: soon the reader is caught up in the tale
column19: what happens to the different people
column20: the relationship between the \"stars\" and the workers
column21: many aspects of a traveling circus are revealed
column22: even in the treatment of the animals!This story is an interesting portrayal of life in a traveling circus
column23: and the ending is an unexpected one that takes you unaware.This is Sara Gruen's first novel and she is nominated for two Quill writing awards."
column25: "summary": "Circus life revealed through the memories of Jacob"

column6: "reviewText": "When I read a book
column7: I want to immerse myself in it.  I don't want jarring inconsistencies to remind me that it's fiction
column8: and not particularly well written fiction at that.  The speech of Jacob
column9: who supposedly is in the setting of 70 years ago
column10: is disturbingly nonauthentic.  People at that time didn't use the same phrases we use now and putting them in
column11: when you're picturing them in the dress and background of that time period is annoying and unnecessary.  This author needed a better editor.  It's not a 'best' book and the fact that the author is begging for votes makes you wonder about her integrity."

I couldn't help but feel for the elder Jacob who was lonely and felt like he was just a trinket on a shelf that someone comes once a week to dust off. But the younger Jacob
column9: I found myself rooting for him all through the story.The author has done a great job at incorporating the stories of the circus in to a story that seems so real. I was left with a connectedness to the characters and their struggles
column11: and their feelings for one another.If you ever have ever been to the circus
column12: and ever wondered what it would be like to work in the circus during the 1920's and 1930's when all the big circuses were traveling the United States
column13: then this is a book you will have to read. You will not be disappointed."

column6: "reviewText": "I have to admit that I wasn't initially excited to read this book. I kept hearing great things about it
column7: but I just had no interest in reading about a circus. Then I saw the movie preview... and knew I wanted to read the book before seeing the movie (I'm rarely able to finish a book if I see the movie first). So I started reading
column8: and had a hard time getting into it at first... I think this was mainly because I felt like I HAD to read the book... as if I was back in school! I eventually got past this and was able to get immersed into Water for Elephants.Usually
column9: I rate books by how I feel while reading them
column10: so my ratings are normally always subjective. In this case
column11: I felt I had to give this book 5 stars based on the fantastic writing and the amazingly rich and unique backdrop of the train circus! It is obvious that the author did her research on circus culture and depression-era American history. She really dug into the down and dirty details of circus life. In the discussion after the last chapter you learn that many things in the story are based on true stories or anecdotes of the circus. The Bezini Brothers train circus is easily like another character in the book
column13: like the characters themselves. I really liked how the story is told from Jacob's perspective as a spunky 93 year old man
column14: having flashbacks of his life 70 year earlier. The altering perspectives (from young to old) effectively grounded the story and added another layer to his character.At times
column15: this wasn't easy to read... It was sad to read about the indignities of being old
column16: and I felt like Gruen's depiction was honest and very real. Though most of all
column17: I had a really hard time reading some of the scenes with the animals. At one point I caught myself reading between my fingers
column18: as if I was trying to block the scene from view as if it was a movie. I tried skipping over one but I had to go back and read it because I felt like it was important to the development of the characters and the story. It was
column19: and they were. I just wish those scenes hadn't been seemingly timed to when I was getting ready to go to sleep.Seriously
column20: I'm so glad I finally picked up this book. I highly recommend it!"

I highly recommend reading this. Although there are some scenes entailing sexual content it's easily read over. Water for Elephants is a delightful

column6: "reviewText": "I got this book for a free read through my Amazon prime account
column7: not sure exactly what to expect but at times I like to read outside of my normal genres and take a walk on the wild side. I was not disappointed.  This is the story of a man who is looking back on his life and how his actions helped him become the man he became.  After the death of his parents he jumps a freight train only to discover it is a circus train.  He was one exam away from becoming a veterinarian at the time of his families death and his time with the circus not only helped form his view of the world but also his view of mankind and himself.  It was moving
column8: the characters were 3 dimensional and grew during the telling of this tale.  I couldn't put it down.  The ending was very unexpected and I found myself wondering when it was all said and done what happened next.  Although this was not in a genre I normally read I would highly recommend it.  I am an animal lover and his compassion for the beast that were used by the circus was very touching.  I found myself routing for the good guys and hating the bad guys and thinking to myself  I could so see myself doing that.  There are things that happen in everyone's life that shape them
column9: change them and help them become the people they are meant to be. This story will touch your heart and make think back over your own life with new perspective. I give it two thumbs up a must read for anyone who has ever loved and lost or who has wondered what if?  A truly great read."

column6: "reviewText": "Story OverviewJacob Jankowski is 90--or possibly 93. He's not really sure.\"When you're five
column7: you know your age down to the month. Even in your twenties you know how old you are. I'm twenty-three
column9: or maybe twenty-seven. But then in your thirties something strange starts to happen. It's a mere hiccup at first
column10: an instant of hesitation. How old are you? Oh
column12: but then you stop. You were going to say thirty-three
column13: but you're not. You're thirty-five. And then you're bothered
column14: because you wonder if this is the beginning of the end. It is
column16: but it's decades before you admit it.\"Jacob lives in a nursing home--a bit of a grumpy old man but he does OK overall. He likes to give the nurses a hard time every so often. He resents having to eat Jell-O and the other soft food they try to pass off in the dining room. But his mind is drifting a bit; sometimes he finds himself in vivid dreams--and wakes to find himself unsure of where he is and why he is there. And when a circus sets up shop near the nursing home
column17: Jacob's mind begins to wander more--back to when he was a young man of twenty-three. Back when he knew exactly how old he was. Back when his life lay before him like a blank canvas.He was studying to be a veterinarian. Unbeknownst to Jacob
column18: his parents had mortgaged themselves to the hilt to put him through vet school. The idea was for Jacob to return home and join his father in the family practice--E. Janokowski and Son
column19: Doctors of Veterinary Medicine. But on the brink of graduation
column20: Jacob is called out of class. His parents have been killed in a car accident.  He's alone in the world. He returns home to bury his parents and finds that his legacy--the vet practice--is gone. It is the Great Depression and like others
column21: his parents had fallen on hard times and there is nothing left--the bank claims it all.Although Jacob returns to school to sit for his final exam
column22: he walks out without completing it
column23: follows a road down to the train tracks
column24: and hops onto a passing train--a n action that changes everything. For this isn't an ordinary train--it is the Flying Squadron of the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth. Jacob has landed on a circus train.A less profitable and more shady circus than Ringling
column25: the Benzini Brothers circus is its own society--populated by two basic social castes: the Performers and the Working Men. They live their lives on the circus train--crisscrossing the country and setting up in various small towns around America. With his veterinary background
column26: Jacob soon finds himself in charge of the menagerie--the collection of animals that perform in the circus. From horses to tigers to monkeys
column27: Jacob cares for the animals with compassion and concern--doing the best he can in difficult circumstances. (After all
column28: when even the men don't get paid some days
column29: there isn't much money for animal food.)He is befriended by a married couple who perform in the circus. Marlena is the beautiful star who performs with the Liberty Horses. August--Marlena's tempermental husband--is the equestrian director and superintendent of animals (in other words
column30: Jacob's boss). Jacob is instantly smitten with Marlena but works hard to conceal his feelings--August has a dark temper that can flare unexpectedly. At first Jacob can control his attraction
column31: but when the circus takes on Rosie--an elephant--things become complicated.The fates of Jacob
column32: Rosie
column33: Marlena and August become forever intertwined--linked together by love
column34: hate
column35: jealousy and violence. How this story plays out forms the core of the book--taking a path that is full of twists
column36: turns and surprises.My ThoughtsSara Gruen does a brilliant job of creating a world that I've never read about before--the world of a traveling circus train in Depression-era America. What a colorful and fascinating setting this was. Gruen does a wonderful job of giving you the feel for a life of a circus worker
column37: and the story is enhanced by the black-and-white photos of actual circus performers from the era. You feel like you're looking at photos of the actual characters that populate the book. In the Author's Note and the accompanying interview
column38: Ms. Gruen talks about her inspiration and research for the book. There are a million little details that give this book such an authentic feel. She really did her homework and it shows. From the words used by the characters to the descriptions of the logistics of the circus to the types of men and women who made their home in what was essentially a traveling
column39: self-contained community
column40: I felt like I was really there on the circus train.Although the heart of the book is what happens to Jacob when he joins the circus
column41: the book alternates between the elderly Jacob in the nursing home and young Jacob in the circus. I thought this juxtasposition worked well (except for the very end--I personally didn't care for the final choice that Gruen made for the elderly Jacob). When the circus comes to town and triggers Jacob's memories
column42: his story unfolds in a natural way--with the reader getting more and more drawn in to Jacob's story as it unfolds in the book and in his memories.In addition
column43: Gruen establishes a framing device in the prologue that influences the reader from the very start of the novel. I found this particular choice extremely effective--and I loved how she pulled it off and tied it together at the end. I love when an author plays with her readers a little bit
column44: and Gruen did a great job in this aspect.If you're looking for a movie to go with the book
column45: I must recommend Dumbo. I kept picturing scenes from that movie as I read the book
column46: and I could completely imagine this story being told in a similar way.My Final RecommendationI definitely see why this book was a bestseller. It offers something for everyone--a unique setting
column47: a bit of history
column49: animals
column50: an examination in what it means to grow old. This book effortlessly fits all of this in without seeming forced or strained. And on top of that
column51: it is just a good story that makes you want to find out what happens next. If you haven't read it already
column52: I think it is definitely worth a read. If I was attending the Benzini Brothers circus
column53: I would be standing up and yelling \"Encore! Encore!\""
column55: "summary": "Unique Setting + Good Writing = Fascinating Tale of Depression-Era Circus Train Life"

column6: "reviewText": "(Review originally posted at GoneWithTheWords.com)The book begins with ninety year old Jacob remembering a very intense and disturbing event from his time with the circus that will leave you wanting to find out how it got to that point. The chapters then alternate between old Jacob and his very depressed state at the Assisted Living Facility and him remembering his journey with the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth. The circumstances on how he came to join the circus as the show Veterinarian were very sad. He went from being a young man about to graduate from Cornell
column7: his whole future ahead of him and the possibility of FINALLY losing his virginity
column8: to having no one and nowhere to go.Once on the show
column10: the show's equestrian director and superintendent of animals. August is one very questionable character. He can be the most charming man around and moments later he can turn into the most terrifying creature you've ever encountered. He also meets Marlena
column12: and falls in love with her on the spot. At a later point
column13: the show aquires an elephant named Rosie who is thought to be stupid because she won't learn to do anything the trainers try to make her do. Rosie plays a huge part in this story
column14: and she gave me the biggest surprise in this book. This story also takes you on an eye opening journey through the sad conditions circus employees and animals were under in 1931.Water for Elephants was a completely different read for me. It was Adult

column17: but I am so glad I did because it was sooo much more than that! It made me laugh
column18: cry and gasp in astonishment sometimes. It was a huge plus knowing this will be a movie (coming out in April) starring Robert Pattinson and Reese Witherspoon as the main characters. I just pictured both of them the whole time! :D"

column7: the workers are mistreated

column6: "reviewText": "I loved it! Her characters were impressive and her descriptive narrative provides a vivid setting. Both Jacob's young life as a student and a vet for a traveling circus and

column6: "reviewText": "Gruen's latest is a page turner from start to finish. Jacob Jankowski tells his story both in the form of memories while in a nursing home
column7: and as the real time experiences of a 23-year old failed veterinary student in the midst of the Depression. Failing his exams
column8: Jacob flees home and hooks up with a circus; he survives in this brutal world only because he has some skill with animals. Gruen paints a marvelous
column9: completely believable portrait of a circus of the thirties
column10: where the ruthless Uncle Al rules with the power of life and death. He deviates from planned appearances only to pick up the pieces of other failed circuses. Once someone ceases to be of use to the show
column11: or if the money doesn't roll in as planned
column12: they're gone--sometimes forever. It's a harsh world
column13: but apparently historically accurate. And the old black and white photos at the beginning of each chapter are fascinating! Gruen's meticulous research makes the book--the plot line is a bit predictable and the ending a fantasy. But this is a great summer or airplane read--engrossing but not too heavy. Highly recommended."

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants was one of those books that was difficult to put down.  The prose flowed very smoothly. The subject of the circus world during the depression was well researched and make accessible to the reader.  It could be read on many levels
column7: but even a surface level was satisfying.My only problem
column9: was that the action was in places not very realistic.  This may be a bit picky
column10: but after suffering from a concussion
column11: nobody is ready to climb on top of a moving train and hop between cars
column12: no matter how pumped they are with adrenaline.  Such lapses in credibility hurt an otherwise wonderful novel."

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is an immensely entertaining
column7: well researched novel.  It's easy to see why this book is so popular.  That said; there are a few short comings
column9: some more substantial.The research about depression era circus' (not that I profess to be an expert) is excellent and makes a fascinating backdrop to the story.  While the author makes great use of her research
column12: is too contemporary to sound authentic.  While this is a fault to some extent
column13: it isn't one that will bother most readers.  In fact
column14: it makes the novel more readable
column15: likely contributing to it's success.  Fans of Faulkner and Steinbeck
column17: may beg to differ.I'm not sure why the author chose to make the novel's principal villain Jewish and allegedly Paranoid Schizophrenic.  The fact that he is Jewish is irrelevant to the plot (aside from the fact that it apparently makes his wife's family more likely to disown her) and his behaviour
column19: isn't consistent with Schizophrenia at all.  These may seem like minor points
column20: but they bothered me a little because they play into stereo types and were completely unnecessary.The romance that develops between Jacob and Marlena is predictable and uninspired.  The murder during the stampede is a little too contrived and highly improbable
column21: and the final chapter is a little too sentimental for my tastes.  But despite these grievances
column22: I was won over.The first half of the novel is definitely stronger than the second half.  Gruen's writing style is accessible
column24: and often very funny.  Jacob as an old man is cantankerous and vulnerable
column25: and his frustration with growing old is truly heartbreaking.  These `present day' chapters are arguably the strongest in the novel.  While the love story is admittedly unremarkable
column26: it was fascinating to read about life in the circus.  Greun weaves a series of amusing and presumably real (at least according to circus lore) anacdotes into the story.All in all
column27: it isn't hard to see why this novel is a bestseller.  True
column28: the love story is a little flat
column30: the novel is hard not to like.  Water for Elephants isn't a literary masterpiece
column31: but it's enormously entertaining.  If you are willing to overlook a few faults
column32: it is well worth reading."
column33: "overall": 4.0

column35: but enormously entertaining"

column6: "reviewText": "This is the incredible story of a man who was forced to say good-bye to the life he knew and expected to have to take a chance on something wild and unpredictable.  This is a story that lets you see the real person that this man becomes- with imperfections and all.  The author does an incredible job of telling the story about this man with a man's voice and perspectives.  The author is a woman and if you didn't notice that- you wouldn't be able to guess that from reading the story.  It is surprising how well she is able to get into the mind of a man.  One thing about this story that I truly loved was that it was told from a \"real time\" perspective and a future perspective.  We get to see what happens to this man after his long journey.  Plus
column7: we see that that journey never actually ends.  I can't say enough about this book.  It was a pleasure to read each and every word on each and every page.  I give it the highest review."
column9: "summary": "Incredible story of a lifetime on many levels"

column6: "reviewText": "My good mate John down at Matilda's book store  in Mount Waverley ordered this book in for me and it would have to be my favourite novel so far this year.The reader is introduced to 90 something year old Jacob who is a resident in an Old Folk's Home. Jacob talks about his past beginning with not completing his Vet Exams and finding himself in a travelling cirus during the Depression Era in America. Beneath the tinsel and cotton candy you find that the circus consists of hard men who never thought twice about throwing anybody from a  moving train.There is brutality and violence in this book and also the search for dignity in this cold tough world. Naturally 5 stars for this book."

I will never forget Jacob!"

column6: "reviewText": "I'm not going to outline the story

column9: the flaws.  It really doesn't take long to figure out where the story is going.  You can see it coming a mile away.  Second

column11: but she needs a little more practice.  Jacob seemed like a mama's boy
column12: but I don't think that was her intention

column14: it's safe to read.  The trains

column6: "reviewText": "I enjoyed this book so much

column6: "reviewText": "Have you ever asked yourself these questions? \"What is a life worth? How do you judge if someone is worth saving? What does it mean to be human? What distinguishes an animal from a human being?\" Hidden beneath this easy-to-read though dark coming-of-age romance is a theme that prompts the reader to ask the above questions. The answer come through the reminiscing of protagonist Jacob Jankowski--a man at the end of his fascinating life. The story begins with the circus rolling into town
column7: triggering a flood of Jankowski's memories
column12: regret & guilt. Sara Gruen brings the quaint circus existence of the mid 20th century to life through meticulous research and wonderful storytelling. Anyone who ever dreamed of running away to the big top or just dreamed of running away should read this book."

column6: "reviewText": "This novel is riveting from start to finish. What really surprised me is how well written it is. Water For Elephants is a great book for your book club or for a quiet night reading in bed."

column6: "reviewText": "What a wonderful story of a rag-tag bunch of people and animals

column9: August.  Of course he falls in love with her
column10: but the husband is a force to be reckoned with.  There is also Walter (Kinko)the clown
column13: and of course Rosie the Elephant.  The ending is extremely satisfying.  This book is well-researched and authentic.  I loved it!"

column6: "reviewText": "A family disaster sends a first generation Polish-American almost-veterinarian down an alternate
column7: precarious path; one filled with
column13: and an intriguing woman names Marlena. After the teaser of a prologue
column14: during which a murder takes place
column15: the story shifts to real-time in the life of ninety or ninety-three year old nursing home resident Jacob Jakowski
column16: as he realizes that a circus has rolled up mere blocks away. He is resigned to suffering through several standard days of monotony - wakefulness alternating with bouts of night-time and inadvertent
column17: memory-filled dozing as he anticipates viewing the upcoming circus performance. Although his brain founders
column18: his wit and wisdom-filled thoughts and words are spot on: of memory \"You start to forget words: they're on the tip of your tongue
column22: \"You want to drug me. You want to turn me into a Jell-O eating sheep
column24: \"I'm so used to being scolded and herded and managed and handled that I'm no longer sure how to react when someone treats me like a real person
column25: \" and after explaining his inability to keep track of his grandchildren and great-grandchildren
column26: \"My brain is like a universe whose gases get thinner and thinner at the edges.\" The story of his circus-related escapades is equally good. Although the ending seems more contrived than likely and the plot contains a fair amount of sexual situations
column28: its uniqueness as well as several fact-based plot parts overshadow its few faults. Good books with similar themes: Life of Pi by Yann Martel
column29: The True History of the Elephant Man by Peter Ford and Michael Howells
column30: and All Creatures Great and Small by James Herriot."

column6: "reviewText": "Well I think the sign of a good book is when you put it down and you are still thinking about the characters or the storyline because you can't get them out of your head.  That was definitely true of this book!I had heard and read a lot about Water for Elephants which actually put me off reading it as It meant my expectations were sky high and I wasn't sure if the book would be able to live up to them.  But let me tell you that it certainly did.I was a little apprehensive about how it started
column7: with Jacob in his golden years reflecting on his youth
column8: but in the end I found this was actually one of the things I enjoyed about how the book was written.  Like Jacob
column9: I longed for the times when his mind slipped back to his younger years when his body was whole and his mind sharp
column10: when his passions ran high and his life was full of adventure.  I could relate to his frustration with his age
column11: mental status and physically limitations.The story of his life was emotional
column12: and felt very real.  The ending was surprisingly satisfying for the reader and Jacob
column13: possibly because Jacob received what we all hope for at the end of a long life.  I'm not going to say anymore than that
column14: as i dont want to give anything away so if you want to know more you will have to read it yourself.  I hope you enjoy this book as much as I did."
column17: went to sleep thinking about the characters"

column6: "reviewText": "This is a good book about the circus (a comment I never thought I would ever make).  Jacob's story is heartbreakingly sympathetic.  Ms. Gruen's mastery of the circus vocabulary really sets the stage for the plotline.  A remarkable amount of reseach went into writing circus lore.  This is no Barnum and Bailey's Greatest Show on Earth.  This is a downtrodden
column7: edging ever closer to disaster circus run by the same type of people.  I must admit I had to skip anything that resembled animal cruelty (although I am sure it is factual).  My inability to deal with this led to my giving the book only 4 stars.  A reflection on the reviewer more than on the book."

column6: "reviewText": "It took me a long
column7: long time to get into this book.  I kept picking it up
column8: reading a few pages and then putting it down again.  It wasn't terrible
column9: but it didn't really grab me until well after the 100 page mark.  Nevertheless
column10: I did enjoy it and I'm glad I stuck with it.The book jumps backwards and forwards in time from Jacob's life as a vet in a 1930s circus to his life today as a 93 year old in an old folk's home.  Not much happens in the present day chapters and for a while I wondered what they were adding to the book
column11: but the pay off at the end is very satisfying.  While I don't know a lot about circuses in the depression era
column12: my impression was that the book is well researched and certainly it brings that world very vividly to life.  The book is peppered with sepia toned photographs from that era which is a clever touch.Overall a good book and one that is worth sticking with.  I was caught up in the central romance and I very much enjoyed the character that is the elephant

column6: "reviewText": "This was a delightful summer read. Everything about this book was good. You could really identify and feel passionate (good or bad) about the characters
column7: including the animals. All the loose ends are wrapped up. It makes me feel nostalgic and she has a way of transporting you back in time without being too wordy. The book is well written and entertaining. This was pretty  much the best book I read all summer. I even cried a little at the end. :) I really hope they make this book into a movie. It would be such a great movie if it was done correctley. Everyone should read this book."

column6: "reviewText": "I fell in love with Jacob Jankowski even if he is 90.... or 93!I ordered this book through my online bookclub \"Audible\" and am so glad I did.The cover of the book interested me and I had almost bought the book to read but thought.... naw I am really not into the whole circus thing. Besides
column7: I am more of a Non-Fiction kinda gal lately.Then a few days later this book was listed on Audible  as one of their bestsellers so I gave it a try and immediately fell in love with the narration of old man Jacob.  The story drew me in and I couldn't stop listening to it... even after we had all gone to bed I was up past 2am last night listening to it trying to control my laughter at the really laugh out loud parts to keep from waking my husband.Now to me that is a really great read so I thought I would pass along a little note saying how much I enjoyed \"Water for Elephants: A Novel\" and to say thanks to Sara Gruen for writing it!I enjoyed the Awesome Narration also by David LeDoux and John Randolph Jones that really added to the enjoyment of this novel!!!"

column6: "reviewText": "This book was amazing. The pace is almost like the circus train itself: it starts chugging forward slowly and then before you know it
column7: you're flying so fast you can barely keep your balance! Gruen's writing is so evocative -- you feel like you are on that train and in those tents. You taste the food
column10: feel the animals and the movement of the train. It's amazing that she could write so vividly about an era in history with which she had no prior knowledge before writing the book.The only thing I didn't like about it were the scenes involving animal cruelty. I knew they would be there
column12: but it was still difficult. However
column13: I give Gruen credit for not making them gratuitous. They were important to developing the story line and the characters.All in all

Yes it was painfully sad and I was angered when the abuse was occurring but still I read on. I must say this book made a big impression upon me as far as a story of adventure

column17: keep it in your library to reread in the years to come."

column6: "reviewText": "I read this book at the recommendation of a client...I loved it!  I read this book quite some time ago about two years ago and still think about some of the characters.  While reading this book

I  so enjoyed this book and I would be disappointed if the characters were not portrayed as beautifully on the big screen as I have them in my mind.  I would highly recommend this book to anyone looking for a beautifully written story that is sure to stay with you long after the final page."

column6: "reviewText": "It appears as though I'm in the minority once again.  All of us are entitled to our own thoughts and opinions but for the life of me I can't understand the number of 5 star ratings given to this book.  I'm not even sure I feel good about giving it a two.I wanted to like the book.  Really.  Who doesn't love a cute
column7: little
column8: old man telling his story of the good ol' days?  But as endearing as the concept was
column9: I couldn't get past the fact that I honestly didn't care that much about any of the characters.  Sorry but it had to be said.  The characters were flat
column10: the story was more fantasy than fiction and worst of all
column11: the whole thing felt quite familiar.  It was only later that it occured to me that this story was trying very hard to be Fried Green Tomatoes and/or Driving Miss Daisy; the difference is that I actually cared about the characters in those stories.  Frankly
column12: Water for Elephants read more like a screenplay than a great novel.For my friends
column13: I would suggest:If you want a story of reflection - The Green Mile
column15: Fried Green TomatoesIf you want a story about elephants - Hannah's DreamIf you want a story about a circus - well
column16: I've got no idea.  :)Having said all of that
column17: I would like to see the movie.  As stated before
column18: this read like a screenplay -- bare bones
column19: generally just waiting for someone to bring life to the characters and story."

column6: "reviewText": "The wife and I started reading this book after seeing the movie and were not disappointed. Kept our interest all the way through. Recommend to anyone over the age of 13 (some mature subject matter). Loved the characters especially Rosie. Bound to be a classic. Worth buying the audio book too!"
column7: "overall": 4.0

column6: "reviewText": "When I first started hearing the buzz about this book
column7: I politely declined offers  to \"buddy read\" and group discuss. I've never been attracted to all that goes on under the \"big top;\" and
column8: if I didn't want to attend a circus
column9: then why would I want to read about one? The book had the added downfall of an elephant as a main character and while I love animals
column10: I generally don't like to read about them. I thought this book had nothing to offer me . . . and I was very wrong.Reliving his young years right along with 90 year old Jacob Jankowski was a beautiful journey. I normally don't care for the sentimentality inherent in an old narrator looking back on his young days
column11: but I found Water for Elephants didn't use cheap tricks to manipulate the reader's feelings. Instead it had a slow build and satisfying finish - marks of a novel well written. As the old man (Jacob) tells his story
column12: I began to feel all the emotions that he did. By the end
column13: I was fully invested.Gruen brings to life - the Depression era geeks and freaks of the circus with generous but not overdone descriptions.  I became so engrossed in that world that it was jarring to come back to reality when I closed the book. The love triangle between man
column14: woman and beast was a beautiful thing and the ending for me came far too soon.I highly recommend Water for Elephants for 16+ and for anyone who enjoys a beautiful love story and being transported to a different day and age."

column6: "reviewText": "I really liked reading about the history of the circus. I loved the images and Sara Gruen knew how to vividly describe something. It's definitely worth reading."

column6: "reviewText": "I loved this book.  It was sometimes hard to read

column10: it was so incredibly good.  One point that bothered me
column11: though.  WHY did the author NOT have Jacob turn back and look for Walter???  Just because the other men said he \"probably did not survive the night\" does not mean he didn't.  At very least Jacob SHOULD have gone back and found out for sure
column12: especially since Walter had done a lot of good for him.  That was the only part of the book I felt let down by

column6: "reviewText": "I dont need to go into too much detail

column8: and it was nice read that kept my interest.  For some reason this book reminds me of Mitch Albom

column6: "reviewText": "I loved this book. It's about an lonely old man in a nursing home who's memories are sparked with the circus comes to town. He remembers back to his youth when he left veterinary school because of his parent's tragic deaths and joined the traveling circus. He details his unique experiences in the traveling show and of all the colorful people he became friends and enemies with. As mentioned in the title
column7: there is an elephant
column8: but the story is really about a young man's experiences as he struggles and learns his place in the hierarchy of circus and in life. Highly recommended!"

column6: "reviewText": "I found this book interesting because of the research Ms. Gruen obviously did on train circuses and depression-era life.  I also thought her passages detailing the life of Jake as an old man were the best written things in the book.  Since Ms. Gruen is a woman who appears (from her author's photo) to be barely middle-aged
column7: I have to assume that some research went into finding out about the lives of elderly men as well
column8: because she writes these passages with a clear and utterly believable voice that truly resonates.Unfortunately nothing else in the book resonates nearly as much
column9: and there's a lot lacking here.  The young version of Jake never takes off as a character
column10: nor does his entirely manufactured love story with a circus bareback rider.  We know from the moment he sees Marlena that she'll obviously be his love interest
column11: but their relationship never actually develops before they're suddenly declaring love for one another and hitting the sack.Ms. Gruen also fails in her execution of believable villains.  Her two main villains are August
column12: a brutal horse trainer who abuses or neglects all of the animals
column15: but their villainy never really jumps off the page.  For some reason
column16: she chose to make her main antagonist (August) Jewish.  I still don't understand the reasoning behind that
column17: nor do I understand her choice to call him a paranoid schizophrenic as well.  Oh and for good measure
column18: he's also a wife beater.  He's simply too many things rolled into one.  Perhaps if she'd concentrated on one aspect of his brutality
column19: she could have made him more believable.  And unfortunately
column20: since his religion really has nothing else to do with him as a character
column21: it's hard not to simply label Ms. Gruen as anti-semitic.  Perhaps if she'd actually used the \"show
column22: don't tell\" philosophy and let us SEE what Uncle Al was doing instead of just hearing about everything second hand from other characters
column23: he wouldn't have seemed so two-dimensional.  As it is
column24: I never bought these guys as the towering pillars of pure evil they were obviously supposed to be.I also never bought Jake
column25: at least not as a young man.  One minute he's making a vow to himself that he'll stay with the animals so they won't be hurt
column26: because that's what his dead father would want him to do.  Yet
column27: he stands by not once but TWICE and allows August to savagely beat an elephant with a hook.  It's hard to respect a character like that.  Jake rarely takes any real action; he mostly just stands by while things happen TO him or happen *around* him.I also felt the book could have benefited from a diagram.  In books that take place on ships
column28: there's usually a sketch in the front of the book with all the parts labeled for readers to refer back to so they can understand the action.  I had a lot of trouble visualizing the train where  a good 40% of the crucial action takes place in this book
column29: and that was a major barrier to getting into the story.  Had there been a sketch of it up front with all the sections labeled
column30: those sections of the story would have been much easier to understand.Overall
column31: I am giving this book three stars because of the research
column32: the informative author's note at the end
column33: and the sections with Jake as an old man.  I also really got a kick out of the ending.  But on the whole
column34: I would recommend this as a library book or a used book store book -- definitely NOT one you pay full price for."
column35: "overall": 3.0

column6: "reviewText": "This book intrigued me because it is not something I'd normally be interested in reading. I was expecting to be \"moved\"--as so many reviewers had indicated. Instead
column7: I was only \"moved\" to flip the pages as quickly as possible to at least come to the surprise ending that was indicated in some reviews.The premise

column6: "reviewText": "\"Water for Elephants\"
column7: by Sara Gruen is a compelling read that is fast-paced and difficult to put down. At times the plot ran so quickly I found myself trying to search for a way to slow down the course of the story
column8: but to no avail. The quick pace
column10: does seem to fit and reaches a broader audience that seems to want rapid conclusion and catharsis. Reversions to the present time are a nice break from circus life and I believe are Gruen's most vivid and compelling depictions of the novel. Her illustration of life at the nursing home and perspective of the `patients' which Jacob catches a nurse stating when the correct political term is `residents' provides an accurate and refreshing look at assisted elderly homes. The circus lifestyle is portrayed truthfully
column11: but is often overshadowed by the dynamics and major plot-line concerned with the Romantic relationship and triangle of Jacob
column15: is an easy read with relatively simple themes and motifs to comprehend including: animal cruelty
column20: and older age/aging. It truly encapsulates a broad range of topics
column21: but the overlaying plot and issues are prevalent and riveting

column10: he is taken on as a circus vet.  The story is told by Jacob when he is 90 or 93 (he can't remember which) and is waiting for his family to come and take him to the cicus.  The book is interesting and creative

column6: "reviewText": "For the past few months
column7: I seem to have only been reading thought provoking books.  Some were illuminating
column9: some made me think about some of my most deeply held beliefs.  All in all - I am very glad I read these books

column11: I realized that it had been quite a while since I read a book mainly to find out what happens at the end.My dad recommended this book - and I'm glad he did.  It's a wonderful story.  We experience
column12: along with the main character Jacob
column13: two parts of his life.  We travel through the Great Depression with him after he runs away and joins the circus (!) and we also see his current life as a patient/resident of an assisted living center.  Both times of his life were interesting to me.  I know next to nothing about circuses - yet I could almost smell the sawdust and hear the music as I made my way through this tale.Gruen has filled her story with the colorful characters one would expect from a circus troupe.  Beautiful acrobats
column15: animals with personalities almost as big as their trainers (and sometimes bigger!).  The details are excellently woven in
column16: letting the reader see just enough without blocking one's imagination.  As the story builds towards the climax - I found myself doubting the ending I had been sure would take place.  Gruen creates just enough tension and suspense to keep the reader turning the pages at a brisk pace.I enjoyed
column18: the scenes of Jacob in the present day.  All circus aspects aside
column19: the book has some excellent insight into a man who feels as if he has outlived his life...without becoming a man who was finished with living.  His fears of losing his memories and mind
column20: the despair he feels at the sameness of each day
column21: and the appreciation he has for the few delights left in his day to day existence are beautifully crafted.  He may come across as a crotchety old man at times
column23: and a few characters whose eyes still see a man instead of an old man
column24: know that not to be true.\"Water for Elephants\" was a very enjoyable story.  It was an interesting and fun book - well researched and well-written.  While I didn't take many notes while reading
column25: it was not for lack of content
column26: but because I didn't want to miss a minute of the story."

column14: and those that had them did anything they could to keep them. Describing the desperate times
column16: and the pay cuts served to present a great representation of the time period.I loved hearing about the different circus acts
column17: though I know that was but a miniscule part of the story. The tiny facts and funniest little things kept my interest and had me smiling. This book is definitely dark and depressing at moments. At others
