column6: "reviewText": "I had this book on my to read list for some time
column7: when I saw that the movie was coming out soon I decided I better get to reading this.  I listened to this as an audio book and it was very well done; they have two readers one for Jacob in his twenties and one for Jacob in his nineties.  It was a good read and I enjoyed learning about the circus.Jacob is ninety three and living in a retirement home
column8: through his dreams and daydreams he relives a tumultuous time in his life in his twenties.  When Jacob is in his twenties he is getting ready to sit for his Veterinarian finals at Cornell University when he gets a call; his parents have been killed in a car accident.  Then when he gets home he finds out that the bank has seized his parents' house.  In a fit of grief and sorrow he abandons his exams and hops a train that just happens to be part of the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth.  Through a series of circumstances he ends up working for them as their vet; taking care of the exotic animals in their menagerie.  In the process of all of this he falls in love with a beautiful performer named Marlena who has a brutally viscous husband
column9: who also happens to be Jacob's boss.There were a number of things I liked about this book.  The story moves quickly and has a sense of mystery and doom about it as Jacob falls deeper into the seedy goings on in the circus and deeper in love with Marlena.  It is very engaging.It is clever how you see into Jacob's life in the present while he is in a nursing home.  These portions of the story really tug at your heart and give insight into an old man struggling to retain his sense of self in an environment where everything is sanitized and ordered.  These glimpses are bittersweet in contrast to the crazy life Jacob lived; obviously this man has lived and lived well and it is heartbreaking to watch him struggle with the descent into age that we are all faced with.The majority of the story is about Jacob's life in the circus.  Gruen doesn't shy away from the nitty gritty including sex
column11: language; as such this is definitely an adult read.  Issues such as animal cruelty
column13: and the Depression are woven throughout.  Making the story very believable and easy to relate to.All of the characters in this book are very human and engaging and have a lot of depth. Even the villainous characters (Al and August) have moments of graciousness and goodness.  While the main \"good\" characters do things that border on bad
column14: if only through neglect.The only thing that really bothered me with this book is that I thought Jacob made too many bad decisions and too many mistakes.  I understood that he was young and hot-headed
column15: but at the same time he is supposed to be very smart...and well...let's just say he doesn't spend much time thinking about his actions.  A lot of what happened he brought on himself and I think that this was inconsistent with the way he was presented as an upstanding citizen and character.The book ends well and should leave readers happy and smiling.  The story is expertly told and the look into the way a circus runs fascinating.  It would have been nice to have an afterward of Gruen talking about how accurately she represented the circus in this book.  Were all circuses like this?  Or was this one particularly bad?Overall this was a very engaging story
column17: and am happy that I read it.  The characters are fascinating
column18: the glimpses into both life in the circus and life in a nursing home intriguing as well.  I loved how the book was set up with us seeing the elder Jacob's memories/story through his eyes.  Definitely a book to check out if you are at all interested in circuses or people living during the Depression Era."
column20: "summary": "4.5 stars; entertaining look into Depression era circus"

column6: "reviewText": "One sign of a skilled novelist is the ability to write convincingly from the point of view of characters who share little in common with the author.  (I would liken this skill to that of a masterful actor capable of playing a wide range of movie roles.)In \"Water For Elephants\" Sara Gruen showcases this rare talent
column7: telling a Depression-era circus tale from the perspective of a veterinarian named Jacob Jankowski (both in his twenties and flashing back from his nineties) in a convincing and captivating manner.  The contrast between the innocent young Jacob's foray into the rough-and-tumble world of a traveling circus and the old Jacob's cynical ruminations on life in a nursing home creates a \"book end\" effect that makes his story feel more real and meaningful.Gruen has also infused her novel with enough historical details to bring the sights
column8: sounds and smells of the midway
column9: menagerie and big top to life
column10: without cramming in superfluous details that could have dragged on the story line.  The dialogue is sublime
column11: especially the banter between the working men who handle the behind-the-scenes grunt work.  Her characterization is strong as well: I was moved by the star-crossed romance between Jacob and Marlena
column12: repulsed by the evil of August and Uncle Al
column13: and captivated by the antics of Rosie the elephant.All in all
column15: most deserving of its long run on the best-seller list."

column6: "reviewText": "\"Water for Elephants\" is wonderful Depression-era circus history retold with a compelling story line. I was fascinated by this carefully researched
column7: well-written look at the circus as a community with its own cultural norms
column10: and social bonds.A little-bit love story
column12: the underlying message is that individuals can overcome adversity if they are brave enough
column14: to take their lives into their own hands.This is the story of Jacob Jankowski
column15: a Cornell vet student who loses everything in the Great Depression; parents
column17: incipient career. Almost by accident he becomes a circus veterinarian. After a long and successful life
column18: the elderly Jankowski escapes from a nursing home to once again join the Big Top.The author agiley shifts between Jacob's memories of circus life and his life in the nursing home. As Jacob's memories and present-day realities merge
column19: the line between truth and fiction blurs. Perhaps Mr. Jankowski really did toddle off in his walker to be reabsorbed into the circus world; perhaps he died dreaming in his wheelchair.This is a lovely book; well-worth reading if you are interested in early twentieth-century history and/or the aging process.Kim BurdickStanton

column6: "reviewText": "OK... this is the classic
column7: \"don't read a book by its cover\".The title of this book and the cover picture caused me to leave it sitting on my bookshelf for almost a year (it was a gift). I finally picked it up because I had nothing left to read... and I really
column8: really enjoyed it!93 year old Jacob is the narrator and he flashes back and forth from his current life
column10: to his past life as a member of a traveling circus during his early twenty's.There are two stories going on here: the story of his youth
column12: and the more subtle story of the passage of time and the process of aging on the human body
column14: and relations.The stories of Jacob's youth as a circus \"veterinarian\" and his relationships with the other performers were not only interesting as stories
column15: but historically educational and informational. It is all about life in the Circuses of the 1930's
column20: story of the aging process that I find haunting me still."
column22: "summary": "Don't read a book by it's cover!"

column6: "reviewText": "This book is written in two narratives: the past and the present. It is written with such elegance and grace
column7: that each voice is like a piece of silk weaving in and out like a slice of humanity screaming to be heard.Jacob Jankouwski tells this unbelievable tale from a rest home at ninety or is it 93? And his memories are so lush and tragic that the reader will be transformed into his past along with him.Jacob enters the `circus life' by no desire of his own
column8: but this world changes him beyond belief.  The reader will be changed
column10: and utterly awakened by this world within a world.  The caste system at The Benzini Brother's Most Spectacular Show on Earth reminded me of working on the cruise ships----the engineers
column12: and third country employees working below the ship (boiler room) and the showgirls
column14: and shop girls working and living above the ship--as if they were superior in some respect.Rosie
column16: becomes the voice for all animals
column17: whom deserve respect and caring for.  She also becomes the voice for old folks
column19: who for some reason are tossed to the side because of old bones
column22: but Rosie has not lost her memory as the reader will see.  And the abusers will pay for their sins as we all do.Sara Gruen has created brilliant
column24: people whom I fell in love with and cared deeply about.  For example
column27: who was so hard and incredulous on the outside
column28: but had a dog he adored like his own baby.  The characters are articulately developed
column29: and one will even feel empathy for the hateful August.\"Water for Elephants\" is a book about humanity:  how it can be dark and light at the same time
column30: how people can change
column31: how others do not
column32: how survival is connected to love
column33: and above all
column34: how giving water to elephants is like giving water to the world.I dreaded turning the last page
column35: exiting the circus and all of its peculiarities and delights.  This book will leave the reader thirsty for more and more and more.*** A must read for fiction freaks!"

column7: "reviewText": "Have you ever experienced an unexpected disaster
column8: something that leaves you completely alone? Water for Elephants tells the story of life after tragedy
column9: when Jacob Jankowski is accidentally thrust into a chaotic circus whirlwind. He discovers the truth about life on a circus for both the performers and workers but more importantly the circus animals. A veterinary major at Cornell university drop out
column10: Jacob needed a break from the world that had plummeted toward him at a thousand miles an hour. Leaving him with not a cent
column12: and no certain future.This 5 star book opened the eyes of many across the world to the condition of a circus life in the early 1900's
column13: and how this life could go spinning out of control at any given moment. Each page rich with love
column16: Sara Gruen creates a masterpiece of twists and turns aboard the `Flying Squadron' with the `Benzini Brothers most Spectacular Show on Earth'. This book shows the greed and hunger for money and wealth and the harsh conditions of the Great Depression from front to back. Her writing leaves you hanging on every word
column17: and her distinct characters introduced throughout the story never expose their comfortable selves among the dishonest businesses of the circus. Definitely a 5 star novel
column18: I recommend this book to both teenagers and adults as a MUST read book
column19: Water for Elephants truly makes a difference.-kd"

My sisters ranted and raved about this book when it first hit the scene in 2006 I believe and I just read it-- and it was worth the read.  The depth and substance of the book was what kept me interested and invested in the characters.*Taken from another reviewer because it's said so well and I believe the same thing of the book: \"Water for Elephants is a great book for a summer read.  It's obvious that the author did her research into the time period (post-Depression America)
column8: and the subject matter (traveling circuses).  According to the author's note at the end of the book
column9: many of the compelling anecdotes in the story were based upon real events
column10: culled from the diaries and personal histories of old-time circus performers.  As a result
column11: Water for Elephants is a novel that boasts the rare combination of being both entertaining and informative.\""

column6: "reviewText": "I'd been hearing a lot of rave reviews of this book in the writer's groups that I'm in (ALL rave reviews
column7: as a matter of fact) and when I heard that the movie was due out soon
column8: I purchased the e-book now so that I could compare the book to the movie. There are so many great things about this book
column9: when you put it all together
column10: it was just one of the best books I've ever read.The point of view for Water for Elephants is unique. Jacob
column12: comes to us first as a 90 (or is it 93?) year old man who is living in a seniors home. Most of the story is Jacob recalling his life with the circus
column13: with short trips back to his here-and-now. I felt that I came to know all of Jacob. From his beginning
column14: losing his parents in an accident
column15: to his experience with the circus and his true love
column16: to his last days feeling trapped in a body and mind that he wasn't free to control himself any longer.With the story being set in the 1930's and in the Depression
column17: the book was even more interesting to read about days in that era. At the end of the book
column18: the author describes all of her research that she's done for her book. It's obvious by how thoroughly and well written Water for Elephants is.I highly

column6: "reviewText": "Water For Elephants was just what I wanted in a book right now: an easy read
column7: fun
column9: with a unique setting. Sara Gruen's research into the life of long forgotten train circuses and America in the 1930s was obviously extensive and the way she used her knowledge in the writing of the book was loving and playful and made me want to learn more about it. There were a few things that I looked up
column10: curious to know if they were the author's invention or actual historical facts that she incorporated into her story. For example
column11: I had never heard of \"Jake Leg\" before and commend her for revealing in the context of her book parts of American history that most people must be unfamiliar with. The characters were well drawn and the fictional Circus she created was completely believable. I loved the photographs that accompanied each chapter which added to the believablity of her story. I would recommend this book to anyone looking to immerse themselves in a good old fashioned yarn filled with romance and even a little danger."

column6: "reviewText": "There were many good qualities in \"Water for Elephants\".It starts off with a very action-packed prologue.Then
column7: suddenly you're witnessing a confused
column8: aging old man who is being shuffled around in a nursing home- losing his memory and therefore also his mind.\"Water for Elephants\" then switches between the old man
column10: life versus the younger version of Jacob when he was in his early twenties- during probably the most important period of his life
column11: ever.Then you are brought back to the action-packed prologue (except this time when reading it
column12: you get the back story leading up to the event).In his 20s
column13: Jacob was a vet for traveling circus for three months.  Obviously traveling with the circus is going to make for some really interesting stories.There are many details throughout the book that I didn't think were nearly as bad as others have made them out to be in these other reviews on Amazon.-The sexual content really wasn't that explicit.  There were maybe two sex scenes and they really weren't that bad.  If you want explicit sex in the middle of a fiction story (without being considered erotic fiction) read John Irving's \"The World According to Garp\" and/or \"A Prayer for Owen Meany\" and/or \"The Fourth Hand\" and/or \"The 158-Pound Marriage\".  All very good books that have way more detailed sex scenes that may or may not make you squeamish.  \"Water for Elephants\" barely grazed the surface of reproductive organs and whatnot.  So
column15: don't be.-The animal cruelty also was not that bad.  Yes
column16: it is written that someone would walk off and you could hear the animal cry out
column17: but... other than that- it wasn't detracting from the entire story.  And not only that
column19: I'm sure things like that really happen on the road.  There are definitely people who are capable of doing such things.  If you watch any show on \"Animal Planet\" or watch any real animal documentaries on late night television
column20: you'll see that things are much worse.  So
column21: if you're leery of the cruelty content
column22: don't be.  It is also grazed over.There are many real elements- as far as I can tell- and whether or not the research was done before writing the novel
column23: I think the descriptions are pretty believable.The only characters that really stood out were Walter and (in the beginning) Camel.  Jacob was a very strong narrator
column24: but I didn't care for his burst of love for Marlena (a married performer).The back story behind Marlena and August's marriage was important
column25: but it was summed up in about two paragraphs.The story behind Uncle Al's creation of the circus was interesting
column26: but we barely meet Uncle Al.  And both August and Uncle Al seem to be bi-polar
column27: which was annoying and unnecessary.  It is okay for there to be \"normal\" performers.  I don't think it was needed to move the story along or to qualify their actions.Most of the characters are added as bodies
column28: but none have interesting or \"deep\" back stories.  To make it easier to remember their names and who they are (as the names are mentioned often)
column29: it would have been better for me to know more about these guys so that they really stick out in my mind as real people.There was nothing memorable about Camel by the end either- he lost his appeal about halfway through the book.Walter was interesting and probably my favorite character.Marlena was a bother.  I didn't get the whole tragedy of her marriage to August and felt that his temper was added in as only an excuse to make her want to be with Jacob.  The tangled love story wasn't even as interesting (to me) as the whole circus thing:  Redlighting and setting up the stage
column30: and canceled wages
column31: and the whole life of a circus performer.By the middle of the book
column32: people started to become \"missing\" and/or dead
column33: but I didn't care about those characters anyway- so
column34: it seemed like those events were added just to make \"Water for Elephants\" interesting as a whole.This is my first Sara Gruen book
column35: but it felt like \"Water for Elephants\" was a first novel for her too- though it was written well
column36: the plot kind of fell flat by the middle of the story.  It was entertaining enough to finish
column37: but I probably won't be recommending it.  I may try her again
column39: but... I won't be jumping to it."

column6: "reviewText": "Ninety-year old Jacob lives in a nursing home where he spends most days parked in the hallway
column7: waiting for Sundays when a visitor comes.  He's excited because a traveling circus has set up next door and he can't wait to go.  He flashes back to his youth during the Depression

column9: he fell in love with Marlena
column11: his boss was her brutish husband.I absolutely loved this book.  It contrasts the misery of being old and helpless with the non-stop action of life \"on the show

column13: too.  The pathetic circus Jacob joined was full of lively characters
column16: and Jacob was forced to grow from naive youth to courageous man.  There were many pages that reduced me to sobs
column17: especially those detailing the agonizing despair of some nursing home residents and some instances of animal cruelty at the circus.I would have given this book five stars

column19: and it was written entirely in the present tense which struck me as awkward.  The story itself is engaging

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants should not be missed! It is a beautifully written story with a lot of heart and soul.  The prologue will completely captivate you and you will be hooked from page one!The story begins with a 90 year old
column7: who also could be 93
column8: he doesn't actually remember how old he is
column9: named Jacob Jankowski. Jacob is your typical old man. He's seen too much in his life to give a crap what people say and think. From the first line Jacob spoke
column10: I knew I loved him. He was sarcastic and funny
column11: but also sad and lonely. His wife died a few years before
column12: and his children and grandchildren only visit him in the nursing home for a few hours on Sunday. All Jacob has left are his memories of working for a circus when he was 23 years old (Rob Pattinson played young Jacob in the movie and it was wonderful having to picture him as Jacob. It was a beautiful sight!).At 23
column13: Jacob is about to graduate veterinary school and go on to work for his father caring for animals. When his parents die in a car accident
column14: he learns that his parents left him with no money and the bank repossessed their home (it takes place during the depression
column15: and the Jankowski's were struggling along with everyone else). Jacob
column17: jumps unto a moving train and in this moment his life will change forever.Water for Elephants has an amazing cast of characters that all bring something to the story. Jacob meets the beautiful
column22: as well as many others that all shape Jacob's life one way or another. Even the animals play a huge role in his life!I think my favorite part of this story was the last few pages. Not because it was over
column23: but everything came together so beautifully. We last see Jacob as his 90 or 93 year old self
column24: and you will not be disappointed on how his life will turn out.Water for Elephants is a must read! I just hope the movie will do this amazing book justice!"

column6: "reviewText": "I've noticed that some have said they wanted to like this book due to the high praise others here have given it. I will try not to gush. But honestly
column7: this is one of THE best books I have EVER read.From the beginning to the magnificent and most satisfying end
column8: I was entirely delighted. Not every page was perfection I will admit but my annoyance was due to my own impatience about wanting to get back to a certain character rather than learning a bit more about another.It is quite clear from the moment you begin that the author did some seriously extensive research about the Depression era in general and circus life specifically.The way the author weaves the story between present day and older Jacob (at 90 or 93
column9: he can't quite remember) and the flashbacks to the past (when Jacob was in his 20's) are fantastic. She handles aging and its inherent frustrations quite well
column12: and intensely likable.I enjoyed this novel so much

column6: "reviewText": "In recent years
column7: publishers have put out a number of collections of early twentieth century circus photographs.  The photographs are intensely interesting
column9: brutality and absurdity underneath the surface glamour of the traveling circuses of that era.Gruen was inspired by the photographs to write this novel.  Gruen thoroughly researched her subject matter
column10: collecting scores of anecdotes that revealed the brutality and desperation of that world.  She weaved the anecdotes together with a love story worthy of a three-hanky weepie from the 1930s. The combination of grit and sweetness works only to a point
column11: but the inherently interesting nature of the subject matter managed to hold my interest to the end.To me
column13: Gruen never managed to transcend her source material.  The primary problem was the narrator's voice.  Although the book was sprinkled with circus-specific vocabularly of that era
column14: Gruen utterly fails to capture the rhythm or syntax of the time or milieu. Gruen's language felt inappropriately contemporary
column15: which undermined the overall credibility of the story.  The subject matter cried out for a writer with an ear for the street; I kept thinking about what Damon Runyon or Ring Lardner could have done with this material.The other major problem was that Gruen over-anthropomophized and over-romanticized the animals in the story.  Gruen could have honored the animals' intelligence -- and decried the brutality of their treatment -- without veering into fantasy.In the end
column16: while I wasn't sorry I read the book
column17: I would have preferred to read a non-fiction account of life in the Depression-era circus from a first hand source rather than this watered down trifle."

Also the passages in which Jacob is 90 or 93 years old were beautifully written and very believable.The not-so-good:  The author often devoted long passages to the mundane and then just jumped over the parts of the story that a reader wants to spend time on (such as key dialogue between the main characters which would provide the reader with their back stories and develop a genuine love story)...which brings me to:The bad:  the characters are
column9: one-dimensional and the character dynamics and relationships are unrealized and unbelievable.  At its core

column6: "reviewText": "I loved this book set during the depression in a third rate circus
column7: The Benizini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth.  The book is told through the eyes of 90 (or 93) year old Jacob Jankowski

column17: as it brought the whole story full circle. I really loved this book."

column6: "reviewText": "Alternating between times

column8: 90-something year old Jacob recalled his life in the circus.Life pretty much changed overnight for Jacob Jankowski.  Jacob dropped out of veterinary school.  He just had to take the last test before graduating.  However

I wanted to like the book because my friends were telling me how great it was.  I just couldn't get into it.  After about 100 pages and days later

column6: "reviewText": "My daughter has been asking me to read this book for years.  I resisted because I read the synopsis and thought \"a story about a circus in the era of the great depression? Nah.\"  I finally downloaded it and gave it a go and couldn't put the book down.  Seriously this is one of the best books I've read in years!  I felt like I was right there.  The narrative shifts back and forth between old Jacob and young Jacob seamlessly.  I strongly regret waiting so long to read this book.  And for you Nook/Kindle lovers
column7: this book is only $5 to download.  I would have paid full price.  It is a haunting story and often had me thinking of my own aging.  What will it feel like to be inside a body that is old and doesn't function like it used to
column8: yet the mind still feels young?  I can't wait for the movie to come out in April."

column6: "reviewText": "Sara Gruen spent months researching circuses that traveled by trains and they paid off in the realistic Water for Elephants that she turned into fiction. The novel begins with main character Jacob Jankowski
column7: a 93-year-old man in a nursing home
column8: when the circus comes to town. This begins his flashback of his time with the Benzini Brother's Most Spectacular Show on Earth in the summer of 1931.While it focuses on the cirucs
column9: the novel weaves back and forth between a 23-year-old Jacob on the circus and present-day Jacob with his nursing home struggles.Jacob had never intended to end up on the circus
column10: but once he does he is caught in a whirlwind of romance and drama. He has to learn the ropes of a struggling circus that can't always afford to pay its employees. Each character has his/her own unique qualities that make each seem as real and relatable as the next. Even the circus's animals take on personalities that make them seem real.After the great reviews I wanted to give it a shot and I had trouble putting it down. The novel has a little something for every kind of reader as it falls into multiple genres of mystery
column11: romance and adventure. Gruen continuously surprised me through the last page. Each page was as compelling as the next. I would absolutely recommend this novel to everyone."

column6: "reviewText": "As a former circus performer
column7: I really should have read Sara Gruen's Water for Elephants when it came out in 2006. As it turns out
column8: I just finished it and quite simply
column9: it's fantastic. Set in both present time and the 1920's
column10: it tells the tale of young Jacob Jankowski's circus days: how he stumbled upon the spectacle
column12: and how he found true love. Told through flashbacks of himself at ninety...or ninety three
column14: you see how the circus life effected him and what became of him after his years under the big top.After leaving Cornell
column15: Jacob made his way onto the Benzini Brothers most Spectacular Show on Earth
column16: a not as good as Ringling Brothers
column17: but still decent traveling circus. He became the show's veterinarian
column24: he meets a dazzling array of characters including Walter
column27: the show's ringmaster and owner; August
column28: the moody and arrogant animal keeper; and his wife Marlena
column29: the lovely horse tamer and elephant rider that Jacob falls for.Accompanied by archived photos from the Ringling Circus Museum
column30: the book accurately portrays the life of a traveling circus member
column31: riding the train daily going from city to city
column32: hoping the town is looking for an afternoon of entertainment. In a time when entertainment was scarce
column33: the circus really was a legendary spectacle. Money was tight and the sleeping quarters were tighter. The performers were treated like Gods
column34: but the workers were seen as slaves. But when you were living cent by cent
column35: it was a job--and a good job at that.As a reader
column36: you're wrapped up my Jacob's tale
column37: following him through his four month stay with the Benzini Brothers. You cheer him on and fear for his life all at the same time. You become attached
column38: friends. And the ending leaves you satisfied
column39: fulfilled and content.Personally
column40: I was disappointed that they didn't concentrate more on the acts
column41: however that's a small complaint from an otherwise fantastic read. Even for those who have no interest or knowledge of the circus lifestyle will get something out of it. Because at one time we've all seen the show. We've all seen the clowns
column42: the elephants
column43: and the acrobats. We've all eaten the pop corn and cotton candy sold from the striped tents. And
column44: really
column45: at some point
column46: we've all wanted to run away and join the circus."

I just didn't really like it - I kept expecting it to get better and it didn't. It was a complete and utter failure."

The rest of the story is told by the 93-year-old Jacob and the author did a superb job of portraying the world from the point of view of someone who's in a care center and isn't always allowed to make his own choices. The switches back and forth between the two Jacobs were flawless and really help make the story. The ending was perfect

column6: "reviewText": "Water for ElephantsSara GruenA 90-year-old man--or is he 93?--narrates the story of his one summer as a veterinarian with the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth during the summer of 1931 in Depression-era America.  Jacob Jankowski resides in an assisted living home with other elderly people
column7: many of whom require more medical attention than he.  He is quite mentally astute for his age
column9: most of the people in charge of the facility treat him as mentally incompetent
column12: who treats him and the rest of the patients/residents with the loving care
column14: and respect they deserve as human beings.  But she is moving away and will be quitting the facility
column15: which in the end leads to Jacob's decision to continue his life--what little he may have left--in dignity.There is a circus that has come to town.  It is so close to the facility that the big tent and other goings on can be observed from the window.  All of the old people reminisce about their experiences in their youth going to the circus.  One old man and a newcomer to the home
column17: who is considerably younger than Jacob
column18: brags about having worked in a circus
column19: carrying \"water for elephants.\"  Jacob becomes upset because he knows Mr. McGuinty is lying to attract the attention of the other residents; and the memories of the truth of his past life are triggered.Flashback to young Jacob Jankowski
column20: a veterinary student at Cornell University in his last year!  Just before he is scheduled to take his final exams
column21: after which he will graduate and receive his degree
column22: both his parents are killed in an automobile accident.  After their burial and after learning the truth of his financial situation
column23: Jacob is unable to focus.  He leaves the exam room and leaves Cornell.  Distraught
column24: he leaves with only the clothes on his back and no money in his pocket.Because of the Depression
column25: people were unable to pay for his father's services; and his father
column27: worked for people even though they could not pay him
column28: taking whatever they could give him--eggs
column30: whatever they had.  Therefore
column31: his parents had nothing to leave their son but debts.  To pay his tuition
column32: the house had been mortgaged.So not being able to focus
column33: he leaves without ever putting pen to paper.  Without aim or destination
column34: he walks and soon finds himself beside the railroad tracks
column35: when along comes a train.  Like a hobo
column36: he hops the train with no idea where he is going.  He soon learns this is a circus train and is not tossed off it because the Benzini Brothers
column37: whose circus it is
column38: discover he is a veterinarian; and his services are badly needed.Working as a veterinarian that summer leads to all kinds of experiences
column39: tantamount among them which are falling in love
column40: getting married
column41: and eventually working with the circus's one elephant.After his summer with the Benzini Brothers
column42: he is hired by Ringling Brothers.  He
column43: along with his wife and his growing family
column44: spends seven years as a circus veterinarian.  He then becomes the veterinarian for the Brookfield Zoo in Chicago.  His seven years experience with exotic animals and his degree
column45: in addition to bringing an elephant with him
column46: insures him the job when the former vet suddenly dies.Jacob
column47: ninety years old--or is he 93? he asks himself
column48: recognizing that his old age has caused some memory loss--struggles to hold onto his humanity and his dignity as long as he can.  It is he who in his reminiscences about his circus life
column49: his friendships
column50: and his deep love for his wife narrates the story.  The reader falls in love with Jacob and develops an even greater love and respect for \"old folks.\"  Sara Gruen's novel awakens the reader to the often mistreatment of and disrespect for the elderly
column51: evoking empathy in their cause.  Especially hurtful is seeing how their own families
column54: or forget about them.  Old people are still human beings.  In many cases
column58: there is a brain inside their heads as Jacob proves.  In having Jacob tell his story in Water for Elephants
column59: the author informs us of this and reminds us of the fact that we will grow old someday.  At the same time Sara Gruen affords us a moving and delightful read--so do not be misled by the title."

column6: "reviewText": "Where to even start with a review of this book...  There are over 2
column7: 600 reviews already and I doubt I'll be able to add anything new or groundbreaking.  My mom and my friend have been trying to get me to read Water For Elephants for the past couple of years
column8: but I've resisted.  I didn't want to read this book for a few reasons
column9: namely - the subject matter (a traveling circus) didn't really excite me
column10: the idea of an old man telling the story in a sort of flashback manner reminded me too much of The Notebook (of which I only saw the movie)
column12: I didn't want to read this story because I absolutely adore animals and I knew there would be parts about abuse that would be difficult for me to read.  But now that the movie has come out
column13: I knew it was time to give it a go.  Books are always so much better than movies and I wanted to check this novel off my list before it possibly became tainted by Robert Pattinson's portrayal.... just in case.  :)If
column15: you also have these reservations - don't let them stop you.  Yes
column16: the story is rather sad in parts
column17: and it will make your heart break
column18: but it's so much more.  It took me a while to really get in to the story
column19: but I absolutely tore through the last 200 or so pages.  It's not so much a love story as it is a life story.You can really tell that the author did her homework.  There are vivid
column20: graphic descriptions of everything and you feel like you're right there with these characters.  The true mark of a good writer (at least for me) is when they can create characters that you hate and abhor so much they can actually make your skin crawl even after you've read the last page.  This author did that - and with more than one character.Overall
column21: it was a fantastic story and I highly recommend it!"

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is the first book in a long time to allow a reader to savor the pages while thirst for the next.  What more could you want out of a book???THe story revolves around the main character
column7: Jacob Jankowski
column8: and a part of his young adulthood.  During this period of time
column9: Jacob must fend for himself as he migrated from what he believed would be a promised and lucrative life to a life of uncertainly and of poverty.Jacob stumbles into a lifestyle within and revolving around work in a traveling circus during the Great Depression era in the United States.Sara Gruen's writing brings alive every event and character very vividly; the setting simply demands only her very apt and transporting descriptions.Sara Gruen does transport the reader; the captivating read that feels as if you are just plunked down in the middle of Jacob's life.  The reader is absolutely the quintessential \"fly on the wall\".We not only observe but feel Jacob's pain
column14: and grief.  She has managed to include the reader in her words.I enjoyed my role as a reader and can only hope that Gruen's other titles enable me to be transported yet again to another world that only Gruen can create."

column6: "reviewText": "WE was terrific out of the starting blocks
column7: vivid and well-researched
column8: replete with interesting characters.  Along the way
column10: it increasingly took on the feel of a creative writing exercise -- ever lighter on research
column12: and thinner on plot.  In the end
column13: I found WE disappointing.  Like many historical novels by contemporary young authors
column14: WE is only shallowly situated in its particular historical context (depression era
column15: circus).  Every now and then the author tosses in a cliched reference to food lines to remind the reader of the historical moment; otherwise
column16: nothing to suggest the landscape (literal and figurative) through which the Benzini Brothers train chugs ever onwards.  I emerged from WE with far less of a feel for circuses or society in the 1930s
column17: or for aging and the elderly today
column18: than I should have.  WE reads like an entertaining short story stretched to the breaking point.  There just isn't enough 'there' there..."

column6: "reviewText": "I recently finished reading Water for Elephants.  The historical elements in this novel were carefully researched which made for a thrilling book.  I loved the way the story was told by an elderly man living in a nursing home and it bounced back and forth between timelines.  You fell in love with the grumpy man and you think about what the elderly actually feel like when they are forced to live in places like this. His story is touching and you really get to know all of the characters.  The elephant is a sweetheart and it's amazing how smart she is.  Great book and look forward to seeing the movie to see how well it was done."
column7: "overall": 5.0

column6: "reviewText": "I couldn't wait to read and this book didn't disappoint.  The circus was an incredibly vivid background

column6: "reviewText": "What kid hasn't wanted to run away to the circus? I wanted to be an acrobat at one point
column7: swigging around high up in the sky. I don't think I ever really considered the repercussions of such a life though-always moving around
column8: having to live with who you work with weather you like it or not
column9: constant work...now it sounds more hard than fun to me.But Jacob Jankowski never really had a choice in the matter. Emotionally wrecked and financially bereft when his parents die in the great depression
column10: Jacob hops on a train and ends up in the middle of the Benzini Brothers most spectacular show on earth. With his status as a (not graduated but) Cornell trained Vet
column11: Jacob is hired on to see to the shows animals.Its decent work
column12: but hard. And Jacob's boss August only makes it harder with his mercurial temperament and his very beautiful wife
column13: one of the circuses star performers-who might like Jacob a little too much. But it's an arrangement Joseph can live with-until Rosie comes along.Every circus needs an elephant right? And Rosie becomes Jacob's. As circus life becomes more and more perilous-Can Jacob get out with his friends
column14: animals and possible love of his life alive and intact? Come to the show and find out?\"Water for Elephants\" is a fantastic little gem of a book. The writing is marvelous
column18: except for one thing. And how could one fail to read the book after reading the prolog? There is no doubt this is an author to watch because she is going places!Just one problem-the disease that August is eventually unveiled as having is completely wrong for the symptoms he was exhibiting. I doubt the author really researched it or she would know that. It didn't bother me too much but for people who are suffering from or love those who really are paranoid schizophrenic it could be seen as stupid and offensive.But still
column19: five stars.So step right up folks! Admission for this five star show is only the price of a good book."
column21: "summary": "Step right folks! The price of admission to this five star tale is only that of a good book!"

column6: "reviewText": "What a good book

column6: "reviewText": "A very well-written piece of literary fiction that is not easily forgotten.  I picked up the novel because of its great reviews and my disdain for the circus and inhumane treatment of circus animals
column7: but ended up loving it because of a very engaging plot and my great affection for the main character in particular.  This novel is SO much more than a great story of Depression-era circus workers and performers; that simply lays the very interesting foundation. The ending was the best I've read in a long time and brought the novel full circle.  I look forward to more books by Sara Gruen!"

column6: "reviewText": "I had no desire whatsoever to read this book until I saw a trailer for the movie. The tailer caught my eye and since books are always better then the movie I took a chance and found that I thought it was a great story. The story felt real. It's a very believeable read and I liked that it wasn't sugar coated. It held my interest and taught me a lot about circus life in that time period. The ending completely caught me off guard. Water for Elephants is a story that will stay with me forever. I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys reading!"
column7: "overall": 4.0

column6: "reviewText": "Jacob Jankowski is 90 or 93 years old - he can't remember -- living in curmudgeonly isolation in a nursing home where he reminisces and dreams of a time in his youth when he was an uncertified vet with the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth traveling circus in the 1930s.  Uncle Al
column7: the unscrupulous and chiseling owner
column8: runs a tight train.  He has thugs who throw non-productive and trouble-making employees off the train to their deaths in a practice known as \"red-lighting.\"  He also buys down-and-out circuses and
column10: acquires Rosie the Polish speaking elephant
column11: who is smarter than anyone but Jacob knows.Jacob is the only person in the book who has a handle on a moral compass and as his reward he spends most of the novel beaten
column15: swollen and hung over.  He is the self-appointed Protector of the Downtrodden who makes a dangerous mistake: he falls in love with Marlena
column16: an animal act performer who is married to the brutal August
column17: the menagerie supervisor.  His cruelty to animals and his violence are probably due to paranoid schizophrenia.  It is enough that he terrorizes everyone in his life and every animal
column18: too.Jacob is forced to bunk in the horse car with the Shakespeare-reading Walter
column20: \" a dwarf who is devoted to the Jack Russell terrier that is part of his act.  As the train carries the circus across the US
column21: the lives of the performers and workers intertwine
column23: and Jacob becomes a hero through simple humanity to Camel
column24: a drunken laborer who is poisoned by drinking Jamaica ginger.The best scene in the entire novel is the descriptive passage of Marlena performing with her horse team and with Rosie
column25: the elephant in her pink sequined costume.  Gruen manages to humanize people who really seem to be populating a fairy tale for adults.  Not a great book
column26: but a diverting one.  Gruen seems to specialize in animal stories."

column6: "reviewText": "This is a best seller and has been lauded by many as an accurate portrayal of circus life in the 1930s.  Perhaps this is true.I loved the narrator
column7: an elderly gentleman who is living in a nursing home.  I related to his upsets about the way he is being treated and understood his desire to get himself to the circus which has pitched its tent across the street from the home.  I felt empathy of this old man and felt the several chapters relating to his present life were done well.Through his voice we learn his story in flashback and most of the book takes place in this circus in the 1920s when the old man was young.  As the fresh-faced new kid
column8: he's a stereotype.  And so is the woman he falls in love with.  Problem is that she's married to the ringmaster.  How this all turns out is mildly interesting
column9: especially the parts about the animals
column10: but I kept hoping the book would get better and I would feel some empathy for someone.Therefore
column11: while this book has a few good moments
column12: I can't even give it a lukewarm recommendation."

column6: "reviewText": "This is a very good book. It may be slightly over hyped
column7: but it certainly deserves of most of the praise it's receiving. Water for Elephants is a moving tale about circus life during the depression era with quirky characters and complex emotions underlying the character's actions. It's uniquely told from the perspective of one character at two different stages of his life; Jacob at 20 and again when he was 93 and living in a nursing home. The story moves seamlessly between these two timelines and although I was more intrigued by the introspective old Jacob
column8: the complexity and volatility of young Jacob also captured my attention
column9: just on a different more concrete level. The book touches on what's important at different phases of life. The story is sweet
column10: tragic and entertaining and the emotions that surface range from sad and lonely to happy and in love. In short
column11: the story is haunting and brings to light the strong bond that develops between man and animal and shows the true meaning of friendship. An excellent selection for those who enjoy a good character driven story."
column13: "summary": "Really hit home on the bond between man and animal"

column6: "reviewText": "This is one of the best books I've read in years.  It had excellent character development and I had to keep reminding myself that it was fiction.  Since hearing about the dreadful Hartford circus fire from my mother (who had friends perish)

The book quickly became an engrossing story.  I was cheering for the animals!  The mal treatment some of them received was very hard listening.  The one criticism I had

column11: in danger?  I would have found him more attractive had he been more discerning.  As it was

column6: "reviewText": "This audiobook was so well done! Two different readers provide for the voices of the man at 93
column7: living in a rest home and his 23 year old self in memory. Alternate chapters keep the reader torn between hearing the story of Jacob and his experiences with a circus during the depression and his later self coping with another type of depression as he deals with a worn out body and his limited life as he waits to die. Anyone with compassion for older people will find this story heart wrenching and enlightening at the same time. Excellent!"

column6: "reviewText": "The last novel I read and reviewed was also about animals but this could not be more different and after struggling to get into the last one
column7: I loved this from the minute I picked it up and found it to be an exceptional read. The authors love of animals and the tremendous research she did for this novel make it not only a fascinating portrayal of life
column8: ugly and vibrant in the American circus of the 1930's but a beautiful and tender love story. I had never even heard of circus trains until I read this either and learning a little something when I read also appeals to me.The title had been on my wishlist for awhile so I was delighted to obtain a copy recently and wanted to get on with reading so that I can see the film
column9: which has been recommended to me.Since seeing elephants up close in Thailand
column10: I also have more understanding of just how intelligent they are. Wonderful creatures which will treat humans well if they are given the respect they deserve. Sara Gruen portrays the nature of the elephant perfectly
column11: for me Rosie was the real protagonist of the novel. The novel is told as two separate but connected stories
column12: as well as being immersed in the circus world
column13: we are also given an inside view of a home for the elderly where the hero of the story Jacob is now living. Again the author has done her research as the scenes in the nursing home were poignant and all too familiar to me in many ways.When the novel starts Jacob Jankowski is in his nineties and living in a nursing home and the imminent arrival of the circus in town revives some very stirring memories for the old man and it is these that are told in the other storyline.It is the American Depression and when Jacob's parents die while he is studying veterinary science at university
column14: he discovers that they were in dire financial difficulties and he cannot even afford to complete his studies. Confused and bewildered with no plans for his future he finds himself hitching a ride on a circus train and in that moment his whole life changes. By the following morning he finds himself working for the travelling circus and by that evening he has met and fallen for the woman who will for evermore be the love of his life. Marlena
column16: however the love should remain unrequited as she is married to August the strangely mad animal trainer. Of course it is not long either before he also meets my particular favourite
column17: Rosie the elephant. Whilst struggling to survive in the world of this second rate travelling circus this young couples love overcomes obstacles that you can not begin to imagine.The two stories are ultimately woven together but to find out just how you will have to read for yourself. I highly recommend you read this if you have not already done so. I think most avid readers will find something they like about this one."

column6: "reviewText": "What a terrific read! Water for Elephants has been lauded as a \"great pick for summer\"
column7: but this book is so much more. It has a depth and a substance to it that you don't usually find in your typical \"beach read\". It's obvious that the author did her research into the time period (post-Depression America)
column8: and the subject matter (traveling circuses).  According to the author's note at the end of the book
column9: many of the compelling anecdotes in the story were based upon real events
column10: culled from the diaries and personal histories of old-time circus performers. As a result
column11: Water for Elephants is a novel that boasts the rare combination of being both entertaining and informative.The main character is a cantankerous
column13: and his frustration at being trapped in an old man's body is palpable. The story of his incredible life and adventures with the Benzini Brothers circus unfolds in a way that is emotionally wrenching
column14: and yet flashes of good humor pervade throughout. The characters are richly drawn
column15: and even the animals are given complex personalities that make them a pivotal part of the story. There is something in the novel for everyone: it is equal parts adventure
column19: and historical account.I highly recommend this book!"

column6: "reviewText": "Picked up this book to read based on the fact it was a local Book Club's Selection.  Immediately was drawn into it and read it in a day.  Book is 331 pages and for me it read quickly.My opinion the book is that it is thought provoking and also educational - communicated through the day to day thoughts of a man now facing the day to day realities and drawbacks of living in an \"Assisted Living\" facility.Gruen is able to effectively weave a lot of bittersweet humor into her character and has also imparted quite a bit of history of the period of the Great Depression and also circus life.Read thru the ratings that were less than 3 star - guess it goes to show we all have different tastes.  The reviewer who stessed going back to the old classics made me remember dry
column7: horrible
column8: rambling selections that to this day I do not value.Water for Elephants goes beyond boy meets girl
column10: walks into the sunset hand in hand.  The interjection of the character in  his later years keeps the book flowing and gives the reader a chance to develop empathy for the main character.The end is upbeat - seems a bit unbelievable - but then again it keeps the \"spark\" of the book burning bright.Looking forward to more reading from Sara Gruen."

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants follows two alternating storylines: the first traces the veterinary career of Jacob Jankowsi
column7: a Cornell dropout who finds work with a little-known circus during the Great Depression. The second sees Jacob years later as a bored
column8: temperamental old man in a nursing home. Having nothing but time
column9: the older Jacob slips in and out of memories
column10: mentally revisiting his days with the circus.The main focus of the \"circus\" storyline is the love triangle between Jacob
column14: a performer. Although they all start out as friends
column15: it soon proves to be a disjointed friendship at best. Despite his charming exterior
column16: August is a two-dimensional bully prone to violent rages. Jacob
column20: and shares a mutual passion with Marlena (also somewhat two-dimensional) for the circus animals.The story has potential. Honestly
column21: what's a more romantic setting for a love story than the surreal world of the circus? Unfortunately
column22: the circus merely serves as exquisite background scenery for the main drama
column23: which turns out to be nothing more than a predictable love story between two cardboard characters I could honestly care less about. That said
column24: it's still worth a single read just for the background material itself."

column6: "reviewText": "This book sat on my bookshelf for over a year and I finally picked it up because i saw an ad about the movie. Now I am saying to myself
column7: why did I wait so long to read this book.Water for Elephants was so visual to me and I constantly dreamed that I was with the characters on the train. I also could not get out of my mind the thoughts that the main character had as an older man. The author did not hold anything back and I loved that this made the character so real to me. This book was definitely a part of me while reading it and I am sure it will stick with me for awhile.The story goes from the main character being an older man to him thinking about when he was younger and how he got involved with the circus. There is a love story that is so strong and so real.I would recommend this book to anyone."

column6: "reviewText": "\"Water for Elephants is fiction\"
column7: but the author clearly did her research
column8: and so it's solidly based on the sad realities of life for both humans and animals working in circuses during the Depression.  But sadly
column9: animal circuses haven't changed much since that time.  Human workers may no longer be \"redlighted\"
column10: but captive wild animals are still packed into buses or trains without heat in winter or air conditioning in summer
column11: imprisoned in cages or chained up
column12: forced to perform demeaning tricks for the public
column16: not enough nourishment.Gruen can tell a story
column18: she presented the animal characters in a sympathetic and favorable light
column19: and I enjoyed the read.  But I have to say that to me
column20: the happy ending of Jacob and Marlena finding employment with Ringling Brothers so they can bring Rosie
column21: Bobo and the horses along with them is anything but.  Admittedly
column23: it may have been the only option open to them
column24: and there were few if any animal protection advocates out there exposing circuses like Ringling.  The truth is that Ringling Brothers has a long history of well-documented animal abuse
column26: something Ms. Gruen never refers to in her novel--although
column29: unbelievably cruel execution of Topsy by electrocution of none other than American paragon Thomas Edison.  It's also quite unrealistic that they would be able to keep an adult chimp as a pet
column30: especially with five children of their own to care for and protect.  Chimps become quite intractable as adults; they're extremely strong
column31: unpredictable and dangerous.I can't help thinking that the happy ending to a circus novel set in the 21st century would have Rosie sent to a place like The Elephant Sanctuary to spend her remaining life blissfully roaming hundreds of acres with other former circus and zoo elephants
column32: and Bobo retiring to a wonderful sanctuary like Save the Chimps
column33: where he would join a chimp family and have the closest thing to a normal life a captive ape can have.  And Jacob getting a job at a zoo so he can take Rosie along after his circus career is also not a very cheery outcome for me.  There's no question that zoo elephants lead short
column34: painful
column35: highly restricted lives
column36: and many zoos are in the process of retiring their elephants to sanctuaries.Also
column37: it's quite unbelievable to me that after Jacob witnessed so much brutality while working for circuses earlier in his life
column38: he would want to join a circus again rather than live in a nursing home.  That speaks volumes about that nursing home!Lastly
column39: I understand that the author considers herself an animal lover
column40: but that can mean a lot of things
column41: and I'm wondering exactly what her agenda was
column42: writing this book."

column7: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is a thoroughly enjoyable read!! column6: "reviewText": "You are very close to your parents and are planning on following in your father's footsteps
column7: becoming a veternarian.  In fact you have completed your grad studies at one of the finest institutions of higher learning in the land and are prepared to sit for your finals.  Then you discover your parents were just killed in a freakish auto accident.  You are devastated

column12: \" circus wanna-be.This is the story of Jacob Jankowski
column14: who tries to find himself after he experiences the worst possible news.  This phenomenal novel fluctuates between 93 year old Jacob's declining last years in a retirement home to his 3.5 month stint as a vet in a traveling circus during the Great Depression.You will not be able to put this book down as you travel back in time and discover Jacob's newly found existance as a member of the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth.  His friends
column17: and others will sadden you as you explore their limited
column18: fragmented lives.  While Jacob grows more cynical in those who callously control the lives of others he also learns about himself through his caretaking instincts involving an elephant named Rosie.  This relationship seals his beliefs that he needs to complete his final exams and secure the profession he was meant for.  In addition

column6: "reviewText": "Stripped of everything after his parents' untimely death
column7: twenty-three-year old Jacob Jankowski has failed to sit for his veterinary exams at Cornell
column8: left with no home and no future
column9: the country struggling through the Great Depression
column10: bartering in goods instead of money. Hopping a train that by chance belongs to The Flying Squadron of the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth
column11: Jacob hires on to care for the menagerie
column12: his training an entre into this bizarre world; but as the novel begins
column14: restricted to an assisted living home
column15: his memories sparked by a nearby visiting circus and a creeping helplessness that assaults his ageing body: \"Age is a terrible thief. Just when you think you're getting the hang of it
column16: it knocks your legs out from under you and stoops your back.\"The story is related in the somber tones of the Depression
column17: the hardscrabble and often unscrupulous business of a traveling circus and the heartless despots who make their fortunes on the backs of men who must do anything to survive. Star performer Marlena
column19: is sensitive to the needs of her horses
column23: is obsessively jealous and given to unspeakable cruelties. Uncle Al
column25: is a ruthless businessman who cares little for man or beast
column26: engaged in a quest for fame to rival the great Ringling Brothers. With his advanced training in veterinary medicine
column27: Jacob does his best to protect the animals from their harsh existence
column29: an elephant purchased to replace Marlena's lead horse. Jacob and Rosie share an affinity for one another
column30: the huge creature at times almost human. Because of his growing affection for Marlena
column31: Jacob suffers August's increasing affronts
column32: caught in a cycle of inevitable violence
column33: certain of a reckoning.In chapters that move flawlessly back and forth in time
column34: from the rowdy circus atmosphere to the antiseptic corridors of the assisted living home
column35: the world is viewed through Jacob's perspective
column36: as he rages helplessly against the decrepitude of old age and the secrets of the past. In prose both poignant and infinitely tender
column37: Jacob dwells in both worlds
column38: revealing the wounds of the past and the sorrows of the present. In one touching scene
column39: Jacob awaits a family member to escort him to the circus
column40: yearning for the Big Top with every fiber of his being
column41: craving the familiar sights and smells of that pivotal summer of `31
column42: the roustabouts
column43: the kinkers
column44: the rubes
column45: the animals. The denouement is devastating
column46: as inescapable as the indifferent world that turns a blind eye to the vagrants of the 30's. Yet Jacob's spirit retains the essence of his kind nature and a respect for others
column47: a man who will not be broken by circumstances. All is redeemed in a coup d'grace that will leave the reader strangely satisfied and richer for having met this raggedy tribe of miscreants and lost souls. Luan Gaines/ 2006."

column6: "reviewText": "This novel is the best of all of my summer reading so far. I couldn't put it down and read the entire book in a day. I was absolutely captivated. Each incident
column7: each character
column9: the time-frame - every aspect of this book was simply amazing and I was even brought to tears twice.What a perfect setting. The Great Depression - the time when the great circus shows began to lose their prowess as the best kind of entertainment. But the Benzini Brothers circus isn't the fun
column10: song-and-dance circus that everyone thinks of from movies like 'The Greatest Show on Earth'
column11: 'Merry Andrew' or even Disney's 'Dumbo'. This circus is a delight on the surface
column14: dangerous and deadly place to be if you're not a performer. (And even some of the performers get the boot - like poor Walter the dwarf clown.)This kind of circus gives a taste of what spectators and boys who dream of running away to join the circus would never imagine.The method of Jacob's memoirs - alternating between his life now at 93 years old - still sharp minded and still having all of his teeth
column15: stuck in a nursing home and feeling horribly depressed about it all
column16: and remembering what happened during his time with the Benzini Brothers Circus - is an incredible technique. One minute I was drawn in by his angst of losing his parents
column17: his home and his security to the point of jumping the next train to anywhere
column19: we are back in the nursing home
column20: and poor Jacob is fighting with a fellow resident about the possibility of carrying water for elephants.Add the vulturous Uncle Al
column21: the wicked ringmaster who'll stop at nothing to make his circus better than the Ringling Bros.
column25: a cranky dwarf and his little dog
column27: and an elephant who only understands Polish. The characters alone are enough to make you want to read before you even know half of what is going on.As I said
column28: twice I was brought to tears - once by old Jacob in the nursing home
column29: when he realizes that his five children had forgotten who was to take him on his outing
column30: and he was actually brought to tears himself. I just couldn't help but think of my own 90 year old grandfather
column31: who isn't in assisted living and drives himself and my grandmother to Florida every winter and goes bowling and plays shuffleboard every week. It was sad to think of poor Jacob
column32: excited about getting to see the circus one last time
column33: and then being terribly disappointed that his own children had forgotten. It made me feel like I will never let that happen to my grandfather.No one who reads this book will be disappointed. From cover to cover
column34: it is absolutely wonderful. The writing style is simple and easy to understand. There is no 'filler' - unnecessary
column35: boring descriptions or dialogue that has nothing to do with the story. It is an excellent novel and although I could rave some more about my favorite characters and my favorites scenes and so on
column36: I will simply say that it is a must-read."

column6: "reviewText": "This is a sometimes gritty
column7: sometimes heart-wrenching story of a man who ran away and joined the circus.  The story is told through the mind of Jacob
column9: I had to look that up) resident of a nursing home
column10: who was orphaned his last week of veterinary school.  Jacob discovers that his parents
column11: struggling along with everyone else through the end of the Great Depression
column12: had impoverished themselves to keep him in college.  Broke himself
column13: and unable to focus enough to complete his exams
column14: he desperately jumps a train and runs away from his life.The train he jumps happens to belong to The Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth.  Barely avoiding getting thrown off the train
column15: he is befriended by a few of the circus workers
column16: and becomes the veterinarian for the show's menagerie of exotic animals.This look behind the scenes of the train circuses is enough in itself to carry the book.  Sara Gruen's ability to place herself behind the eyes of a 93 (or is it 90?) year-old man is gripping.  The two combined give the story a depth that makes you want to keep turning the pages.The flaws in the story are not enough to make it founder but just enough to keep this from being a five-star read.  In particular
column17: Jacob's ability to turn his back when those he loves are endangered is at odds with what we see of his nature at other times.  The encapsulated explanations for his behavior notwithstanding
column18: his integrity is deeply flawed in a manner that can't be explained away
column19: and yet the author ignores it.  We are thus left cheated from seeing not just how Jacob affects the circus
column20: but how deeply the circus affects Jacob."

column6: "reviewText": "Although the story is quite intriguing and the juxtaposition of Jacob's life in a nursing home with his life as a young vet at the circus is a clever way to tell the story
column7: the hardships that the animals endure are quite upsetting. I had to stop reading this book when August decided to take his anger out on Rosie
column9: because his wife who had never ridden an elephant was injured during Rosie's first performance
column10: a performance for which neither one had trained. Circus trainer's used a bull hook to cause pain to the elephant so that it would do what they wanted it to do - I don't know the extent to which he tortured the elephant with the bull hook but I didn't want to find out.In terms of the writing style it is not the best. I believe the books' popularity may have more to do with the scenes in the nursing home which are much better written than those of the circus and touch the lives of many of us who have had to put our parents in or have visited these institutions."

column6: "reviewText": "I had numerous kin
column7: friends and co-workers tell me to read Sara Gruen's Water for Elephants.  I told each person that as soon as I obtain the opportunity I would read the novel.  The narrator
column9: did an eminent job guiding the reader.  Personally I didn't feel everything he was going through
column10: but I was able to help justify his actions.  For instance when he finally yelled at August or when he consummated his love for Marlena.  What intrigued me most about Gruen's writing was her ability to tie the ninety year old Jacob to the circus Jacob.  I was thrilled how she gave Jacob a sense of eudemonia when the book concluded.  Jacob finished up where he began; he ended up right where he wanted to be.  On a scale of 1-10 I would give this book a 9.  All in all when you read it you won't be disappointed."

column6: "reviewText": "Overall
column7: I'm rather underwhelmed based on the hype around this book.The details of the Great Depression were amazing
column8: and seemed accurate enough.  The writing didn't get in the way too much but seemed amateurish at times.  I spent the ENTIRE afternoon
column9: EACH and EVERY ONE was used three times in a single chapter
column10: and unimaginative clichés one after another such as quick as lightning were not uncommon.  I assumed this was Gruen's first novel and was quite surprised to find out it was her third.The morality of the story fell very flat as well.  The characters kind of want to do the right thing
column11: but I wasn't sold on their move toward adultery based on initial attraction.  A lot of people feel an attraction toward someone who is not their spouse.  That doesn't mean it is right or destined.  Greun's inability to convince me that Jacob and Marlena were any different was a major failing of the novel for me.How many meals can people in the Great Depression skip without even thinking about it.  At least a dozen times through the book people skipped meals because they didn't feel like eating.I had high expectations so I'm judging harshly.  Did not meet expectations.  Not a bad book by any means
column12: but far short of novel-of-the-year quality."

column6: "reviewText": "Why bother chiming in with review number 1
column7: 605? The verdict is in. Most readers (at least those who post reviews) love this book. Everybody who told me to read it (five or six reader friends) guaranteed enjoyment. I like those guarantees. Unfortunately
column8: there's no such thing.Good things about \"Water for Elephants:\" Atmosphere Period detail (a rundown traveling circus from 1931) Old man's voiceNot so good things about \"Water for Elephants:\" Run-of-the-mill imagery. Examples: \"His eyes drill into Marlena. His temple pulses.\" \"Flailing my arms like a windmill.\" \"I blush so hard my scalp prickles.\"  (Really?) \"The roustabouts
column10: run about like headless chickens.\"  The terrain is as \"dry as a bone.\" \"I leave though every bone in my body screams against it.\" There's not too much doubt about where the story is going
column11: even from early on. We know Jacob will be successful
column12: despite predictions he won't last a week. Tension is low throughout. Protracted scenes--such as Lucinda's funeral and the long strip-tease scene at the beginning. To what end? Perfect characters--too perfect. The sadistic hothead. The charming circus girl. Etc.In the end
column13: the good things about the book were buried under the weight of the not-so-good. I left feeling like I'd been chewing on something tempting and sweet but ultimately unsatisfying

column6: "reviewText": "This is not the best-written book you'll ever read
column7: it's sentimental and morally simplistic
column8: but it's very entertaining. Good parts: The depiction of human and animal life in a seedy Depression-era circus is fascinating. The implausible adventures of the protagonist Jacob
column9: a veterinary student who joins the circus
column12: the circus animals in Jacob's care
column15: keep you in suspense and turning the pages. Gruen risks ridicule with her over-the-top romantic ending
column17: but there's something endearing about her having taken that risk. Bad parts: The admittedly engaging human characters are too one-dimensionally virtuous or nasty. Gruen
column18: though she capably creates a world in which you can immerse yourself and carries the story along at a good clip
column19: is no literary stylist. I did not care for the bookend device of beginning and ending the story with Jacob looking back on his life from a nursing home. If I were rating this on writing quality

column21: I gave it four stars. Highly recommended for long flights

column6: "reviewText": "What a WONDERFUL book about a slice of American life that not many people know about.  What was circus life like during the Depression? Don't let the topic discourage you from reading this book.  I was captured by the first line: \"I am ninety. Or ninety-three. One or the other.\"  As I was reading this book
column7: I could see the whole story play out in my mind as the author easily transitioned the storyteller from the present day back to the 1930's and his life on a circus train.  I can't say enough good things about this book.  Read it....It's a true winner!!!"

column6: "reviewText": "\"Water for Elephants\" is one of those rare
column7: enchanting novels that takes the reader into another world with complete believability.  Reading this tale makes you believe you are on board this Depression-era circus train
column8: complete with all the sounds and smells.A great novel must combine such a travelouge with interesting
column10: and Sara Gruen has accomplished that.  The New Yorker review complained that the protagonist
column12: was not interesting because he was \"relentlessly decent.\"  Apparently the idea that some people really are decent escaped the jaded reviewer.  Also
column13: Jacob certainly commits his share of moral transgressions (and is ready to commit murder) in the course of his growth into the decent man who so bored the New Yorker.The Publisher's Weekly reviewer complained of a predictable ending
column15: either: it took me until the last chapter to see where Jacob's journey would end
column16: and the final twist is a heartwarming one.  Maybe that's what some too-cynical professional reviewers really don't like: the idea that
column17: in literature as in real life
column18: some stories are uplifting ones.I'm a writer as well as a voracious and nit-picking reader
column19: and I don't give five-star reviews.  In this case

column6: "reviewText": "Of the gazillion-billion books I've read in my lifetime
column7: this currently ranks as #1.  I say currently because I'm allowing that I might come upon another book that bowled me over like this one did....I hope so....but I kind of doubt it.  Be forewarned...once you crack this book open
column8: you will fall head over heels between the pages...and not want to come back out!"
