column6: "reviewText": "Romance
column7: love
column9: violence and humor are expertly woven into this novel.  I loved it and I was sorry to finish it.  It was one of those books which makes it difficult to begin another book.  I cared about the characters
column10: and the events lingered after I completed it.  That is saying a lot about a book for me; I'm a voracious reader and I usually begin a new book as soon as I finish the last.  I think it is a book which would appeal to a wide range of readers'"

column6: "reviewText": "\"Water for Elephants\" was recommended by an animal loving friend with the comments that the book was a must read.  The story is set during the 1930's depression and takes place primarily on a traveling circus train.  Jacob Jankowski
column7: recently orphaned
column8: is hired as the veterinarian for the circus. Through Jacob's gaze
column9: we are introduced to the inner workings of the greatest show on earth as proclaimed by Uncle Al
column10: owner of the Benzini Brothers circus.  We learn of the work required to roll out and pick up a circus as well as the cruelty with which the men charged with this work are treated.  While the animals
column11: performances and circus atmosphere are well rendered by the author I found the class structure created within the traveling circus of particular interest; a structure whereby the lowest members of the circus team may be guaranteed a meal but not necessarily a wage or a life.  Equally interesting to me is the depiction of geriatric care
column13: afforded Jacob during his twilight years.  Gruen did an excellent job of capturing the desolation of aging without the care and proximity of your family.\"Water for Elephants\" is a well crafted tale of adventure
column14: love and murder.  The characters are memorable and the language easily accessible and imagistic.  This is an entertaining read but I must admit it dispelled any quixotic notions that I associate with running off with the circus; that was hard and dangerous work then. You were luck if you left the show with your life and even luckier if you left with a life.  For this reader
column15: It'll be enough to watch the next circus that comes to town and remember the men and women that whose hard work made it possible then and keeps the show on the road now. Enjoy!"

column6: "reviewText": "In WATER FOR ELEPHANTS
column7: Sara Gruen takes us into the world of the circus during the Great Depression and the incredible lives associated with it.  For Jacob Jankowski
column8: the circus is just about a last chance that fate has given him after some untimely luck.  Joining with the Benzini Brothers to care for their animals
column9: Jacob is launched into a world that's strange and unusual for him
column10: and provides the backdrop for reminiscing when he's 90 and in a nursing home many years later.With vivid imagery
column11: you're taken into the world of the circus and into the lives of these characters.  The characters themselves are very believable and fleshed out
column12: especially August the animal trainer.  His viciousness and mood swings were gripping and his evolution into the bad guy had me sitting there waiting for more.  And as the husband of Marlena
column14: August had plenty of opportunity to be jealous and controlling.  Even secondary characters were well formed and fleshed out
column15: giving the book even more life and character.  Even Rosie the elephant becomes a character that you fall in love with by the end of the book.The author tackles a bunch of interesting subjects and has obviously researched them all thoroughly.  From the drinking of Sterno fluid during Prohibition and its effects afterwards to the history of the circus originally as an event for men to get on with their hoochy koochy stuff
column16: Gruen provides a well researched take on everything.  This research shows and if you're a history nut like me you will not be disappointed.What I had a slight problem with was the love story.  It was very sweet
column17: but it was also somewhat stereotypical.  Boy comes along and becomes the knight in shining armor to the damsel in distress.  It was still a believable
column20: and it makes you remember that back in the day
column21: people thought that women were property of men.  Even in the circus with people protecting one another there was no escape from domestic violence.The story in the past and in the nursing home blended seamlessly and the transitions were impeccable.  Gruen crafted a well researched and well written love story that
column23: was a very good novel.  Gruen is definitely an author that I want to watch and read more of.VERDICT: Even though it suffers from a stereotypical romance
column24: WATER FOR ELEPHANTS is a well-crafted
column25: heartwarming novel that keeps you glued to your seat wanting more of the circus and the atmosphere."
column28: enchanting book you'll want to check out"

column6: "reviewText": "I read this book about a year ago and was truly amazed with the imagery and visions the author
column7: Sara Gruen
column8: managed to portray. Written as a historical novel
column9: it reminded me very much of Nicholas Spark's The Notebook
column10: with the main character being an elderly man and telling the story through memories of his youth.Preparing to take his final exams as a veterinary student at university
column11: Jacob Jankowski receives some shocking news about his family which sends his future into a spin. Abandoning his exams
column12: he leaves school and hops on board a train in the middle of the night. This train is home to a travelling circus
column13: and it's through the characters he meets there that he becomes a vet to the animals on board and enters a world he never imagined. He quickly becomes part of the family and is soon caught up in a love triangle with the beautiful Marlena
column14: a circus performer who holds a particular soft spot for the star of the show
column16: Rosie.The novel is so beautifully written and will touch the hearts of all animal lovers. Sara Gruen really did her research into the circus era and the book is even peppered with images of old circus photographs. Definitely worth a read!See more book reviews at Storybook Love Affair - [...]"

column6: "reviewText": "I have to say that I was skeptical about reading this book.  A friend of mine talked me into downloading it onto my Kindle...and well...I finished the book in two days.  I wasn't sure about reading about a circus
column7: but it is also a bit of a love story (nothing intense).  I found the book easy to read and I loved the fact that the book goes back to the past and then to the present with the main character (an older man maybe ninety or ninety three) in a nursing home with a sense of humor. I will recommend this book to my friends."

column6: "reviewText": "Not very exciting but a decent read."
column7: "overall": 3.0

column6: "reviewText": "I really enjoyed the juxtaposition between the 90 (or was it 93?)-year-old Jacob and the young man Jacob who ran away to join the circus in 1931. However
column7: towards the end
column8: the 1931 story devolves into a bit of a soap opera the I didn't really enjoy. Other than that I found it a lively read...but I wanted more about Rosie
column9: the Polish-understanding elephant who everyone thinks is dumb because she doesn't understand English. Every moment where she is on the page
column11: but I found parts of the book slow-moving and lackluster when the story so lends its self to being bouncy and light (it is about a circus
column12: Miss Gruen!). People \"locked eyes\" 10 too many times for me. I loved the parts when Jacob is 90~~or is it 93~~(he can't remember)and his body
column14: in general has betrayed him. If you are looking for some lightweight entertainment and a quick read
column15: I would recommend this book. The biggest thing that bugged me about this edition (and many other books) are the book club discussion questions at the end of the book. These type of questions are too lengthy to actually be part of a lively book discussion (believe me
column16: I know...whenever someone in my book group chooses to go this route
column17: the discussion dies a hideous death). These questions are better suited for essay questions."

column6: "reviewText": "I admit that I didn't pay much attention to this book until I saw the commercials for the movie (yes
column7: I am one of \"those\" people).  I knew I would eventually see the movie so I looked up the book to see what it was about.  When I read the many positive reviews
column8: I figured I should go ahead and read it before I saw the movie.  When the Kindle edition dropped to $4.17
column9: I figured I wouldn't be out much money.  I am very happy I did.The story flowed very well and the writing was easy and accessible without seeming juvenile.  I found myself drawn to the older Jacob. Right out of high school
column10: I worked at an assisted living home while attending college and I was also extremely close to my late grandmother. I thought that the portrayal of an elderly person feeling trapped by the limitations of their failing body (and sometimes their mind) was heart-wrenching yet spot-on. In your heart and your \"inner dialogue\" you don't feel any older than you did 60+ years ago
column11: yet everything about your physical being has changed and the world around you has changed as well.The atmosphere and the feel of the book was wonderful. I felt like I was riding in that train car along with Jacob and Walter.  I felt the hurt that Jacob felt when he was orphaned
column12: confused and lost.  I felt scared and anxious along with them
column13: fearing that their \"stowaway\" in their car would be found.  I felt the elephant's fear and happiness.  I could almost hear the sounds of the circus
column14: smell the peanuts and greasy food.The only thing I wasn't 100% convinced on was the relationship between Jacob and Marlena.  I felt it from Jacob
column15: but not really from Marlena.  I felt like she was a weak character and there were moments I actually wondered if she gravitated towards Jacob because August was so cruel and hard to live with.  That is honestly the only negative thing I can say about this story.I think if you are looking for a real romantic read (like a Nicholas Sparks novel)
column16: I wouldn't recommend this. It has moments of romance but I didn't feel that was the main storyline. I got more out of it from the circus standpoint and the old man/young man's life.  I will be interested to see how \"romantic\" they make the movie (I am guessing by the poster
column17: commercials and lead actors that it will be the main point of the movie).  However I will still see it.I do recommend this book.  VERY much worth the time spent reading and worth the price.  Probably 90% better than most current novels out there now."
column20: but VERY good. Worth the time and money"

column6: "reviewText": "I put this item on my wishlist when it first came out because the premise sounded interesting and then I forgot about it until I saw it was released in paperback. I purchased it and was not let down. The story starts a little slow was you try to make sense of what is going on and whose exactly is this main character

column6: "reviewText": "#42 Book Read in 2012Water for Elephants by Sara GruenI have put off reading this book for a while now because I was afraid that I would not be able to handle the way the animals were treated in it.  After a few friends read
column7: they assured me that I would be able to handle it
column8: so I added it to the reading list for a class I am teaching this summer.  Boy
column9: am I glad that I did!Part of this book is set in a nursing home
column10: where an elderly Jacob is living and waiting for his famiy to visit so they can bring him to the circus.  The majority of this book is set in a circus
column11: a second rate circus who really wants to be Ringling Bros.  Jacob joins the circus and is considered their vet
column12: even though he does not have his official degree from Cornell.  He meets the circus folk and instantly forms a love/hate relationship with August and an attraction relationship with August's wife
column13: Marlena.Circus life is not easy and this book shows it.  Animals are treated as property and receive basic
column14: minimum care.  There is a huge class distinction between workers and performers.  Money is given out in order of the caste system.  There are nice people like Walter
column15: Earl and Greg.  There are evil people like Uncle Al.  The most despicable character in this book is August.  He abused his wife
column16: his animals and his workers.  I was hoping for justice and felt satisfied with how August ends up.There is also some not so dark relationships in this book. Jacob and Marlena share a deep connection and they spend time together
column17: even though it is forbidden.  Walter loves his dog Queenie.  Jacob has a connection with the animals
column18: especially Bobo and Rosie.  Camel gets Jacob a job with the show.  There are good people in this book and readers will root for them.A difficult at times book to read
column19: it was also powerful.  I recommend it.[...]"

column6: "reviewText": "I put off reading \"Water for Elephants\" for a long time because I'd heard it was about a circus
column7: and that topic held no interest for me. However
column8: so many people recommended this book to me that I finally bought it
column9: and once I started reading it
column10: I couldn't put it down!This is a wonderful story about the dark side of working on a traveling circus during the Great Depression. The story is told in flashbacks by Jacob Jankowski
column11: a former circus worker who is now in his early nineties and living in an assisted living facility. Jacob recalls the tragedies that led him to jump a train one night and end up working as the resident veterinarian for the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth. There isn't really anything spectacular about working for a traveling circus
column13: and this well-researched novels depicts the class issues between the performers and the workmen
column15: and the cruelty demonstrated by the show bosses. \"Water for Elephants\" is also a touching love story revolving around Jacob and Marlena
column16: a beautiful performer who is trapped in an ugly and abusive marriage with one of the circus bosses.I absolutely loved this book. It's a real page-turner filled with dynamic characters
column19: and terrible heartache. \"Water for Elephants\" will have a place of honor in my bookcase for all time. I highly recommend this book to everyone!"
column21: "summary": "Best book I've read in many months"

column6: "reviewText": "I really enjoyed this book. It is uniquely and well written from two perspectives of the same person. You definitely get drawn into the drama of the circus and invested in all of the characters. Sara keeps you wondering what is going to happen next. I do not want to give anything away but I was surprised at the ending!! I would definitely recommend and purchase this book to/for others."
column7: "overall": 4.0

column6: "reviewText": "I picked up this book because I wanted to see the movie when it came out. I have yet to see the movie

column6: "reviewText": "For years
column7: \"A Prayer For Owen Meany\" was my favorite book.  Until I read \"Water For Elephants\" for the first time.  I turned the last page and started all over again on page 1. I read it again after that.  I just love every sentence.  Jacob is a hoot!  The ending is the best ending ever!  Totally unexpected and totally true to character.  I live in Chicago
column8: so the Chicago connection was one more sweet moment.  It's just such an all around loving
column10: with quirky surprises at every turn.  It made me laugh out loud.  I can't help it . . . I love everything about it."

column6: "reviewText": "WARNING: SOME SPOILERS!Water for Elephants is a story based on a young man's life with the circus in the 1930s. Also
column7: it's about an older man reflecting back on his life. That alone should seem to confuse someone
column8: but it was done seamlessly. A couple chapters of back-story
column9: how it was back in the 30s and a chapter or two as the older man. Doing it that way
column10: you get a feel of different personalities of the same man. How he was sweet and nicer in his younger days and grew to a grumpy old man.What I liked about this book was reading about the circus life and the history aspect of it all. It's clearly shown that Sara did her research when it came to writing that time period. Things were so in detail
column11: I felt as if I was there.However
column12: some things seemed a bit much. At the end
column13: when I was reading the Author's Notes about this book
column14: it mentions all the things that happened in the story were inspired by real events. The thing is though
column15: not all of them happened to every circus. It was a random circus here and there. She ended up throwing all of the together in this one circus which was just too much and overcrowded. I really didn't think there needed to be that much in there. It makes it unrealistic to have it all happen.Supposedly there was a romance between Jacob and Marlena but to be honest
column16: I didn't see it. I don't see how she was in love with him and I don't see how he was in love with her. I expected something to show they loved one another
column17: I expected to be happy about it
column18: but I was just lost and confused. It wasn't until Jacob kissed her that I realized that there was supposed to be a romance blooming there. I think it was then
column20: that Sara realized she didn't have the romance in there and had to throw it in. It was stiff and unnatural. I like smiling at a romance that blossoms. I didn't smile.It honestly felt like they just \"liked\" each other because they both didn't like August

column6: "reviewText": "I finished Water For Elephants about 10 days ago and I can't stop thinking about it. I am quite a film fan and I often envision novels as a film
column7: which to many purists is tantamount to blasphemy I suppose
column8: but I cannot help it.  And I'm telling you this would make a terrific film. This is the first of Sara Gruen's novels that I have read
column9: and as important as animals are to the story
column10: I would venture to guess that Rosie the elephants importance in this novel is not near that of the role that the horses in her other novels have. In other words
column11: this is not a book just for animal lovers
column12: though being an animal lover can't hurt. This is  a revealing look at life in a Circus in the Depression era
column13: and even more so a story full of fascinating characters and compelling relationships.  It is a page turner that I truly enjoyed from start to finish.  I am reminded of Thomas Berger's \"Little Big Man\" when I look at the structure of this wonderful novel. As it moves back and forth seamlessly over a seventy year span.Sara Gruen writes an interesting afterword to the novel in which she reveals how she came up with the idea and the extensive research that she embarked on before completing her tale.  Her hard work paid off.  I really learned a lot about a milieu that I knew very little of prior to reading the book.  I cannot recommend this novel too highly."

column6: "reviewText": "This is a wonderful story! It is all at once funny

column6: "reviewText": "Last week
column7: halfway through my own reading of WATER FOR ELEPHANTS
column8: I decided to check the customer reviews to see if any other readers were rolling their eyes as much as I was
column11: not many were.  300 hundred reviews and most of them were five stars!  What seemed paper-thin and kind of ridiculous to me was \"beautiful and moving\" to nearly everyone else.  Everything about this book seemed like a cheat--like the warning you get on a bag of chips--\"contents may settle\"--to explain how there are only three chips in a family-sized bag.  Even the inclusion of the period photographs seemed to excuse the writer for not making clear enough pictures of her own.  It's not just the implausibility of the story either (elephant speaks only Polish).  If the details are right
column12: I can be drawn into even the most ridiculous of stories (THE RUINS and THE TERROR come to mind))
column13: but the paragraphs here are so flimsy (usually no more than three sentences long) that I never pictured (or believed) a word of it.  I'd close the book and pick it up a few hours later and have absolutely no idea what had happened.  It was an \"easy read
column14: \" but I don't know many writers who would consider that a compliment."

column6: "reviewText": "I read this book shortly after a loved one who had been staying in a nursing home passed away. Against that backdrop
column7: I was very moved by this book
column8: especially by the parts where the old man was narrating. I loved the spirited way he interacted with his nurses and the other residents
column9: and his inner dialogue as he grudgingly allowed himself to be taken care of. It reminded me so much of the things we would see when we would visit PopPop; it made me wish I had more time to give to my relative before he passed away. I also loved how the narrator's voice sounded old-fashioned in the context of the modern day scenes
column10: yet somehow contemporary in his flashback scenes. Kudos to the author for doing such a nice job with character voice.The plot was fun too- a young man trained as a vet hops a circus train and joins the crew. He falls in love with one of the show girls
column11: who happens to be married to the lead trainer. Conflict ensues
column12: and somewhere along the line an elephant appears. (Personally
column13: I felt the elephant could have been given an even larger role; she was wonderful to read about.)The plot is simple enough; will he get the girl
column14: or will she stay with her husband? My one complaint is that some of the examples the author gave on why the husband wasn't a model citizen weren't all that horrible in my mind. Yes
column16: but one of his supposed despicable decisions was... well.... practical
column17: in my mind. Maybe I'm just a cold-hearted monster
column18: but you'll see what I mean when you read the book.Also
column19: I felt the 'twist' at the end of the book was more akin to a 'trick' as readers are deliberately misled by the subtle revision of a key scene
column20: but I am willing to overlook it given the pleasure I received from the book overall.A word of warning to parents of pre-teens who may want to read this book because of the movie that just came out: Descriptions of masturbation
column22: and sexual encounters all make appearances in this book. As a mother
column23: I would recommend previewing these sections and taking your pre-teen's maturity level into consideration before giving them the book. It's all fairly tame
column24: but it is mentioned. Just an FYI."
column27: especially if you have an elderly loved one"

column6: "reviewText": "Water For Elephants is the story of ninety-something nursing home resident Jacob Jankowski
column7: who reflects on the time he spent with the Benzini Brothers circus when he was in his early 20's during the Depression Era.  The story goes back and forth between those two periods of Jacob's life.  Old Jacob is clearly frustrated by the physical limitations of his aged body
column8: and how small his world has become while living in the nursing home.  Young Jacob joins the circus due to circumstances in his home life that are beyond his control
column9: and the story goes on to describe the events that occurred during the time that Jacob spent with the circus as the staff veterinarian.Sara Gruen writes with such rich detail.  The sights
column10: sounds and images she portrays are all so vivid that while reading this
column11: I felt that I was transported to another time and place.  I learned so much about what circus life was like during the 1930's
column12: and how disposable both human and animal life were to the circus owners.  I was also very interested to learn that many of the happenings in the book are actually based on real-life events.  The characterizations of the animals were particularly well-written in this book
column13: too.This book truly exceeded my expectations
column14: and I am anxiously awaiting the release of the film!"
column17: Detailed Account of Circus Life in the 1930's"

column6: "reviewText": "Cleverly placed in the backdrop of the romantic but hard times of the Great Depression's wake [1931]
column7: this novel describes the weirder world in a stranger time in the not-so-common confines of a circus family.Gruen found a topic and made it extremely fun to read.  This reader likes stories
column8: and the author either created or embellished great stories of circus folklore [reader Author's Note at end].And
column9: amid the story there is a common group of guys who are the comedy which hold the story together - otherwise it may be too depressing and too violent for some readers. The three eclectic characters are the foul-mouthed hard-tempered dwarf clown whose mother sold him to the circus
column10: combined with the protagonist - a Cornell educated veterinarian
column12: who falls into emotionally hard times -  and the old man of the circus family whose overindulgence of jake makes him become a victim of the paralyzing Jake Walk Effect
column13: as him limbs wither along with his mind from the chemical's destructive forces. Each with his emotional or physical scars
column14: enlightens the others with dry wit and warm compassion as each struggles to continue to live on the circus train where many mornings are greeted with discoveries of losses of others from \"red lightings\" -  those who are not economically valuable to the \"family\" are thrown off the train while in transit at the latest of hours.Amid many stereotypical characters - aren't most circus characters stereoptyped by this time? - is the greatest monster of them all: a paranoid schizophrenic Jew named August. A love triangle grows between August
column15: his lovely wife Marlena and Jacob. Things get out of hand and at one time the author has Jacob think
column16: \"It occurs to me that my conscience stopped me from killing August at the very moment someone was attempting to carry out his orders to kill me.\" \"Prizzi's Honor\" meets the big top.If there is any criticism of this book
column17: it is not anything extraordinary.  Some of the dialogue was not totally sharp
column18: but few writers can write great dialogue.  Dialogue is the hardest task of any fiction writer. This dialogue is very good. Just not great.I also take my hat off to her delivery of the story through a young man's eyes.  His feelings about women
column20: and other items delivered through this book are not reflective of the author's gender. That accomplishment always amazes me and may amaze you as well.This book is good for trips or beach outings. This is a fun book to read.  I like fun novels. I read for fun. I like this novel."
column22: "summary": "Fun Fiction About the Big Top of Yesteryear"

column7: at 90-something-years-old

column6: "reviewText": "Given the number and quality of this book's other reviews on this site

This is one instance where the number of positive reviews don't lie:  Water for Elephants is worth reading."

column6: "reviewText": "I just finished reading Water for Elephants and goose bumps cover my skin as I type this review. Now this is a good book! Immediately engrossed
column7: I had a hard time putting it down as I read the story of Jacob Jankowski and his reminiscence of days with the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth--otherwise known as a train circus in 1930's America.A talented writer and storyteller
column8: Sara Gruen takes readers on a bumpy and tense train ride through history. This tale defines Americana. There is no evidence of author here--simply narrator telling the story from Jacob's perspective (is he 91 or 93 years old?). I liked everything about the book
column9: but primarily it was the crafting I liked best about this reading experience.Seamlessly
column10: Gruen weaves together the modern day voice of this old man
column12: abandoned in a nursing home--a.k.a. assisted living facility--and his memories of three months spent as the accidental veterinarian on a traveling circus. Just before his final exams
column13: he learns his parents have been killed in a car accident and this is what sets the story in motion. Once he hops aboard a train
column14: which he soon learns is a circus train
column15: he falls in love with a pink-sequined performer
column19: who happens to be his boss. Jacob
column21: is highly likeable and befriends most of the animals aboard. Most unforgettably is a \"Polish\" elephant by the name of Rosie. But he also endears himself to his roommate
column23: and a stowaway named Camel. One can't help but root for Jacob through the entire story. And to my complete delight
column24: it comes to a surprising and very satisfying conclusion.This is an excellent novel and I give it my highest recommendation. Well done Sara Gruen!Michele Cozzens is the author of It's Not Your Mother's Bridge Club"

column8: the movie was made for a PG-13 rating and though there were some mild situations and language
column11: where there was a lot of swearing and a few lewd descriptions that weren't necessary for the story in order for it to be a good one. If not for the cheesy sexual stuff and multiple F-bombs dropped
column12: I would have enjoyed the book more. The story itself is quite good
column13: but the delivery of it was lacking because of the language and overly-detailed sexual situations. So if I were to recommend one
column14: I'd tell people to choose the movie over the book. It's less crude
column16: a more satisfying experience. The story structure itself reminded me a lot of The Notebook by Nicholas Sparks."
column18: "summary": "I preferred the movie because it was PG -13 and had less bad language."

column6: "reviewText": "I had this book in my TBR pile and really wasn't in any sort of hurry to read it. Now

column6: "reviewText": "I endured this inartful

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is terrific.  How much you will enjoy it depends on what you are looking for.  As historical fiction---evoking the Depression Era and travelling circuses of a time gone by
column7: it is five stars.  As romantic fiction
column8: three and half stars.  The past is brought back superbly:  compelling and detailed.  The life seems awful on many levels
column11: so exciting and alive that a part of you is jealous of the characters living it---like the sailors of the British Navy in the Aubrey/Maturin series (seeMaster and Commander (Aubrey Maturin Series)).The romantic scenes are less well executed
column12: and the author does not well capture the sexual feelings of a 22-year-old man.  That is a small part of the story
column14: and is more than outweighed by the other bonus the book offers
column15: the reflections on aging from the protagonist at age 93.  These are powerful and thought-provoking.  I \"read\" the audible version of the book
column16: and the reader for the \"old\" Jacob alone would have made the book worthwhile.I recommend this strongly."

column6: "reviewText": "Get your tissue ready

column6: "reviewText": "This story has a circus
column7: a villain
column9: and a love story. What else could a summer reader wish for? I thoroughly enjoyed this novel. Granted
column11: but it is great fun.Jacob's experience as the an old man reminded me so much of the nursing home my mother died in. His experience as a young man reminded me of the stories my father told about the depression

column6: "reviewText": "This book was really engaging
column7: had good characters
column10: and a good ending.  I have read books that have been very good and then the ending seems to be rushed
column12: or just plain awful.  Loved this book."

column6: "reviewText": "What is a life worth? How do you judge if someone is worth saving? What does it mean to be human? What or who is really an animal? Why can an individual choose how to live but not how to die? Who has the power to answer these questions? How do you know that person is right?Hidden beneath this easy-to-read though dark coming of age romance is a novel that prompts the reader to ask the above through the reminiscing of protagonist Jacob Jankowski who is prisoner in fact to old age and in feeling to a nursing home. The story begins as the circus rolls into town and the flood of Jankowski's past full of pleasure
column7: joy
column10: regret & guilt washes over him.Sara Gruen brings the Circus Culture of the mid 20th century to life through meticulous research
column11: both the bright spot light and the grittier nature of transitory existence. Anyone who ever dreamed of running away to the big top or just dreamed of running away should read this book."

column6: "reviewText": "Ok
column7: well after reading the other reviews published mere hours ago i just couldn't help but put in my two cents worth!  Firstly i would like to recommend this book
column8: because i really enjoyed it!  It has been a little while since i have read it
column9: but it is a favourite of mine (and i would like to add that it is now ranked 62 in the top 100 list of my local bookshop! so hah!) and i thought it was really funny! (in a good way
column10: that is!)I am totally confused by some of the recent reviews that talk about Jacobs morals
column11: etc. blah blah blah.  I think these people should go back and read the whole book again because i really found Jacob to be a likeable character and think he was one of the few in circus who DID have morals and a conscience!Anyway
column13: funny and incredibly interesting (i just found the whole circus idea really fascinating) and I'm not ashamed to admit that i loved this book!  Obviously as it got a 4 1/2 star rating from over a thousand reviews i am not alone... i really recommend this book if you like a story that is well written
column14: original and not the norm! Great Reading!"

column6: "reviewText": "I'd like to think one day
column7: when I have nothing else to do but read until my heart's content (which is probably impossible to do btw) I will re-read every book that has hit my favorites list. Honestly though with all the newly discovered titles
column11: etc I fear I'll never get to revisit my beloveds anytime soon. But when (and if) that day comes
column12: Water for Elephants will be on that list!I've never really been a big circus fan - reading about them or attending them
column13: but I liked the atmosphere of circus life of the 1930s. It is both beautiful and gritty in detail. After reading this I must read more Great Depression era books. I can't imagine how hard it was to live in that time period and I find it fascinating and frightening.Bouncing between young and old Jacob's POV was actually a great way to read the novel. I felt as if I was re-living Jacob's memories as he did
column14: rather than being told a story.  Jacob is utterly honest and humble as a young man and it's hard not to like his character. Harsh reality is thrust upon him after he tragically loses his parents and is forced to find a way to survive without money or family. Normal life is hard but living life under the famous Benzini Brothers' big top is even harder. Despite elderly Jacob being extremely (and understandably) cranky (I probably wouldn't want to be around him - family or not) Gruen does a spectacular job portraying his life and state of mind at the assisted living facility.Gruen actually does a spectacular job at a lot of things. She delivers a cast of characters that become just as important to me as Jacob
column17: the larger-than-life elephant that is supposed to save the Benzini Brothers show from biting the dust. The characters are really the hands-down winner for me in this story. But it certainly was coupled with some amazing story-telling.I think I didn't give this one a solid 5 stars because the ending didn't quite sit well with me. While I'm glad of the outcome for Jacob I felt the HEA was sort of - slapped on
column18: for lack of a better term. Kind of like \"Come on
column19: let's hurry and wrap it up here\" ending...if that makes sense. It's happy (which made me happy; I happen to really like Jacob). Maybe a little too convenient for my tastes though. However
column20: I have a hunch that if the ending were any different I'd still have a problem with it. Maybe I just didn't want Jacob's story to end *shrugs* ...Definitely a good thing about a book
column21: if you ask me!As a side note I have not seen the movie adaptation but I want to. Nothing could really ruin the story for me but I'd hope the movie did some sort of justice to the book.**I received an eBook copy through AmazonPrime**"
column23: "summary": "Sad I waited so long to pick up!"

column6: "reviewText": "I read this book only because it was on my book club list. I had passed it up many times in my search for a \"good\" book to read. When it came time to read it for the book club I was not looking forward to it. All I can say now is WOW!!! I would have missed a great ride had I not been \"forced\" to read this WONDERFUL story. By the end I was cheering! I have since recomended it to many people and they all have had the same reaction. This is a keeper!"
column7: "overall": 5.0

column6: "reviewText": "After finishing a powerful and emotional novel like \"the Kite Runner\" i started to read \"water for elephants\". I am at chapter 8 and i am still hoping that this book will turn out to be better. Its written boring so far and the storyline is not making it any better. I know a lot of people will be shocked bout that comment
column7: but i will continue reading and i hope that it will get better. So far its quite boring to me.UPDATE:Well i did finish this book and i dont know how this book got so many 5 star ratings?????? did i miss something? The whole story was BORING and I really didnt care to much for the main characters. The old man telling the story was a good Idea but at the end it was simply dissapointing.If you didint finish the book yet
column8: then dont continue to read!From the first moment when he met August his wife we all knew what would happen.so that was not surprising at all.After reading and figuring out how august was acting up all the time it was also not hard to figure that he probbably had a mental problem. That was not surprising neither.I really wanted to like this book and i kept my word and finished it in the hope that it will get way better but .... no... this book is OVERRATED!"

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants took me by surprise. This book was really well-written. Not only does this author know how to tell a story
column7: she educates the reader without making it unreadable. She seamlessly wove the main characters story around the unknown story of circus life during 1930s. She offers a glimpse of animal treatment
column8: different types of jobs within and the classes that separate the workers
column9: the expectations given by towns on entertainment
column11: etc. The research is evident and I welcomed and looked forward to it. The book does have romance but it has so much more depth so I read freely
column12: not really anticipating the story between the hero and the heroine.Sara Gruen has made me a fan and has given me hope for modern writers."
column14: "summary": "One of the best well written books I've read in a long time..."

column6: "reviewText": "As always
column7: the book is better than the movie
column9: too! The author tells a first rate
column10: unique story that had me laughing at various points. There were also points I was in tears. Am looking forward to see what Ms. Gruen writes next."

column6: "reviewText": "Great book. Slow paced but with enough detail and grace to make it hard to put the book down. Recommended."
column7: "overall": 4.0

column6: "reviewText": "I just finished this book after three days of reading
column7: and I could not put the book down. It has been awhile since a book has had that type of impact on me. This book was excellent.I never really thought of the circus being around during the Great Depression. Everytime people hear 'Great Depresion' people automatically think of the soup kitchens and as Ms. Gruen put it 'hobo jungles'. I was pleased to learn a little bit about the circus during this time period and learn that there were harsh treatments and conditions of the animals AND workers in this book (which is horrible because I love animals
column8: and people shouldn't be treated like nothing). I have read a few reviews regarding the volgar and violent content of the book. Let's face it
column9: this is what happened (or at least similar to what was so to say). There were no strict enforcements on labor law or even animal laws such as PETA back then. This was life; workers and performers thought of it as such. It is unpleasant to read and even learn about but it was a different time and a different world. Just like other tragic times in history (wars
column12: etc.). As for the volgar parts
column14: just part of life back then too and I suppose Ms. Gruen wanted it to be properly formatted.This book is very descriptive
column16: has an excellent plot and an unexpected ending. This was unlike any other endings to be honest
column17: and I was shocked and pleased with it. The pauses between young Jacob and old Jacob got me too
column18: just because I feel sorry for old Jacob and happy he's able to go back to an important time to him. Got you thinking about the people in those situations who have nobody left and feel like a burden to your family just to come visit.If you are looking for a love story
column20: this book is for you! :) Five stars!"

column6: "reviewText": "At 23 life can be difficult for anyone
column7: but for Jacob Jankowski
column9: difficult is a bit of an understatement. Not only has he just tragically lost both of his parents
column10: but thanks to the bank he is now broke
column11: and homeless. Unclear as to what to do next Jacob starts walking
column12: unfortunately a few hours later he realizes he is lost and his feet are covered in blisters. In short... he's no better off than when he started
column13: but... all of that is about to change when he hears a train is coming his way.  With no clue as to where he is
column15: Jacob makes a decision; hop the train and see where it takes him
column16: little did he know that that would be the circus. Finding himself knee deep in the Benzini Brother's most spectacular show on Earth; Jacob quickly discovers that his \"previous\" life may (in fact) do him justice in his \"new\" one
column17: and takes on a job as the circus' official veterinarian. With animals however
column18: comes their performers and that's where things start to get sticky. Marlena is beautiful
column21: and more importantly... taken. Will Jacob be able to control his feelings for the one person he is forbidden from caring about? Why and how are people disappearing off of the train
column22: and what REALLY happened that fateful day when the world flipped upside down and all hell broke loose?Gruen is very clearly a masterful storyteller.  Not only did she deliver a gasp worthy love story
column23: but the background in which her story took place was so artfully crafted that after only 1 chapter I found it impossible to put down.  The detail involved in creating the grit of a traveling circus (while at the same time tacking such issues as the Great Depression and Prohibition) was genius
column24: and to do it through the eyes of 1 man at very different times in his life (23 and 90 or 93) added a depth and emotional connection that would have otherwise been lost if penned differently. The story as a whole was perfectly plotted
column25: leaving zero downtime for the readers mind to wonder off or lose focus of the moral dilemmas at hand
column26: and at the end of the day became: just another one of those books that sucks you in and doesn't let you go.Overall...a wonderful book and an interesting peek into classic American history.Happy Reading my fellow Kindle-ites and remember: animals may not be able to talk to you
column27: but they can understand you. Be nice"

column6: "reviewText": "Sure it is a well researched book.  The detail and description of circus life is very realistic and at times downright disgusting.  But what else does this book have that made one of my friends rave that this was the best book she had every read.  I'll tell you what....nothing.  I partly read this book on the recommendation of friend but I also wanted to read it because it was described as a murder mystery book.  A mystery murder it is not and by the end of this book I wanted all of the main characters to go away too!  I won't spill any beans but frankly this book deserved less time on the best seller's list and more time on the bottom of my discard pile (the books I will never read again or books that I would like to forget).  You make up your mind."

column6: "reviewText": "This was my book club's book this month.  I don't always like what they pick
column7: but I give each book 100 pages before giving up on it.  I liked this book immediately.The main character is in a nursing home and the story goes between his life there and his memories of his younger days when he worked for a circus.The imagery is excellent and you can feel the movement of the train as the author is describing the setup of the cars and where everyone rides.  You can smell the disinfectant in the nursing home when Jacob is there.I guess one of the reasons I liked this book is that I've never read something on this topic.  It was very interesting to learn about the different aspects of the circus and its struggle for survival.This is slower reading
column8: you can't plow through it like one of those books you read on the beach
column9: but you will enjoy every moment!"

There are some great characters in the novel and it has a lovely ending with a twist."

column6: "reviewText": "I had to force myself to finish this and was continually disgusted with the animal cruelty. Maybe I should have stuck w/the gut instinct that I don't usually care for historical fiction? The writing was not \"stellar\" - I just don't see all the hype but for the millions that loved it I'm glad for you - just be prepared if you haven't read it to wince w/some of the scenes."

column6: "reviewText": "MILD SPOILERS--I'm a little confused as to why this novel is classified as literary fiction
column7: as it's lacking the strong character development and emotional complexity that most literary fiction strives for.  I'm aware I'm in the minority
column8: but I can't honestly say I enjoyed this book.  It was very predictable
column9: and the characters were wooden.  Marlena has zero depth--and Joseph isn't much better.  They fall in love
column10: but it seems more like the affair happens because the author wrote it into the plot
column11: not because these were two developed
column12: real people whose minds and hearts shared something magical.  A few of the secondary characters have more detail
column13: but they never go beyond superficial personality traits.The elephant is the absolute best part
column14: and once I read that Gruen was inspired by old stories and photographs of real circus elephants and performers
column15: I wished she'd gone ahead and written a non-fiction book so she could really delve into the struggle of the era and the horrible treatment of these animals.  She makes aspects of the circus interesting--in fact
column16: that's why I kept reading even after I'd given up on the story having any real complexity or resonance
column17: but the whole book is littered with anachronistic language that disturbs the realism she's aiming for.She's trying to get at some very deep issues (mental illness
column20: the traumas of the Great Depression) but it's all very superficial.  She never quite digs deep enough to give these real complexity or power
column21: so all of the characters have very obvious
column23: predictably shallow reactions to these deep issues
column24: and I was left feeling a bit like I was reading a kid's slightly juvenile interpretation of events.  Overall
column25: disappointing and even a little simplistic.  The frame of Joseph in the old folks' home is the richest and most emotionally complicated part of the text--until the ending
column26: which is utterly unrealistic and saccharine."

column6: "reviewText": "This book was beautifully written. I felt so connected to the characters and the descriptions made the characters that much more vivid in my mind.The content regarding animal cruelty was hard to read for me. I cried a few times as I read them.With that said
column7: I think it is beautiful and honorable for these elephants to be acknowledged and their names remembered as their stories are further shared with the world.The details in the book regarding the workers and the environment of the circus were accurate and well portrayed.I felt a connection with all of the characters not just their Marlena and Jacob."

column6: "reviewText": "I adore this book.  I love the characters and they are so well written as to visualize them.  I like the use of first person narration of the main character Jacob Jankowski.  It is interesting to go from the present to the past
column7: and back.  It really integrates the progression of the character rather than a linear progression.  I read this book a couple of years ago
column9: I found I couldn't exactly remember the outcome and was like reading it anew.  The character of Rosie is one of my favorites
column10: inspite of the fact that she is an Elephant.  August is hard to take
column11: yet one can see before it's revealed that he clearly is mentally unwell.  The tension of the triangular relationship was reminiscent of the trio in Sophies Choice.  Walter the clown and Camel are both very sympathetic characters
column12: though Walter's true nature is revealed slowly from being a crusty
column13: mean spirited person to one with great compassion.  The historical details of the depression era and circus life is so well drawn as to feel you have been working on a circus throughout this story.I highly recommend this book."

column6: "reviewText": "Loved this book!  It was a reminder of my childhood experience in a small town when the circus came
column7: with a definite look at the seedy side of the circus life.  The story was filled with the good and bad that exists in every element of society.  I loved the author's style of writing from the memory of a man in his 90's
column8: which also gave the reader empathy for that stage of life.  Great ending as well!"

column6: "reviewText": "I loved this book.  It was very honest and doesn't hold anything back.  It really pulls you in.  Once you start reading
column7: you can't seem to put it down."

column6: "reviewText": "This is quite an unusual book
column7: but the story is told very well. I recommended it to friends."

column6: "reviewText": "Let me say at the outset of this review that I usually read literary fiction.  This book was a departure for me
column7: one that I took on the faith of the 1600+ positive reviews.  Those reviews misled me
column8: I'm afraid.It's mystifying why so many reviewers loved this book.  It's not a bad story
column9: a fairly straightforward narrative without any literary flourishes
column10: written in plain language and present tense. Certainly the author did her research so she could use the right lingo and details.  Flash-forwards to the protagonist's current life in a nursing home only provide a pretense for the ending
column11: unfortunately.  The plot is so thin that until about 3/4ths of the way through
column12: I was convinced there wasn't one.  Likewise
column13: the characters are fairly thinly realized
column14: except for the \"paranoid schizophrenic\" villain and the intelligent elephant
column15: Rosie.  I found myself wondering why I even liked the protagonist
column16: who fashioned himself as a kind of savior for a couple of victimized lesser players.  Recently bereaved
column17: the protagonist's experience of bereavement is completely absent from the book
column18: which I found unrealistic at best.That said
column19: I was surprised that I stuck it out and read to the end
column20: which is why I didn't give the book a lower rating.  In all honesty
column21: the last quarter of the book is quite possibly the best
column22: when the main character finally acts on all his misguided desires. However
column23: the final scene disappointed me; it seemed a bit too contrived.Light reading
column24: this one.  If you want to read for 30 minutes before bed
column26: because it doesn't not require much thought or deconstruction."

column6: "reviewText": "I bought this book in September 2007. That means I had it in my drawer for almost five years and I just kept postponing reading it (I bought it along with many other books and it took me a while to read them all; then other books got on the way and so on).  When the movie came I refused to watch it knowing I should read the book first. And so I finally made up my mind and did it. It's a great book. I'm not a circus fan but the love story is precious. It was interesting to read about the Great Depression and how hard it was to make a living. I liked the pictures inside the book. I think they were a nice touch from the author. And of course I rented the movie and watched it after reading the book. Guess what? The book is better!"

column6: "reviewText": "I was given this book years ago. Looked at the cover and didnt feel compelled to read it.It sat on my bookcase for years.The movie came out and then the books were everywhere.So

column6: "reviewText": "I never got to see the movie so decided to read the book. I had heard from another person that they didn't like it. But I don't listen to other reviews and I'm glad I didn't. I really enjoyed this book. It was entertaining

column6: "reviewText": "One of the greatest books that I have ever read. I have yet to see the movie

column6: "reviewText": "The book is okay so far
column7: but I'm very distracted by the horrible Kindle formatting.  I've never had a problem with a Kindle book before
column8: but this one is full of gaps and spacing problems. Dialogue is separated by abnormally huge gaps
column9: but author-intended spaces intended to denote a pause are the same gaps as the extraneous ones; in other words
column10: the intentional spaces are lost in the shuffle.  This makes the book very hard to read and follow
column11: since I'm never sure if it's a \"Kindle\" gap or an \"author\" gap.  This was very poorly digitized.  It almost makes the book unreadable because it is such a distraction."

column6: "reviewText": "This is a great read
column7: one you can devour---and I don't even like circuses. The reviews piqued my interest and Water for Elephants was even better than I expected. Pleasing on every level---prose style
column9: denouement. Actually you will probably guess part of the ending but it is ever so satisfying. I sat and thought about this one a long time after I finished reading."

column6: "reviewText": "I experienced to this book as an audiobook
column7: so my opinion is shaped by that.  Also
column8: I scanned a few 1- and 2-star reviews before I read the book
column9: to see what some people didn't like
column10: so some of my review is addressing others' opinions.First
column11: the narrators for the audio book I thought did a pretty good job. The young Jacob did a wonderful job using varying voices for the various circus people and I forgot they were all spoken by the same person. The old Jacob's voice was great for a crotchety old man
column12: but still clear enough to understand. 4 out of 5 stars for narration.I thought the story overall was good. I did not feel as much of a connection to the characters as I would have liked and that may be due to the \"shallow\" writing that some people have complained about in reviews. I did laugh out loud in the car listening to some of the narration by the \"old Jacob\" though
column13: I thought his character was amusing.I don't claim to know much of anything factual about the early 20th century or life in the circus (then or now) for that matter. With that said
column14: I thought the descriptions of this FICTIONAL circus and recent college graduate veterinarian were nicely done. I felt like I understood what the narrator was talking about and how he was feeling (most of the time).Yes
column15: there was some animal cruelty and there was some sex/masturbation. While I don't particularly enjoy reading about animals being hurt or neglected
column16: I felt that the things they were doing seemed as if they might have been done during that time period due to desperation/ignorance or that was just what everyone else did. As for the sex/masturbation
column18: I don't generally enjoy reading those things
column19: but I thought they might have been appropriate for the time and characters.  How else is a little person going to get physical pleasure in a time before \"political correctness\" where his mother SOLD him to the circus to be a circus freak/clown because of his stature?  The sex between the characters was inevitable and if someone is so offended by it that they quit the book
column20: maybe they should go back to reading Dick and Jane (unless you're also offended by the word/name Dick).Overall
column21: I enjoyed the story. Interesting time period
column23: and good narration from two different perspectives of the same character. I've never read any books about the circus and after reading this one
column24: I might have to find some others. This is the first book I've read by Sara Gruen and I have another book by her \"Ape House\" in the car and ready to listen to later today."

column6: "reviewText": "If you want to feel the sorrow and excitement of joining the circus and the sorrow of old age in our country
column7: Ms. Gruen could not have crafted a better story.  The protagonist
column10: joins the circus and therein begins the story of corrupt managment
column11: the wonderful animals and the class system among the workers and the performers.  The reader is provided with historical information while the author paints a vivid picture of the circus train and its dynamics.  She interweaves a touching love story and a strong respect for circus animals
column13: the elephant who only understood Polish commands! Read it - you won't be wasting your time."

column6: "reviewText": "When this book came out in hardcover
column7: I passed it by.  No interest in reading about circus freaks.  When the book came out in paperback
column8: I passed it by.  Still did not sound interesting.  Three people recommended it to me and then
column10: a friend gave it to me after she finished it.  Still
column11: I waited a month or so before beginning it.  Within the first few chapters
column12: I was intrigued.  I loved the descriptions - created a definite picture in my mind.  I loved the characters - I wanted to know what would happen to them.  Although I thought the end was somewhat predictable
column14: I found this a very enjoyable read."

column6: "reviewText": "One published review of this book described it as a \"romance between star-crossed lovers\" ... what an unengaged
column7: superficial understatement that is!It's ever so much more. Among other things
column8: it's a young man's coming-of-age; it's about a test of character and compassion in the demanding
column10: carnival atmosphere of both the circus and the Great Depression
column11: all accomplished while the death of the young man's parents is still fresh.You'll smell the blood & stench of the circus
column12: feel the splinters of the train's floorboards
column13: and breath dust as the musty tents slap bare ground at yet another town of rubes; you'll empathize with the rib-thin sadness of the (mostly) sweet
column15: circus animals; you'll feel the protagonist's love
column18: and anger as he makes the choices that allow him to become a man. You'll see these same qualities shine forth in the 90-year old (or is it 93-year old?) version of the man.I found it astounding that the author of his book is a woman. My experience of myself and my male friends as young men
column19: and of my father as an old man in assisted living
column20: ring true with the nuances embeded in this book. It's also evident that substantial research was necessary to give the book the authentic feel that it has. And not only does this book reverberate with atmosphere
column22: and passion; it's a good read! The pacing
column23: plot and narrative make for a non-stop adventure. Highly recommended."
column25: "summary": "The dust & dirt of the circus and Great Depression... much more than a love story."

column6: "reviewText": "It is such a pleasure to dive into a book and read wonderful prose.  As a busy busy person who is a reader I found myself stealing moments where ever I could to read this book.  The story held my interest on evey page and I learned alot about the circus
column7: cruelty and class.  Read this book it is delicious."
column9: "summary": "Much has been written about it already......................."

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants amazed me.  It was not at all what I expected.  I knew it was about a circus
column7: and obviously for the title
column8: an elephant was involved.  What I was not prepared for however
column9: was the cruelty it showed.  And I don't doubt for a minute
column10: that even though this was fiction
column11: that these atrocities didn't happen in real circuses.We are introduced to a death in the prologue.  While it is fuzzy and hard to tell who's who
column12: we are witnesses to a scene that the narrator
column14: has viewed and never forgotten. Mayhem abounds as we discover that the menagerie of a circus is on the stampede.We are then reintroduced to Jacob
column16: as he is a resident at a nursing home.  He is ninety three
column18: he can't keep it straight and a circus is in town and being set up within sight of the nursing home.  This causes him to reminisce about his time spent with the Benzini Brothers circus.As a runaway college student
column19: after the death of his parents
column20: he finds himself hopping a train that turns out to be part of the circus train.  There
column22: he is taken in by an older man named Camel who secures him a job with the circus mucking stalls
column23: which later turns into a position as the circus's veterinarian.He falls in love with Marlena
column24: the wife of his schizophrenic boss August.  While he keeps his love hidden
column26: dangerous and unpredictable makes life tough for Jacob in the circus while in his better moments is a best friend to him.He also makes the acquaintance of Walter
column27: a dwarf clown whom he bunks with and together they help Camel in his time of need.  He also makes an unlikely friend in Rosie
column28: an elephant picked up from another failing circus whom he feels a bond with and devastation at her treatment from the cruel August.Throughout the book it cuts back and forth from Jacob at the nursing home
column29: to his reminisces of the circus and its happenings.  One of the ending chapters recaps the prologue
column30: only with more detail.Gruen does such a marvelous job on this book that you would believe she had traveled with a circus.  But she hadn't
column31: all her knowledge came form extensive research and interviews.  The result is this novel
column32: gritty and real and it keeps you at the edge of your seat wondering what is going to happen.  Jacob's tale is one I could read over and over again.  By far this turned out to be one of my favorite books.  And the ending
column33: well in hopes to get you reading this book
column34: the ending was perfect and real fitting for such a wonderful tale.  Its well worth the read.Water For ElephantsPublished in 2006331 pages"

column6: "reviewText": "I thoroughly enjoyed every word of this book.  I was actually quite disappointed when I reached the end.  I recommend this book to everyone I know!Water for Elephants: A Novel"
column7: "overall": 5.0

column6: "reviewText": "This paperback has sat on my bookshelf for two years and last week I finally got round to reading it - was I surprised! Quite simply
column7: I found Water for Elephants an exceptional read and one that any reader should not miss. Briefly the novel is during the Depression in the USA and it recalls how a circus struggles to survive. The story is seen from the eyes of Jacob Jankowski
column8: an unqualified vet who jumped on the Benzini Brothers circus train
column9: one evening after the shocking death of his parents.The action in Water for Elephants is just right; more than sufficiently paced to keep the reader glued to the pages. There are flashbacks reverting back to the nursing home of the present-day
column10: where Jacob is finding his aged infirmity unbearable
column11: but somehow this only adds to the depth of the story.Sara Gruen has created a circus world that's believable; one that you feel right in the midst of and this is carried through with her characters.  Uncle Al
column13: (the animal trainer) are characters you'll hate. Whereas Marlena
column15: and Camel are character's you'll love. Chief protagonist is Jacob Jankowski and I found myself completely empathising with him. His struggle to fit into circus life
column16: gain acceptance from his peers and deal with the urges of his love interest
column17: make him a hugely engaging character.I highly recommend this book. It's a gripping story and is one of those novels which will both shock and thrill you. The stark poverty of the early nineteen hundreds is interspersed with details of the emotional deprivation the main character
column18: Jacob experiences in a nursing home during his latter years. Yet in both settings a light is shone on acts of kindness which define our humanity and reinforce the fragile dignity of those who are almost overwhelmed by their plights. There is a social history dimension to the story which enhances its value and impact. This is easily one of the better books I've ever read."

column6: "reviewText": "Beautiful and enchanting tale set in a circus. Excellent story that is beautifully written and utterly absorbing. Highly enjoyable - recommend!"
column7: "overall": 5.0

column6: "reviewText": "I bought the audio of this and was enthralled and wouldnt get out of my car for two weeks.  I bought the book also

column8: the work reads evenly and there was nothing that I didn't like about it.  Pleaded with Hollywood to make it into a movie
column9: but probably won't watch it as I don't like the actors
column10: as in my head Tom Hanks was the father.Anyway great book

column6: "reviewText": "baby boomers beware
column7: if you have an aging parent who brought you up on stories about the depression and a relative that joined the circus for work
column8: or vice versa ( that should cover several million people) you will enjoy this book.it isn't about the circus
column10: its about life and love.a truly beautiful book."
column12: "summary": "water for elephants is water for the soul"

column6: "reviewText": "This was an incredible read and a quick read if you want something to captivate you for a trip.  For fictional history it's clear the author did her homework.  The author took many real events and spun them into the journey of a fictional character through a composite circus during the depression.  The story is exciting and hard to put down.  The intro leaves you wondering throughout the whole story.  Its very easy to relate to the main character and feel what he feels
column7: stress
column9: love...  I can't say much else without giving away the books little secrets."

column6: "reviewText": "I received an advance reader's copy of this book
column7: and gave it to my neighbors to read. They thought it was ok
column8: but no great shakes. But every bookseller I spoke to loved
column9: loved this book. So I decided to read it. *I love this novel* and cannot put it down! Gruen really fleshes out the characters in this book. And what I especially enjoy is the strong sense of time and place she evokes
column10: she recreates a real slice of Americana. Water for Elephants is set during the Depression
column11: a time long before I was born. I feel as if I much better understand what life was like for Americans during this period
column12: and the importance circuses played in providing some escape from people's otherwise desperate lives. And I feel as if I glimpsed what life is really like in a circus
column13: behind the facade of magic and glamour. I heartily recommend this novel to anyone wanting a compelling read
column14: even though there were some aspects of the plot that I could see coming from a long way off. The real photographs from Depression-era circuses included at the beginning of each chapter was a nice touch
column15: as was the striking cover art. The ending could have been heartbreakingly sad
column16: but it turned out to be uplifting
column17: made me turn the last page with a sigh that I had finished this fairy tale. I highly recommend this book
column18: now I know what all the bookseller buzz is about."

column6: "reviewText": "The quality of the writing is not in question. My problem is that I did not find the characters or plot to be engaging. I did not enjoy the book and have no interest in seeing the movie."

column6: "reviewText": "I enjoyed this book; it was like an interesting history lesson or a memoir and I learned a lot about the horrors of living with the circus in the early 20th century. The relationships weren't as well developed as I like
column7: neither were the characters. But the variety of characters made the story very interesting. The concept of Jacob as as old man remembering the circus is a good idea
column8: but I didn't like Jacob as an old man; he was grumpy
column10: and aloof. I thought it took Jacob out of character because as a young man he was very mild mannered and pleasant. I don't think that part made the story better."

column6: "reviewText": "The vivid descriptions of the characters and setting
column7: the obvious depth of research the author did in order to write this book
column8: the historic photos dispersed throughout the story
column10: the seemless transfer between past and present
column11: and the most satisfying ending makes this read one of the best I have encountered in a long time. I just could not put this book down. Amazing all around!"

column6: "reviewText": "I have never thought of giving a book a \"content suitability for certain audiences\" rating before I read this one.  I would have to give this an \"X: Adults Only\" rating due to the explicit sexual content
column7: violence and language which I found unnecessary for this story line.This story tells a tale of two time lines in the life of a circus veterinarian. It begins as the elderly version of the man who is forced into memories of his youth. Through the story
column8: he is transported back and forth between the two time lines. This is the first dual time line story that I've actually enjoyed. With the exception of the \"X\" rated parts. This is a delightful easy read. The author has a talent for description which allows the reader to easily become absorbed by the story line.  She has done quite a bit of research into circuses of the past
column9: which helps to make the story more authentic."
column11: "summary": "I have never thought of giving a book a \"content suitability for certain audiences\" rating before I read this one."

column6: "reviewText": "Jacob Jankowski is just about through with veterinary school when fate switches things up a bit and turns his world upside down.  He decides to hop a train and ends up in the middle of the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth.  The Great Depression was just in its early stages so for Jacob having a paying job was lucky but he also found parts of the circus life to be a living hell.  As he was just shy of his degree
column7: Jacob ends up being put in charge of the menagerie
column8: the starring animals of the show.He then meets Marlena
column9: the beautiful equestrian act star who happens to be married to August
column10: the twisted and manipulative animal trainer for the show.Uncle Al
column11: the big boss of the Benzini Brothers
column12: makes a habit of visiting other circus shows that fold and go under.  There he has his pick of their performers and animals.  It is at one such place that he picks up Rose
column13: an untrainable elephant.  He hopes her to be the savior of this traveling show that struggles a bit to keep up with Ringling Brothers
column14: the top of the line.  Jacob finds an instant connection with Rosie and the show and his life start to change.The book alternates between Jacobs time with the circus and his \"present\" time where he is 90 (\"or maybe 93\"...as he can't quite remember) and in an assisted living home.  A circus has come to town and is visible out of the windows of the home.  No one knows Jacobs past at the home when a new resident comes along and claims he carried water for the elephants in the circus when he was younger.  This kind of woos the ladies and makes Jacob (who is much the curmudgeon by this time in his life) very upset and sets off a string of trouble for him at the home.The prologue when read at the beginning of the book very much drew me in to the story.  When the same story makes its appearance toward the end of the book it is amazingly powerful.  You'll just have to read it for yourself to truly see what I'm talking about.You can really tell that the author has a love of the circus and has done her research to bring the most accuracy she can to this tale.  I honestly thought when I heard about this book from everyone that it was really not my cup of tea.  I'm not one to just read love stories...I have to have some kind of conflict or suspense or something along those lines to keep my interest.  That being said
column15: this book does not lack for anything.  It is really a great read and I would suggest giving it a shot even if you are having doubts about whether you will love it or not.  Fantastic read....hoping to see the movie and also hoping it will not let me down."

column6: "reviewText": "I was torn between two or three stars. I read this book for my book club
column7: otherwise it is unlikely I would have picked it up considering my backlog.Personally I didn't find anything wow-ish or over the top astounding with this story. Besides that it takes place in a circus. It had its moments of course
column8: which makes me think that what really makes you like a book is not sometimes the overall story
column9: but a couple of scenes that really stand out. And this had a handful of those
column10: especially those set in the present time
column11: which were the only ones to actually pull my emotional strings
column12: which usually doesn't take much I'm afraid
column13: and considering that this book didn't stir much in me overall. Not even the traditional `big twist' scene riled me up. I actually read a paragraph past it then did a double take on `oh that was suppose to be it'."

column6: "reviewText": "I sampled this book because it's so popular and the price was right. The author's voice captured me with the authenticity of the elderly Jacob. Literally seconds after I finished reading the sample
column7: I hit \"buy now.\" One of the most brilliant techniques in the book
column9: is the little jolt the author created every time the point of view switches from young Jacob to old Jacob
column10: and it makes you flinch as though you too have been wrenched from the prime of your life into the body of a decrepit codger in a nursing home.The ending is perfect and satisfyingThe scenes depicting cruelty to animals were emotionally difficult to read
column11: though. If that kind of thing bothers you
column12: you may not enjoy the story."

It is only by the grace of the writer that the elephant didn't strike out at all of the obnoxious people who let the beatings occur!Some of the other reviews say much of what I thought about this book and the writing.  The characters are thin
column7: not lovable

column10: is more real than that with Marlena.  I don't recommend this book for those who want good writing.  This is rather amateurish in so many ways.  I do admire that the author did the research... but her execution of the story and the story line leave a lot to be desired.  I felt the writing and plot itself wasn't much above that of a 'bodice ripper'.  I was disappointed."

column6: "reviewText": "Here are my problems with this book:1) Remove the sex and animal cruelty scenes
column7: and it reads like a script from a bad Disney movie.2) The main character is shallow and throughout the book I had no idea what made him do the things he did. Why did he join the circus in the first place? Not once did he mention missing his dead parents
column9: school etc. Didn't he have any memories from his childhood

column15: and that's probably because the writer had absolutely no idea how to do that properly.3) I get the feeling that some people liked this book simply because it was so easy to read even Bobo the monkey would get it
column16: since it lacked any depth or complication in the script or the characters. Readers who rate this kind of books with 5 stars have obviously no idea what real literature is.4) The dialogue was poor
column17: and so blatantly contemporary that it made me angry at the writer's lazyness of doing her research properly.5) It was so obvious that the writer was a woman that you could not get it out of your mind even for a minute.6) I'm no prude
column18: but I'm sure images of the masturbating dwarf will be haunting me for a long time.7) Trust a good old disaster/great accident to get rid of the bad guys for you. That way you don't get to kill them yourself and become (gasp!) a bad guy yourself. I would be curious to see how the main character would get out of all that mess if the stampede had not happened.8) If you owned a circus and half a brain
column19: would you hire a 90 year old cripple whith serious health problems who ran away from a nursing home and whom you have just met? Yeah
column20: I didn't think so.9) I can't really recall the sex scenes

column25: as was the rest of the book."

column6: "reviewText": "It doesn't happen often where you are just reading a book for the shear beauty of the writing. Water for Elephants may just be that book.There isn't anything truly original about the story but there is something inspired in the creation of her characters and the telling of the story.The beauty of Gruen's prose had me turning pages without a care in the world."

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is an unusual story that I found captivating and difficult to put down.  The story is well written and provides a glimpse into circus life and the cruel times during the early years in the twentieth century.  I would recommend it to anyone looking for a fast paced story that is a wee bit like Grapes of Wrath but less dark."
