column6: "reviewText": "This was a selection for our book group last month and although I'm glad I read it
column7: I'm carting ASAP it to our local used bookstore since I don't have the stomach to read it again.I'll let other reviewers take care of the synopsis and author information. What struck me about this book was the author's handling of the violence against animals--human and otherwise. Sara Gruen takes the reader on some kind of amazing highwire act: we teeter on a fine line between wanting to throw the book down because we can't bear to read another page rife with brutality
column8: yet still we are compelled to edge our way another inch closer to her bittersweet and satisfying (if somewhat unbelievable) conclusion.I'm interested to see what else Ms. Gruen has in store for us."
column11: but difficult to get through some violent passages"

column6: "reviewText": "Water For Elephants has to be the best novel I've read in a long time.  I read all the time and I rarely read a book that I don't like but this book has to go to the top of the list right up there with The Lord of the Rings and Anna Karenina.  I had been told by several people what a phenomenal story it was for some time and I decided to make it one of my summer reads since it is hard for me to really get into books during the rest of the year (I teach).  One of my students was reading it in May and told me how great it was.  I refused to allow her to tell me anything about it because I was determined to read it as soon as summer began.  It took me a while but I am so glad I finally got around to it.This is a book that is easy to read and really pulls you into the story.  It reminded me of the film Titanic in terms of characters.  I have to say that if you are looking for a book that is truly engaging and pulls at every emotion you've got then don't wait any longer. Read this novel and enjoy!  I didn't want it to end and I can't wait to see how the film is compared to the book.  Only a few novels I've read really stick with me for life and this one is one of them.  You will not regret reading Water For Elephants by Sara Gruen."
column7: "overall": 5.0
column8: "summary": "Best novel I've read in a long time"

column6: "reviewText": "This book is an absolute must read. I would literally read faster just so I could get more of it read before I had to stop. column18: and other fauna. It doesn't take Jacob long to meet Marlena

column24: a talented performing elephant; finds his own voice; siezes true love; and makes his way in the world.This is a great book. It's entertaining and easy to read

I thought that the switch between the two worlds is great because on one side you see this young man who has his whole life ahead of him and then you see where he is today.I loved when he talked about the animals and how he took care of them. Once he mentioned that he was a vet student

column23: and although you can interpret it two ways

column6: "reviewText": "I picked up \"Water for Elephants\" on a whim because I liked the title and the premise was cool: Old-timey circus workers rescue a trained elephant from cruelty. I understood that
column7: while the story was fiction
column8: the author did some research and incorporated several real-life incidents. So
column10: I actually crossed the threshold of a physical Barnes & Noble
column11: picked \"Water for Elephants\" off a wooden shelf
column12: and presented my plastic card to a human cashier. For all this effort
column13: I truly hoped the novel would be superb. In some ways
column15: no.\"Water for Elephants\" is the story of the struggling Benzini Brothers circus
column16: for which the main character and narrator
column18: works as a veterinarian. Jacob falls in love with Marlena
column19: a kind and beautiful performer. Unfortunately
column20: Marlena is married to the violently temperamental animal trainer
column21: August. When the circus acquires an elephant
column22: Jacob and Marlena struggle together to defend the sweet pachyderm against August's rages. The story divulges the slimy underbelly of circus life
column23: including gross mistreatment of both human workers and animals
column24: right up to the stunning climax when Marlena ends August's reign of terror.Gruen alternates the novel's setting between a contemporary nursing home where 93-year-old Jacob now lives in a state of semi-dementia
column25: and the 1931 traveling circus. In the nursing home
column26: as Jacob waits for his family to escort him to a modern circus
column27: he wafts in and out of lucidity and mentally revisits his old Benzini Brothers days. Although the flashback technique feels a little worn and
column30: it does set up a finely constructed and sentimental ending
column31: which is one of the novel's strengths.Aside from the tender conclusion
column32: the story itself has other redeeming qualities. The plot is engaging enough to keep you reading
column33: especially as it nears the climax. Also
column34: Gruen exposes the abuses that occurred in depression-era circuses and
column35: which I fear
column36: probably still exist to some extent. Several scenes are emotionally excruciating
column37: but responsible consumers should be aware of ugly realities.Unfortunately
column39: the characters are shallowly constructed. I didn't walk away with a lasting identification with any of them
column40: and in fact
column41: by the time I wrote this post
column42: I had to look up all of their names. Also
column43: Gruen's writing style is flat and unmemorable. While the premise was promising
column44: her blasé rendering diminished what might have been a great novel in the hands of a more skilled wordsmith.If you care about animals
column45: you want a good story
column46: and you're not a finicky reader
column47: then step right up! \"Water for Elephants\" will entertain and amaze
column48: and it may even spur you to reconsider your attitude toward traveling animal shows. But if you're hungry for something profound and beautiful
column49: then move along
column50: folks. There are lots of bigger
column51: better shows out there.(You can find more of my book reviews at ninasbookieblog.blogspot.com.)"

I would love a comment from ANYONE who can tell me how the Bible's story of Jacob (Genesis) was incorporated into this novel! Did I miss something??? I just don't get it! I say!"

column6: "reviewText": "Jacob Jankowski is a student at Cornell Veterinarian School.  He gets the heart-breaking news that his parents have died in a car crash.  In the throes of the great depression
column7: Jacob finds out there is nothing left of their estate.  He tries to finish his exams but cannot.  Jacob takes the next train out of town.  Inadvertently
column8: he finds himself on the Benzini Brothers Circus train.  Jacob is hired on and becomes immersed in the circus life.  He also falls in love with Marlena
column9: one of the star performers married to August
column10: the equestrian trainer.  Jacob is telling his story some 70 years later as a 93 year old patient in a nursing home.  Present day happenings are interspersed with his memories of life back in '31.  The circus chapters start with historical photographs lending to the authenticity of events.  Mesmerizing writing
column12: and actual documented circus events combine to make this an exceptional novel to enjoy!"

column6: "reviewText": "Pluses: This novel is well constructed and well-written (with the exception of a few too many \"outrageously long eyelashes\" describing the elephant) and the main characters well-drawn. The pace of the plot and the use of flashbacks work very well and speed things smoothly along.  The sensitivity between nursing home resident Jacob and favorite nurse Rosemary is beautifully portrayed
column7: and Jacob's observations in the nursing home seem right on target.Minuses: (1) Not enough solid background research into the psyche of the lead character (Jacob) as an almost-veterinarian (moreover
column8: he is also son of a veterinarian).  There were passages where his feelings for and about animals were almost entirely ignored.  In general
column9: there would have been more solid creativity if the author had explored and deepened the relationship of the vet with the animals.  I was expecting Jacob to develop a very deep understanding of at least the elephant
column10: leading to a very strong bond
column11: etc.  He goes through the motions
column12: but I never believe he really understands the elephant
column13: and this is one of the most important parts of the story.(2) Conversely
column14: too much attention is given the run-of-the-mill sexual awakening and human love story of the main character.  I don't mind that it's part of the novel
column15: but I was expecting a deep
column16: enchanting bond between human and animals
column17: which would set the novel apart from the ho-hum.  For me
column18: this borders on a Romance Novel
column19: and should be advertised as such.(3) There was just barely enough information about the circus to hold the story up
column20: and there could have been richer texture by beefing up the details about circus life.Summary: If you happen to have read Waller's -The Bridges of Madison County-(another book that caused a big stir
column21: even though it was basically a romance novel)
column22: as well as a perfect gem of a book called -Fried Green Tomatoes at the Whistlestop Cafe- (Fannie Flagg's masterpiece that was almost as good on film) and if you've read Berger's -Little Big Man- one of the most creative uses of the flashbacks of an very aged man (not so good on film)...put these 3 together and you can imagine what -Water for Elephants- is like.Better yet
column23: if you haven't read Fried Green Tomatoes or Little Big Man
column24: GO READ THOSE INSTEAD of Water for Elephants.  And if you're interested in the circus
column25: I recommend Bruce Feiler's -Under the Big Top-."
column27: "summary": "Bridges of Madison County + Fried Green Tomatoes + Little Big Man"

column6: "reviewText": "The story was good but had too many swear words for my taste. The circus storyline was very interesting (ie
column7: how a circus works
column9: etc). I was also surprised to find a good description of getting old. If you're interested in reading just that part of the book
column10: skip the chapters with pictures at the beginning. In doing so
column11: you'll also skip most of the foul language.I've given this book 3 stars
column12: but it really should be 2 and a half."

column6: "reviewText": "It took me a long time to pick up Water for Elephants
column7: because I'm generally not a fan of the same type of books that seem so popular. I was hesitant when I first bought it and wasn't expecting much. I was pleasantly surprised when I dove into it - I couldn't put it down. I've heard a lot of people complain that this falls short of \"real\" circus life - but I can tell you
column8: it's as close as I'm sure you'll ever get in this day and age
column9: unless you talk to someone who worked back then. I can tell you from experience that circuses and carnivals have changed
column11: from their old days. While I can't say I've traveled on a circus
column12: I have grown up on a carnival that has been in my family for decades. The stories passed down from earlier times
column14: etc tell a very different tale from the modern day carnivals. I'm sure Water for Elephants is the same way. Sara Gruen is a favorite author of mine since I read her horse series years ago. I was sucked into this book from the beginning and was very pleasantly surprised by the way things progressed. There was never a dull moment in the book
column15: though it was easy to guess what was happening next during most of it. It was a surprisingly dark book
column16: but it was done in a way that did not make it terrible to read. The characters were interesting and engaging
column17: though the love between the two main characters seemed rushed and sloppy. I would have rather seen a longer book with more development between them
column18: but I can't complain too much. It was an exciting
column20: read and I recommend it to anyone who is a fan of romance or simply interested in an old-time circus setting. I only hope the movie turns out as good as this book ( though my hope is not high )."

column6: "reviewText": "I avoided reading this book for a long time because I feared it was over rated- I was wrong.  Well worth the read. Good story
column7: easily connected to the characters - loved every minute of it.For those who compared this book to HBOs series Carnival - very very wrong.... general story
column9: theme - nothing the same. I was an avid watcher of the 'Carnival'
column10: the whole black magic thing- loved it. 'Water for Elephants' has none of that.  Comparing the two stories would be like comparing movies 'The Hangover' and the HBO series 'Empire Boardwalk' and the common trait is they both have gambling and take place in a gambling city (not event he same city).  'Carnival' and 'Water for Elephants' only common thread is that take place in the same time in history and based on traveling entertainers (not even the same type of traveling groups).My big regret is not finishing the book before they announced the movie and who was playing the characters - but that's not the books fault."

column6: "reviewText": "I'm not picky about my books
column7: really! I read airport books! I read mystery novels! But about half-way through

column10: anyway. I was waiting for more elephant plot. But no- Ms. Gruen got even lazier at the end.  Anything and anyone that might have been considered a loose end gets killed off without regret.  \"Mr. Major Character W? We threw him off the train 30 minutes ago. Probably(!!) died. Don't worry about it.\"I was disappointed."

column6: "reviewText": "As avid readers there are times when we are apt to encounter books that continue and linger in our minds once read.  For me
column7: \"Water for Elephants\" was a serendipitous find and I truly and lovingly enjoyed this novel.  It's one of those books that you never want to end.  There is reason why this book has been on the NY Times bestseller list for more than 12 consecutive weeks.  As many reviewers have already recounted the summary I will simply say just READ IT!  I promise you will be searching for more of Sara Gruen's novels.  BTW
column8: Apehouse is the next novel to be released!"

column6: "reviewText": "** spoiler alert ** Like many people before me
column7: I picked up this book after having seen and enjoyed the movie. This is one rare occasion where I loved the movie more than the book (but that may just be because I saw the movie first.) In some ways this is like an amped up romance novel. There's so much focus on the romance between Jacob and Marlena but she has the personality of a wet napkin so I really don't get the appeal. When I read the negative reviews for this book a lot of people made issue with the \" graphic and frequent sex scenes\" it made me somewhat hesitant to read it but those concerns were unfounded. There was some sex
column8: and some thoughts of sex and some lit nips BUT the story is being told by a sex-deprived geriatric/ a horny teenage VIRGIN! If anyone was shocked that a 19yo was obsessed with scoring a little trim they should walk directly off the nearest cliff. It was a bit more detail than necessary but I've read sex scenes that made me cringe from the details and this wasn't that. If I had to list my own personal complaints I would start with the ending
column9: that was literally my biggest issue with this novel. There are some big
column11: elephant sized holes my friends. I mean
column13: stand around Bumpuckey West Nowhereland with 12 horses and and elephant for however many days until Ringling could come pick them up? I mean I get that it was a happy ending
column14: the sun will come out tomorrow etc. but the author basically did a Sopranos style fade to black. What about the other animals?! Whatever
column16: I could go off on an all day tangent.... point is there was something to be desired. My favorite parts of the book were mostly centered around Old Jacob
column17: he was by far the best written (and my favorite) character. Curious as to why they cut the Rosemary character out of the movie
column18: because their relationship was a nice really sweet. Overall it was a good read
column19: I enjoyed traveling back in time to the circus and I am willing to overlook the flaws to take the trip."

column6: "reviewText": "I would have never believed that I would have enjoyed this book. Let alone enjoyed it to the extreme level which I did. A well respected friend recommended this book to me so I pull it up online and read the synopsis. Well
column7: the synopsis and subject matter regarding circus life in the mid 1900's did not interest me in the least bit. Suffice to say I did not immediately read it. Only after subsequent prompting from my friend did I agree to give it a shot. That turned out to be an EXCELLENT idea. It was clear and concise reading that gave me vivid images of that era and written with short chapters that propelled me along to read just a little more each time since I was skeptical from the start. The story recounted through the eyes of an old man reminiscing his youth was pulled off seamlessly. It was like reading two stories. Now
column8: after reading the book for myself I'm amazed at the few negative reviewer's comments. I'm reminded that some people complain about everything."
column10: "summary": "Amazed That I Enjoyed This So Much"

column6: "reviewText": "I absolutely loved loved this book. The characters were easy to follow
column7: to relate to . I felt like i was riding along
column8: like i was a part of the circus!Jacob Jankowski : \" I am ninety. Or ninety-three. One or the other.\" Jacob is living in a senior citizen home
column10: depressed and starting to lose his memory . The author does a wonderful job of alternating between Jacobs story of his life in the circus and his current life.The details of circus life
column12: the sadness and the happy times.I highly recommend reading this one. On a scale of 1-10 this definitely gets a 10!!"
column14: "summary": "An awesome read- couldn't put it down."

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is a love story. Love between a man and a woman; love between humans and animals; and people's love of circuses. All these sub-stories coalesce into one that is set at the time of the Great Depression to make up the background of this book.The book starts with a horrendous scene in which the circus's animals stampede and a murder takes place. A man's head is split open by a big stake. The next chapter is in the nursing home where we get to meet a 90+ year old man named Jacob who is in a nursing home. Jacob is lucid and his mind is still sharp and he comments on the other residents of the nursing home who are much further along the path of dementia and senility. The rest of the book bounces around between Jacob in the nursing home
column7: and Jacob as the brand-new minted veterinarian.Putting the story in a time line
column8: Jacob is about set to graduate from the Cornell Veterinary School when a tragic accident kills his parents. He is an only child and it turns out that his parents took all of their savings and a mortgage out on their house to be able to afford to send him to Cornell. When they die
column9: there is nothing left for him so he returns to Cornell to sit for his final exams. His mind is not on schooling and he ends up leaving the school and wanders down the road. It's not long before he decides to hop on a train that is travelling by and this gets him introduced into the world of the circus as it just happens to be a circus train that he jumps on.Being the time of the Great Depression
column10: there is a chance that he will get thrown directly off the train as a hobo but he manages to make some friends among the crowd of laborers and they get him accepted as another laborer on the circus until it is discovered that he is almost a veterinarian. For the circus owner
column11: that is close enough and Jacob is now the circus's vet. Now he moves up in the world and is allowed to travel in a train car with performers and meets the love of his life amongst them. He also meets up with animals that he treats with empathy and kindness - and they respond with friendship.He also meets with some of the more zany and crazy people who inhabit that world and none of them are necessarily nice. There is a crazy horse trainer; violent security men; \"patch men\" who clean up the inevitable problems and messes that take place; and
column13: the associated laborers and hangers-on who populate the world. Jacob deals with them all in his own way and the story develops in a relatively predictable manner. It is no surprise that the animals respond to Jacob's kindness in kind and find ways to get back at the people who treat them badly. There are numerous anecdotes sprinkled throughout the book culled from the rich history of the circus world - things like the Lemonade Thief; the Animal who only understands Polish; and the less than legal activities that surrounded the circus.The climax of the story is presented in the first chapter - the murder. There is no real mystery there - we know who will get murdered right after the first meeting with the man. What is left in doubt is who did the killing. That is resolved in a very satisfying way at the end of the book.However
column14: there is another storyline here too. The old Jacob finds out that a circus is coming to perform outside his nursing home and he would dearly like to go back to the world that he left 60-odd years before - if only for a visit. But
column15: wouldn't you know it - that happens to be the week that his family forgets to come visit him in the nursing home. The twist that the author puts in at this point is brilliant and brings the whole book to a double satisfying ending which proves that once you are involved in a world that you really like
column16: you never really leave it.This was overall a very fun book to read. Being an animal lover
column17: I really appreciated the insights into the world of the exotic - and not so exotic - animals provided. Of course
column18: the whole glimpse into the world of circus life was also interesting. About the only negative thing I have to say about the book is its almost obsessive fascination with human sexuality. There is almost no single chapter that does not have a sex scene in it and it is not clear to me how most of them contribute to the overall story line. In other words
column19: I would not give this story to your younger children to read

column6: "reviewText": "Sara Gruen's \"Water for Elephants\" is a one of those books that fascinate you with a look inside an unfamiliar world while entertaining you. The author is very adept at spinning a yarn

column6: "reviewText": "I hesitated reading this book for three reasons:1. I don't like circuses.2. I am not particularly interested in books written about the Depression era. (I find both #1 & #2 well
column7: depressing).3. I don't like reading the \"latest best seller/Oprah Book\".I am very glad I went against my own prejudices and read this book.  The sections about his current life as a 90 or 93 year old (he is not sure how old he is
column8: or exactly what year it is right now) were charming and a realistic view into the mind of someone who is both angry that he is being treated like he has lost his mind and afraid that he actually is losing it.The sections of him as a young man working learning the ropes of circus life were interesting and enlightened me on the crazy
column9: unstable life that was so common for so many people during the Depression.  It was also impossible to not be enamored with some of the circus animals like Rosie the elephant and Bobo the chimp (or was she an orangutan?).The only thing I DIDN\"T like about the book was an excerpt from the New York Times Book Review that I made the mistake of reading off the back cover:\"With a showman's expert timing
column10: [Gruen] saves a terrific revelation for the final pages
column11: transforming a glimpse of Americana into an enchanting escapist fairy tale.\"I read the book afraid that it would turn out to be the dreams or fantasies of an old man who never actually worked for a circus.  The ending was sweet and heartening; nothing that transformed the book for me

column6: "reviewText": "**Note: my review will not do this book justice! LOL. I loved the book so much I'm try not to let myself give too much away!**My Description:Water for Elephants is a novel bringing us back to the world of the traveling circus in the early 1900′s when they traveled by train.  Jacob Jankowski is a young man in his early 20′s with dreams of becoming a veterinarian like his father.  Very close to the final day for his testing to become licensed his parents die in a car accident and his entire life changes.  Running away from his problems he ends up jumping on a train and this one-act takes him on the ride of his life.  Jacob becomes a worker for a traveling circus as their very own vet and in the process falls in love with Marlena
column7: one of the shows acts.  The problem
column8: she's a married woman.  Along their travels the circus owner buys an Elephant
column10: in hopes to become the greatest act in all the history of circuses...Water for Elephants is a magical book! It brought me back to when I was a child dreaming of being a circus performer.  The way Gruen describes the circus and it's acts really paints a picture in your mind and you feel like you are right there with Jacob the entire time.  I loved how Gruen cuts back and forth between Jacob as an elderly man in a home remembering when he was on a circus to when Jacob was in his early 20′s on the circus.  You love Jacob in both ages
column11: especially as a  feisty elderly man! I love when Gruen brought Jacob in as an elderly man
column12: he brings in some comedy as well as makes you understand how some elderly people feel when they are in a nursing home.Gruen knows how to writer her characters.  You fall in love with so many of them!  Walter
column13: Jacob's roommate on the train. Camel
column14: the man who takes Jacob in under his wing when Jacob first jumps on the train.  The lovely Marlena
column16: the beautiful 53-year-old-elephant.  You also don't like some of the characters like Uncle Al
column20: there are times you just want to jump through the book and beat them yourselves!I absolutely fell in love with this book.  I had two of my good friends telling me that I must read it because it was just that good and I was not disappointed.  I do believe that anyone who has an interest in any genre would love this book!  It's a very fast read and you don't want to put it down. Again
column21: it's just magical! It leaves you smiling and happy.  This book will be on my bookshelf forever and will be picked up several times for a reread! :-DOh
column22: you can buy the Kindle version of this book for just a little over $4.00 but from what I've heard you don't get the awesome circus pictures throughout the book.  Gruen places a real circus picture at the beginning of each chapter that is from when Jacob is in his 20′s on the circus.  It's awesome! There is only one chapter that didn't have a circus pic infront of it when it should have
column23: :-( but really they are great.  If you buy the kindle version
column24: the next time you're in the bookstore pick up the paperback version and flip through and check out the pictures at least...they're fun!  :-D"

column6: "reviewText": "Gruen paints a portrait of the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth
column7: a Depression-era  train circus
column13: \" who grew fat off the carcasses of circusses that collapsed after the Crash. Their losses were his gains.  The Prologue introduces the narrative which begins with a stampede of circus animals
column14: and we are introduced to a secret which is kept by the narrator for 70 years.  The reader is immediately pulled into the narrative.The narrative is juxtaposed between Jacob Jankowski's life during the seven years he spent in the circus and his present life as an irascible 90 or 93 (he can't remember which) year old man in an assisted living facility.  As a young  veterinary student about to graduate from Cornell
column15: Jacob finds himself homeless and parentless and is unable to take his final exams.  He finds himself jumping on a train which turns out to be Benzini's Circus train.  The reader is introduced to circus lingo - rubes are the circus-goers
column16: kinkers are the performers and Patches are the men assigned to smooth the ruffled feathers of disgruntled spectators who might be angry they didn't get their money's worth at the Freak Show or those of a homeowner whose garden has been destroyed by a wandering elephant. One is given a glimpse into the highly stratified
column17: almost caste-like social world of the circus in which performers never rubbed elbows with the likes of the lowly workers
column18: particulary the black workers of the Flying Squadron
column19: who were instructed to run into their tents and remain invisible as soon as the rubes started to make their appearance.The novel is plot-driven
column20: and although there are many stereotypical elements - there are the requisite evil villains - Uncle Al and his sidekick August Rosenbluth
column21: the equestrian director and superintendent of animals who is hated and feared for his violent tendencies and his legendary cruelty to humans and circus animals. There is also the requisite central love story between two gentle souls sho have been dealt life's difficult blows
column22: but whose goodness and pure intentions help them to weather the storm. There is Bobo the orangutuan and particularly Rosie the elephant
column24: and we root for them as much as we root for Jacob and Marlena. If you are looking for a novel embedded with deep hidden meanings and rich with literary technique and complex characterization
column25: then this is definitely not the book for you. If you are looking for a plot-driven novel whose events proceed rapidly and which transports the reader to another world
column26: then I highly recommend this delightfully readable novel.In spite of the stereotypical elements
column27: I thoroughly enjoyed this novel. I found myself getting up extra early and staying up extra late to get to the last page
column29: I was sorry the journey was over. I wasn't quite ready to say goodbye to Jacob
column30: Marlena
column31: Kinko
column32: Camel
column33: Rosie or Bobo.  Perhaps I will just read it again."
column34: "overall": 4.0

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants further romanticizes the age-old dream to runaway and join the circus. Unfortunately for Jacob (our star) it was not his dream to join the circus
column7: but rather coincidence mixed with his last hope. The story is told from two viewpoints: Jacob is now ninety-something years old and we see what has become of our young protagonist
column8: and we see many flashback sequences to the events that took place as he traveled with the circus.As readers we are exposed to the sharp contrast between his youth and aged eras. With the circus
column9: Jacob's life was so full of adventure and non-stop activity. Now he is resident in an assisted-living facility and he fears he is losing his energy and becoming more and more like the peers with whom he shares lodging. As he relives the excitement of his days with the Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth he not only longs for a different time
column10: but resets his grip on his past. He is one old man who is not ready to give up on life.Sara Gruen gave us a beautiful story about a man who refuses to let go of the events that changed his life. As you read about Jacob your heart will break and then
column12: it will break again. It is much more than one young man's tale of woe
column13: however. The story is one of love
column15: never giving up and some unlikely good friends. You will laugh
column17: delight and cheer with Jacob whether he is twenty something or ninety something. I really appreciate that the author went the extra mile in her research of life in the circus.I didn't think I would like Water for Elephants
column18: but I heard from too many people that it was good. When that happens
column19: I had no choice but to give it a try. I really liked this book. And I'm glad I read it."
column21: "summary": "Don't be deterred by the circus setting.  This was very good."

column6: "reviewText": "I was a bit apprehensive about reading this book

column9: his trials and tribulations.  I think that both could have easily been expanded and still kept the reader's interest - wanted to know more about each character who are one and the same!  Bravo!"

column6: "reviewText": "I liked this book
column7: wouldn't say it was the best one I've ever read though. The story itself was well thought out and put together with good incorporations of the flashback to 1931 and the action occurring in the present. I think right after the beginning when Jacob first joins the circus and they get the elephant is a little slow where there is not really much of a plot that has been introduced yet so it was slightly tedious in some parts in that area. The other thing is that there might have been a couple of unnecessary characters that made the story too much of a task to follow at times with all the names and who is who and such."

column6: "reviewText": "Sara Gruen's Water for Elephants is a creative delight.  She uses structure
column7: plot
column8: and setting with originality.  She employs literary devices in innovative ways.  Her characters are believable even though they inhabit the unreal world of the circus.First
column9: structure and plot.  Gruen describes the ending of the novel in the prologue.  She infuses the prologue with ambiguity so the reader cannot be clear about what happened.  She structures the rest of the book as a search for answers to the perplexing prologue.Second
column10: innovative literary devices.  Gruen withholds information like a magician.  This device (suspense) allows her to keep the reader engaged
column11: and befuddled. The novel reads like the children's storytelling game where the narrator brings a character to an impossible situation then hands the storytelling over to the next person.  Each chapter has a rise and fall.Another literary device Gruen handles creatively is point of view.  The story
column13: is seen through the consciousness of Jacob Jankowski.  But Jacob's point of view is complicated because it alternates between Jacob in his twenties
column14: and Jacob in his nineties.  So the reader sees two viewpoints depending upon which stage of life Jacob narrates his story from.Finally setting and characters.  Gruen's setting and characters are unusual.  The background is Midwestern
column15: and depression-era.  The culture is the circus (Benzini's not-quite-as-good-as-Ringling-Bros Circus).  The characters are performers
column25: and care for each other with a common goal: to produce a show.  Though the setting and characters are specific
column26: the reader can relate to them because they display the same passions and vulnerability we all do.  Gruen transcends specificity and finds universal connections.  Life is performing in the Big Top.  We are all players.  We struggle with good and evil
column29: life and death.  The show goes on.  Sara Gruen writes with originality and soul."
column30: "overall": 4.0
column31: "summary": "Originality and Soul"

column6: "reviewText": "Jacob Jankowski
column7: like many Americans
column8: was having a hard time in the Great Depression.  After failing to complete veterinary school
column9: he ends up working on a traveling circus
column10: going to town after town with the big top acts
column12: and the menagerie of exotic animals.  He quickly learns that there is a darker side to the circus behind the scenes that the happy
column13: popcorn eating crown never sees.The set up workers are considered expendable and are kicked off the train if they stay on past their usefulness
column14: and animals are often treated cruelly and ruthlessly.  Out of necessity
column15: sometimes life was cruel during the Great Depression
column16: but sleazy ringmaster Uncle Al and violent animal trainer August Rosenbluth choose to perpetrate this unnecessarily at the Benzini Brothers circus.  Jacob remains part of this world as he is tied by love and duty to the animals in his care
column17: as well as his friends and the beautiful Marlena
column18: wife of August.This was not always an easy book to read.  There are graphic scenes of animal cruelty that had me wincing
column19: as well as heartbreaking scenes of human disappointments and pain.  Despite this
column20: I recommend this novel wholeheartedly.  Sara Gruen describes the scene perfectly
column21: from the Great Depression to the atmosphere of the circus
column22: and there are some uplifting messages about the powers of kindness and love for the reader to take away as well.  I also recommend her previous two novels Riding Lessons and Flying Changes."

Thankfully this adds to the story and doesn't bog it down. This story showed me that the circus is as much a lifestyle as it is a business.I would recommend this book to anyone and will probably read it again - and these are the highest compliments I can give to a book."

column6: "reviewText": "After reading several reviews
column7: I think that many readers may have missed the entire point of \"Water for Elephants\".  Some reviewers said that the book didn't say much about circus life and some say they did not care about learning about the circus. \"WFE\" teaches us that it is ok to rememeber fondly those most rewarding experiences throughout your life but also that it is never too late to create new experiences.  It also provides us with a unique perspective of everyday life in a senior living facility...a place that many of us may end up in one day."
column9: "summary": "Moving story about living your life to the fullest"

column6: "reviewText": "Oh
column7: Water for Elephants... America loves you. America loves you so much that Hollywood is making a movie about you starring Reese and Rob (swoon!). So why can't I love you too?Probably because you had so much potential and didn't live up to it. I will admit
column8: my expectations were a little high
column9: given how much hype has surrounded this book

column11: my reaction was just... meh.I picked up Water for Elephants because:Like I said

column13: the book didn't really live up to the hype for me. And the love story was just okay. It wasn't particularly passionate or compelling - I would call it \"love story lite\". I would actually describe the whole book as \"lite\". It ended exactly how I expected to end. There were no twists
column15: and it just didn't have much depth. Which is really disappointing because the setting was great. A circus
column16: traveling through the U.S. by train
column18: with hundreds of employees and a whole menagerie of animals
column20: provides so much potential for an interesting story. Unfortunately
column21: the author didn't put this great source material to the best use.Don't get me wrong - I finished the book and finished it pretty quickly. It was a fast read and there were some good characters
column22: but I just wanted more. More detail
column24: more depth. Water for Elephants just didn't go far enough for me.In a nutshell: Just okay. Water for Elephants would make a decent beach read

I thought the story was fascinating about a young man whose veterinary education is interrupted and he hops a circus train.  He becomes the circus vet and his whole life changes. Of course this all happens during the Great Depression.  I guess I liked this book because of the background research by the author about circuses during that period.  The old photos were charming as well. Like another reviewer mentioned not all of the facts regarding the care of animals may have been accurate but it's a fictional story and I think you have to give some license to that.  It's a book you would take on the plane or to the beach just to enjoy!"

column6: "reviewText": "After reading the hysterical prologue (\"A polar bear towered above it all
column7: slashing blindly with skillet-sized paws. It made contact with a llama and knocked it flat - BOOM. The llama hit the ground

column6: "reviewText": "Every now and then I find a book that is so wonderful.  It's like finding the lone needle in a haystack.  This book is a treat.  Imagery is beautiful
column7: characters are fabulous
column8: and I loved that the animals had personalities (as they do in real life).  I recommend this for someone who loves to read for pleasure.  Can't believe I almost didn't read this because it was about a circus; that would have been my loss."

column6: "reviewText": "And read this fabulous story.  I could not put it down.  The author's insight into all things human
column7: notably aging
column8: is phenomenal.  This book is top of the line in every respect.  Thank you Sara Gruen for all your inspired research and talent."

column6: "reviewText": "I will admit
column7: the only reason I bought this

column9: but the story grabs you from the very beginning
column10: and holds you until the end. As vacuous as it may seem

column6: "reviewText": "This is the type of novel I expect to be on the bestseller list and is why I typically overlook popular novels
column7: sometimes to my own detriment. An elderly man
column9: looks back on his time spent as a veterinarian in a circus. It's a story that could have been capable of more
column10: but the plot seemed fairly predictable and the characters not that believable or rounded. It wasn't bad
column12: I guess you could say this elephant was just too watered down."

column6: "reviewText": "Having read after watching the movie

column6: "reviewText": "This was a refreshingly interesting read due to its uniqueness.  Much research was done to make it as realistic as possible and it shows through - you'd be missing out not to read this book!"
column7: "overall": 5.0

column6: "reviewText": "Quite a few people recommended I read this book and I'm glad I did! It had all the components you want in a good book
column7: and a fantastic inside look of the depression era circus. You can't help but love or hate the characters
column8: and I found myself smiling at the end. Read it!"

column6: "reviewText": "This book was recommended to me by a friend. I went out
column7: bought it and finally read it. It was amazing book. The book kept me hooked to the last sentence.  It was well writtin and you get to feel sorry for the old man but he finds peace in the end.  This book does not disappoint.  It is a time peace but you will still love it."

column6: "reviewText": "I really enjoyed this historical novel about a depression-era circus and the people who work in it."
column7: "overall": 4.0

column6: "reviewText": "Water for Elephants is one of the best books I've read in a long time. This book was mentioned several times in the House at Riverton book club I participated in; and was a huge seller during the holidays on Amazon.  I figured even though it wasn't a book I would normally pick up and start reading
column7: I would give it a try.I'm so glad I did!The story setting was depression era circus life...more than intriguing! Sara Gruen did an amazing job with her research and the detail she outlined in the book.  She was able to find a perfect balance of grisly and romantic.  Gruen used that same \"memory sequence\" style of storytelling as The House at Riverton
column9: and Rebecca.  The flips from past to present were seamless.Gruen's depiction of the narrator as a 98 year old man was awesome.  She allowed the reader to understand the traumas of being \"that old\" as well as remind us there's often a pretty amazing story to most of the older generation.Each character had a function in the story
column10: including the nursing home staff.  There were no superficial characters and every single character helped you to understand \"who\" the main character was.This was one of those fun reads that sucks you in and makes you wish the story could go on forever.  I ended the book feeling like I wanted to join a circus
column12: and wanted to work in a nursing home.  All very strange
column13: indeed!  Its not often a book I read can make me want to do anything remotely close to those things."
column15: "summary": "One of the best books I've read in a while"

column6: "reviewText": "A true grit romance with all the details of the hard life of \"carnies\".  An amazing tale of one man's life
column7: survival and eventually love."

column6: "reviewText": "When I read the summary of this book
column7: I wondered why it was so popular.  It didn't sound like anything I'd ever want to read
column8: but when a fellow book obsessed friend of mine told me that I had to read it
column9: and I had to read it immediately
column10: I took her advice.  Boy am I glad I did!  This book is so well written
column12: and the story is absorbing.  I live near a circus museum
column13: and am now planning a trip to visit because of this book.  I highly recommend it to anyone that loves a good story!  I've also read Riding Lessons and Flying Changes and am eagerly awaiting her next novel!"

column6: "reviewText": "It's OK.  It's long and not really eventful until the end.  It took me a bit to get into it"
column7: "overall": 3.0

column6: "reviewText": "It is very rare that I don't finish a book. I just couldn't find a single reason to continue reading; the writing style is that of a children's book - in a strange combination with graphic sex and 21st century profanity (both of which I don't mind in the right setting)
column7: the language doesn't match the 30ies
column8: the cruelty to animals made me cringe

column6: "reviewText": "I found this book to be an engaging and interesting read.  There were several authenticity and continuity issues that bothered me.  During the era of this situation
column7: Fox Terriers were very common and used a great deal in entertainment.  Jack Russel terriers are a relatively recent introduction to the US.Jacob gives his watch away
column8: and then it reappears.  There are two or 3 other gaffs along this line that are annoying.  It would be great if the author would put out a new edition with these things corrected.Rose
column9: the elephant is the real heroine of this novel
column10: and she provides the frame for the story."

column6: "reviewText": "I found Sara Gruen's WATER FOR ELEPHANTS thoroughly enchanting in a very engrossing tale of the 1930s traveling circus Benzini Brothers Most Spectacular Show on Earth. Part wonder
column7: part adventure
column10: my first Gruen novel conveys a novel artistry in the settings
column12: prose and storytelling that resonated. Similar to another I read recently (Cornwell's rendition of Arthur)
column13: we find a popular style of writing I find many authors choosing as of late: a first-person narration that shifts from a flashback when he's 23 years old and to the present tense when he's 90... or 93. The flashback comprises the bulk of the book's content over the span of 3 to 4 months when 23 year-old Jacob lands in a shady traveling circus amidst the historical backdrop of the Great Depression and the prohibition of alcohol. Normally
column14: first-person flashbacks tend to affect a doleful disposition. Not so here. Remarkably
column15: I found the present happenings of our senile 90-or-93 year-old Jacob in a nursing home refreshingly funny and instructively captivating as we laugh and empathize with Jacob. I'll never look at my grandmother the same way again. In fact the book derives its title from a grumpy Jacob grousing over another old man claiming to bring water for elephants in his younger days.Personal wants and simple plot devices prevented a perfect 5-star rating on my part. I'm impressed by Gruen's research into the time period and traveling circuses
column18: symmetric storytelling and gritty characterizations far surpasses many of my 4 and 5-star books. I read a 553-page large print edition of WATER FOR ELEPHANTS containing black-and-white photos of 1930s circuses and for the 100 to 200 pages
column19: I was enthralled. The wonder and the adventure of it had me smiling and on the edge of my seat. The book then settles down with the August-Rosenbluth character who factors in more and more prominently. Much of the plotting deals with August
column20: his wife Marlena and our protagonist Jacob as the third wheel at a private dinner or outing. August's violent schizophrenia took center stage and the August character and his prominence choked much of my enthusiasm. Instead of August
column21: I was hoping for more wonders of the circus
column24: and more plots with the animals of the menagerie. The caste-like
column25: hierarchal circus society consisting of performers
column26: workers and rubes was very interesting
column27: but Jacob's helplessness within that hierarchy
column29: proved altogether exasperating. I was hoping to see Jacob doing more
column30: whether helping the elephant or protecting Marlena (both from August). I also found the ending a bit disappointing and anticlimactic
column31: I wanted to see at least one more chapter of closure in the flashback rather than relaying the aftermath in the present tense.At its heart
column32: the book expresses Jacob's story of love -- an impossible love for his wife
column33: a love for animals and the elephant
column34: and of course
column35: a love for the wondrous circus. Unlike so many potboiler romance novels
column36: here's a love between a man and woman that isn't so trite: we have a sexually-inexperienced
column37: red-haired 23 year-old college boy and the compassionate star of the circus who dares to love him
column39: warrants his affection
column40: caring
column41: loyalty and love. Even though their first love scene isn't ideal by romance standards
column42: it nevertheless reverberates with passion and we witness Jacob's joy for giving as she guides him. Granted
column43: it's written entirely from Jacob's perspective and even though the first lovemaking wasn't scientifically precise (again
column44: by romance standards)
column45: the book captures how each gives their heart for the other. Everything isn't initiated by Jacob and that in itself was noteworthy. For myself
column46: love is about mutual giving
column47: and I always hope to see some semblance of that. WATER FOR ELEPHANTS doesn't disappoint.I'm astonished to read a very believable and resonating account of a male character written by a woman. In spite of Jacob's frustrating helplessness at times
column49: how passionate and how intense he was about the animals
column50: friends and love he cares for. I appreciated Jacob's passion and intensity minus the inane
column51: repetitious introspection so common to the romance genre. No
column52: guys don't think and muse about things for endless pages
column53: and Gruen thankfully discarded that element of the romance. Things are happening anyway
column54: so Gruen need not fill the pages with cheap introspection.The story actually begins with the ending. It was actually deftly done
column55: and Gruen fills in the details when we encounter the prologue at the very end of the book again. Ironically
column56: this added a measure of suspense to the novel.  As I mentioned before
column57: I thought the book limped to its conclusion. I would have appreciated another chapter in the flashback depicting our protagonists in a new act with another circus.Still
column58: I found the reading experience a captivating novelty to say the least."

column6: "reviewText": "This book came recommended to me by a couple of friends
column7: but I won't recommend it to anyone else as long as there are plenty of other decent books to read out there.It was relatively engaging in that I wasn't bored.  And it has a lot of potential.  But when I reflected on the story as a whole
column8: I realized it didn't accomplish anything interesting
column10: intelligently complex.  I found it absolutely laughable that it had book club discussion questions at the end. For the life of me
column11: I don't know what there is to dissect
column13: or discuss about it!I never felt emotionally connected to any of the characters
column14: except for the old man's musings at the beginning on growing old and being ignored by family in the midst of their own busy-ness.  Frankly
column15: I was surprised that the love story ended up the way it did because I didn't realize the \"love story\" part of it was actually to be taken seriously.  The couple was so flat and void of chemistry.I didn't appreciate that the book started with a future event only to get to that actual part of the story and learn that it was quite different from what the prologue led me to believe.  That kind of fake-out should be reserved for 1-hour TV shows
column16: not books.  It was sloppy and it set me as the reader on the wrong course for the rest of the book.About 2/3 of the way through the book
column17: I was just pushing through to finish it and say I finished it.  Sometimes a book can redeem itself in the end
column18: but this ending was too ridiculous for redemption.I've read some good modern fiction recently
column19: but this doesn't make the list.  It's a real shame it's going to get a bump in revenue because of the movie -- and because it's a Robert Pattinson movie at that.  (sigh)"

column6: "reviewText": "It's tough to be the sour note in a chorus of \"Hallelujahs.\"  \"Water for Elephants\" disappointed me.
